story:
Four brand new short plays written by four up-and-coming new writers. In a world of quick fixes, Generation Y are said to have limited attention spans and seek instant gratification. But can we... oh never mind.  

Who we are

MF Productions was put together by Mark Donald and Francesca Bailey. They met whilst training at the Bristol Old Vic Theatre School and have worked together many times. 

The company has come together to champion young talent and new writing and we are thrilled that this project has already been sponsored by Sir Ian Mckellen, but we need your help to make it happen. 

When and Where?

The show will be performed at 'The Hen and Chicken Theatre' in Islington East London. We run from the 14th-18th July with two shows on the 18th. We'd love to see you there! 

The Writers and their Plays

History by Mark QUARTLEY

Midnight. An empty apartment. Slowly, piece by piece, She fills the room with objects from Their lives. History is a play told in reverse; an examination of a relationship that should have ended where it started.


Mark is a graduate of the Royal Court Young Writers’ Programme and Stephen Jeffreys’ Advanced Playwriting course.  He has had work produced and/or developed at Theatre 503, Soho Theatre, Northampton Theatre Royal, RADA, NYT, the NT studio and the Bedlam Theatre in Edinburgh. He has two degrees, in Philosophy (Durham University) and Acting (RADA).

Off the Grid by Roisin KELLY

'This is our way of living. The new way of living'. 
Tired of the empty materialism of society, Tash and Rory are trying something new. Cutting themselves off from westernised culture and everything that comes with it, they make a new life for themselves depending on nature alone. A short comedy following a young couple as they prepare to live life 'Off The Grid'.

Writing credits include: 'The Ladies of The Sacred Heart' (FTG Productions, Edinburgh Fringe), 'Bums and Tums' (FTG Productions, Comedy Pub), 'May The Lord Be With You' (Hurtwood Theatre, Cockpit Theatre), co-writer of 'Edgar and The Land of Lost' (Wardrobe Ensemble, BikeShed Theatre)

Plankton by Ben CALLON


‘Don’t you find it exhausting? Every like, every wink, every tick, every swipe, every bloody cat faced emoji! It’s like we need them to live, these miniscule bits of validation, like a mist of digital plankton but we’re never nourished, we’re never full’ A fifteen minute short looking at the disposability of love and validation for the generation Y. 

A professionally trained actor, who swiftly realised that he would have a little time on his hands between jobs (approximately 11 months per year) Ben Callon made his foray into writing in 2014 with the debut of his one act play ‘A Little Bit OCD’. The project aimed to distigmatise the often ill represented disorder with as little preachiness and as much wit as is physically possible. The sold out run/raft of starry reviews put a little fire in the pensmith’s belly and he now continues to seek the truth in uncomfortable places.

Just like a Woman by Suzie Preece

"When we first met at a house party he wanted to play his guitar at me – for me. The way he kept strumming it and stroking it… It was almost like an extension of his penis. And I sat opposite him on his bed thinking I might be touched in a similar manner…"

Sophie doesn't want to be pregnant. She is an intelligent measured young woman who makes rational life decisions. But we find her in a pharmacy wondering whether she's lying to herself. 

Is it quite simple to swallow a pill and shrug life off?

Suzie created the Web series Turn Me Online. She trained at the Bristol Old Vic Theatre School. Theatre Credits include: The Provoked Wife, St Giles In-The-Fields, Fallujah, Cockpit Theatre, A Midsummer Night's Dream, Burnt Out Theatre, The Capone Trilogy, Edinburgh Fringe, After The End, Alma Tavern Theatre. 

What We Need 
£1,200 for the Theatre Hire
  • We're taking the show to the Hen and Chicken Theatre. It's a venue with a strong focus on new writing right in the heart of Islington in East London.
£500 Props, Costume and Set
  • We will be creating a multifaceted swiftly moving set that can house each of the four plays, and will need to provide the costume and props to support each piece. 
£50 Van Hire
  • This is very complicated. We need a van....to transport things...
£100 Promotional Material 
  • Promoting the show is going to be really important, so we're going to be designing and producing flyers and posters to really get the message out.  
£150 Rehearsal Space
  • This is where the work really takes place. We need a rehearsal space to create this work and make it the outstanding show we know it can be. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to support us financially, we would love your support in other ways. 

  • Light up our life! - We need as many filament light bulbs as we can find to be part of our set. If you have one you wouldn't mind giving to us, please let us know!
  • Please share this page on twitter/Facebook/blogs 
  • Follow us on twitter to keep up to date on our news

story:
What We Do:
  • REASONABLY PRICED Aerial Dance classes for adults
  • SCHOLARSHIPS for adult dancers of color to study Aerial Dance with us
  • FREE Creative Movement Classes for Kids
  • PERFORMANCES of expressive Aerial Dance

Upcoming Events:

PERFORM:
Fly-by-Night dancer, Janet Aisawa, is getting ready for a July performance at the International Somatic Dance Conference at Dean College in Franklin, MA. Janet will be doing a solo called Out From Under from our 2013 multi-media evening, Passages.

PRESENT:
Artistic Director Julie Ludwick will be presenting "A Somatic Approach to Aerial Dance" - the technique that we have developed over the past two decades.  The presentation will include how aspects of Skinner Releasing Technique are integrated into our classes. We hope conference attendees will want to experience this technique on a deeper level and join in our NYC classes or invite us to work with them in their communities.

CREATE:
In the coming year we will begin a new work, Thresholds, that will explore the transformations that are inevitable as we pass into new phases of our lives. We will explore these aspects through Trapeze-Dance and Video projection.

Where Your Donation Dollars Go:

  • $50 covers 2 ½ hours of studio time for the solo being performed in July
  • $100 covers 6 months of rigging replacement costs
  • $180 covers 10 classes for a scholarship student
  • $250 covers one month of insurance premiums
  • $1000 covers rehearsal fees for a draft of the new work, Thresholds
Meeting our Goals
Your donation will insure that we can continue to offer all of our programs on a regular basis. As we enter our 16th fiscal year we will continue to serve and expand our community but can't do this without support from you!

Our Thanks - What We Can Offer You
Discounted classes, eco-friendly shopping bags with our logo, unique experiences with the company, digital updates on our programs. Check out our rewards - there is sure to be one that fits who you are.

What Our Community Says:
Aerial Students:
  • I keep coming back to trapeze for the endless possibilities.
  • You never stop learning or being surprised by your body's capabilities.
  • Trapeze brings me to an authentic, genuine place that allows me to share in a safe,giving space.
Scholarship Students:
  • Taking trapeze class has allowed me to see my dancing, artistry, and life in ways I couldn't before.
Audience Members:
  • WOW were we impressed. We've been talking about it ever since.
  • Can't wait to see more. Keep up the incredible work!
  • The only thing I can describe, about the feeling I had about the performance was that it was similar to the first time I heard new music.  Like the first time I heard Jazz or classical or Blues. Completely enthralling and me wanting more.

Help us reach our goal in other ways:

  • Include our Indeigogo URL in your personal email signature line for the duration of our campaign which ends on July 18
  • Send 3 emails out today that include our campaign to people you know that share our values.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
“We rose above everyone and everything, and for a moment the sky was full of brilliant light. And then one after another we fell. And when I look up now I see no stars. I see no light. I see a sky full of darkness. But I do not look into that blackness. I look at what once was. And what forever more will be remembered.”
-Rose Kennedy in ROSE

The women of Nora’s Playhouse need your help in producing our inaugural Off-Broadway venture ROSE, a groundbreaking new play about the Kennedy matriarch starring award-winning actress Kathleen Chalfant.

Rose Kennedy is an American icon. And a bit of a mystery. We are familiar with the facts and the mythology, but the inner life of the matriarch of one of the country’s most revered and reviled political dynasties -- how she coped with loss and grief while maintaining her public equanimity – has seemed a riddle.

Laurence Leamer’s (The Kennedy Women, The Kennedy Men, Sons of Camelot) intimate, one-character play about Rose Kennedy is set in the living room of the family’s Hyannis Port compound the week after Teddy’s fateful error on a bridge in Chappaquiddick. As Rose struggles to understand why the Kennedys suffered so much tragedy, we grapple with their star-crossed lives and come to a new understanding. Rose tells us the story in her own words, and we listen, laugh, and cry at her amazing life, faith, and courage.

“What so excites the Nora’s Playhouse team is that ROSE presents a totally new vision of the Kennedy matriarch that will change forever the way people view not only Rose, but also the Kennedy family. Up until now Rose had been seen largely as a cypher, standing eternally at the back of the stage. That is not the Rose Kennedy of this play.”
- Caroline Reddick Lawson, Co-Founder/Artistic Director of Nora's Playhouse

Following our successful stage reading at New York Theatre Workshop in 2014, we knew we had to bring this compelling story to a wider audience. Taking ROSE to Off-Broadway is by far the most ambitious project we have attempted. With input from some of New York’s leading theatre professionals, we have assembled an extraordinary team. The incomparable Kathleen Chalfant (Wit, Angels in America, House of Cards, The Affair) will play Rose. Legendary costume designer Jane Greenwood (nominated for 19 Tony Awards for Costume Design including in 2015 for You Can't Take It With You, recipient of the 2014 Special Tony for Lifetime Achievement) will dress Rose. And we are excited to announce that some of the most promising young theatre designers in America are joining our design team: Anya Klepikov (Glass Menagerie, Triad Stage) will create the mise en scene, Caitlin Rapoport (Arcadia, Yale Rep) will be doing our lighting design, and Jane Shaw (Jackie, Women's Project/City Center Stage II) will design the sound. Nora’s Playhouse Co-Founder and Artistic Director Caroline Lawson (The Fallen, Jerry H. Labowitz Theatre) directs.

We hope you will join the team with your financial commitment. Please help us to advance the cause of women in the theatre and change the way history views one of the most important women of the 20th century. Join us on this extraordinary journey.


This November, at The Clurman Theatre in New York City, Nora's Playhouse will bring ROSE to the stage for a limited engagement. The first preview is on November 21, 2015 and the show opens on November 29, 2015 for a two-week run. We are working passionately to make this happen. As a not-for-profit theatre company, we will not be making one cent from this production.  All monies raised will go directly to ROSE. 

The typical budget for an Off-Broadway play can range from $150,000-$750,000. Thanks to the commitments from an extremely talented team who are all willing to work for less than their usual rates, we have been able to trim that down a bit.  But we still need to raise a total of $100,000 for this production.  We are halfway to our goal and need your help to get us the rest of the way there.

Where all that money will be going:

With your generous tax-deductible donation, you will not only be supporting an exciting new piece of theatre and our mission of showcasing the talents of women theatre artists, you will also qualify for some exciting perks like signed hardcover editions of Laurence Leamer's Kennedy trilogy; lunch with star of stage and screen, Kathleen Chalfant; or even an invitation to the big closing night cast party.

No donation payments are processed until the end of the campaign.

Please help us spread the word about this campaign (before the campaign deadline!) and make some noise about the production – we need as much support as possible and we can’t wait to share the play with our audiences!

Once you donate, please use the Indiegogo “share” tools and share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and any other social media you use.  Make sure you tag us (@norasplayhouse) and use the hashtag #Rose2015!

If you would like to make a non-monetary contribution, please email us at support@norasplayhouse.org.

And last, but not least, come to see the show!  Tickets will go on sale on Telecharge at the end of August!

Named for the heroine of Ibsen’s A Doll's House, Nora’s Playhouse is a theatre company devoted to providing an environment for women’s stories to be told in collaboration with women theatre artists. Our women-centered mission results from a recognition that women are still woefully underrepresented as directors, playwrights, artistic directors, and managers for professional theatre, as well as the primary subject matter for scripts. Since 2009, Nora’s has presented stage readings and full productions of more than a dozen new plays by women playwrights.

Some kind words from our 2015 playwrights:

"Working with the team of women at Nora’s Playhouse has been one of the most inspiring creative experiences of my professional life. They are serious, dedicated, insightful and honest. I owe them a great deal.”
-playwright, Laurence Leamer

"I wanted to thank you all again for the opportunity you gave me this weekend to strengthen 'Wash, Dry, Fold'. Your patience, insights, and professionalism helped me to see several ways I could clarify thematic points and tighten tension in places.... There is SO much value in the experience you provided, and I need you to know I'm grateful."
- playwright, Nedra Pezold Roberts

"I just want to say thank you to all of you for your generous gift of time and support for 'Francoise'. Your care and attention to the details of the play made the evening a very special one for me. It was a great pleasure to meet and work with you all."
- playwright, Suzanne Trauth

Nora’s Playhouse is sponsored by The Field, a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community. Contributions made to The Field and earmarked for Nora’s Playhouse are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906, New York, NY 10038, 212-691-6969, fax: 212-255-2053, www.thefield.org. A copy of The Field’s latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Thanks to everyone who gave to our first campaign! With the funds from Phase I we were able to secure our production team! But we still need your help to cover production costs, including: actor's salary, rehearsal space, promotional materials, stage management, crew, costumes, set, props, and other design elements. You can see our prior campaign @ The Widow of Tom's Hill (original campaign)

Our Story

In the winter of 2014 the Artistic Director of Luna Stage (a reputable professional theater in New Jersey) asked Rachel Black Spaulding if she would like to direct a workshop of The Widow of Tom’s Hill  by Aleks Merilo. This was a play Rachel - in her capacity as Literary Associate of Luna Stage - had read and admired earlier that season. Rachel reread the play and answered with a resounding yes!

What followed was months of discussion between Merilo and Spaulding, further work on the script, and then in June, three weeks of rehearsals with the actors and even more re-writes led to three sold out performances and a lot of positive buzz. This workshop/production had been produced by David Spaulding (in association with ScriptsUp, a non for profit new play development company) and presented by Luna Stage in Luna’s Lab Theater. David Spaulding then submitted it to 59E59 Theaters, a prestigious Off Broadway theater, and it was accepted into their 2015 season!

Just this spring, the Beverly Hills Theatre Guild declared The Widow of Tom’s Hill a second place winner of the prestigious Julie Harris Playwright Award. Established in 1977 by Neil Simon, the Julie Harris Awards are the culmination of a national competition which over the last ten years has evaluated over 5,000 plays.

The Widow of Tom’s Hill  is an emotionally gritty and spellbinding tale about trust, misinformation, and survival during what was and what still remains the deadliest plague in human history, the 1918 Influenza Pandemic. When a small American town on the Washington coast becomes the subject of an armed quarantine, two liaisons on opposite sides of the blockade - a nineteen-year-old widow and a young sailor - engage in a surprising and dangerous match. Their lives and the town’s fate hang in the balance.

We are at an exciting moment of bringing this play to full life! The Widow of Tom’s Hill  has been given an impressive home for its fast approaching New York City premiere, the director and playwright have just completed script refinements based on discovery from the workshop performances, and pre-production planning is well underway for set design, costumes, and other design elements.

But we need your help!

Your contributions are TAX DEDUCTABLE. Please read on.

[Widow's Image above - Artwork by Mark Block]

The Impact of This Play

Dramatic impact:

Alex Merilo, a young, award winning and critically acclaimed playwright manages to do successfully what many contemporary playwrights cannot, and that is to continually twist and turn a suspenseful tale until it reaches an outcome audiences do not see coming.

Additionally, not only is the plot captivating, but the characters speak in beautifully written prose, so rare in contemporary playwriting.

From an acting standpoint, this two-hander is a tour de force for two young actors, as they are on stage the entire time, embroiled in a byzantine relationship, surrounded by extreme circumstances.

What a thrilling way for audiences to spend an evening, instead of slumped on one’s couch in front of the television screen!

Global Impact:

Although this play is not intended to be a history play by any means, it is significant to note that the workshop production of The Widow of Tom’s Hill  at Luna went up in June 2014, just one week before any major news arrived of last spring’s Ebola outbreak, and numerous weeks before the onset of abject hysteria, media frenzy, and clear mishandling by authorities. Aside from the questions the play raises about the capacity of human interplay as a whole, interestingly, the reactions to the illness explored in this fable and the misinformation of authorities thereof, not only embody a small microcosm of what happened in 1918, but also how the world handled - or rather mishandled - the more recent Ebola Outbreak.

As for the Influenza of 1918, it is lost history. We have forgotten its enormous impact and the scope of loss. Three to five percent of the world’s population died from the illness. It killed more people in twenty four weeks than AIDS killed in twenty four years, and more people in a year than the Black Death of the middle ages killed in a century.

The story told in The Widow of Tom’s Hill  moves us to ask: What impact do global disasters have on us as a people? But perhaps most pointedly, how does human nature, and the complexities and circumstances of our individual lives play a part in how we react?

What We Need & What You Get

Ticket sales will only cover part of the costs.  We need $9,500 to complete our production budget. 

Join us in the final stages of this play’s development and be a part of theatre in the making! Please give a TAX-DEDUCTABLE gift that feeds the spirit, stirs the heart, and informs the mind.

Please help bring The Widow of Tom’s Hill  to life at the prestigious Off Broadway 59E59 Theatres! In so doing, not only will you help a play to its feet in New York, but it will also create opportunity for it to become a viable piece for regional theaters across the country – perhaps a theater near you!

What do you get? Besides a huge thank you from the bottom of our hearts, check out the Select a Perk Column to your right to learn what you will receive for your generosity!

We thank you for your interest, and we’re so grateful for any contribution! 

But, even if you can’t give now please come and see the show. 

Make some noise about The Widow of Tom’s Hill!
story_txt:
Thanks to everyone who gave to our first campaign! With the funds from Phase I we were able to secure our production team! But we still need your help to cover production costs, including: actor's salary, rehearsal space, promotional materials, stage management, crew, costumes, set, props, and other design elements. You can see our prior campaign @ The Widow of Tom's Hill (original campaign)


Our Story
In the winter of 2014 the Artistic
Director of Luna Stage (a reputable professional theater in New Jersey) asked
Rachel Black Spaulding if she would like to direct a workshop of The
Widow of Tom’s Hill  by Aleks Merilo. This was a play Rachel - in her
capacity as Literary Associate of Luna Stage - had read and admired
earlier that season. Rachel reread the play and answered with a resounding yes!
What followed was months of
discussion between Merilo and Spaulding, further work on the script, and
then in June, three weeks of rehearsals with the actors and even more re-writes
led to three sold out performances and a lot of positive buzz. This workshop/production
had been produced by David Spaulding (in association with ScriptsUp, a non for
profit new play development company) and presented by Luna Stage in Luna’s Lab
Theater. David Spaulding then submitted it to 59E59 Theaters, a prestigious Off
Broadway theater, and it was accepted into their 2015 season!


Just this spring, the Beverly Hills
Theatre Guild declared The Widow of
Tom’s Hill a second place winner of the prestigious Julie Harris Playwright Award. Established in 1977 by Neil Simon, the Julie
Harris Awards are the culmination of a national
competition which over the last ten years has evaluated over 5,000 plays.
The Widow of Tom’s Hill  is an emotionally gritty
and spellbinding tale about trust, misinformation, and survival during what was
and what still remains the deadliest plague in human history, the 1918 Influenza
Pandemic. When a small American town on the Washington coast becomes the subject
of an armed quarantine, two liaisons on opposite sides of the blockade - a nineteen-year-old widow and a young sailor - engage in a surprising and dangerous match. Their lives
and the town’s fate hang in the balance.
We are at
an exciting moment of bringing this play to full life! The Widow of Tom’s Hill
  has been given an impressive home for its fast approaching New York City premiere,
the director and playwright have just completed script refinements based on
discovery from the workshop performances, and pre-production planning is well underway
for set design, costumes, and other design elements.
But we
need your help!
Your
contributions are TAX DEDUCTABLE.

surrounded by extreme circumstances.

informs the mind.

story:
Short Summary

Hello everyone, thanks for checking out this funding page. My name is Ryan Lisman and I am the producer of This Is Our Youth, I'll also be acting in the role of Warren for the production. This Is Our Youth by Kenneth Lonergan is my favorite play of all time and I am excited to get the opportunity to produce this phenomenal play. I very much enjoy producing plays and getting to create a piece of Theatre from start to finish, the hard part is being able to fund everything so you can create the best production possible, and that is where you can come in to help out. All donations will go right towards funding the production, whether it be renting the space, purchasing props, payment of Cast and Crew, all of these are aspects of the production that would benefit from your donation. Performances are taking place at the ACME Comedy NoHo Theatre ( 5124 Lankershim Blvd, North Hollywood, CA 91601) from October 4th-24th. Ultimately, what I really hope for is that you are able to see and enjoy this play.

Here are the 8 performance dates:

October 4th, 7:30
October 9th, 7:30
October 11th, 2:30
October 16th, 7:30
October 17th, 7:30
October 18th, 2:30
October 23rd, 7:30
October 24th, 7:30



What We Need & What You Get

I have set the goal at $2000, this would cover of most of the funding for the entire production and would be a massive help. Even if the goal is not met, every dollar counts and is very helpful in helping to fund all aspects of this production. If you aren't able to donate a lot, don't worry about it, all support is greatly appreciated. We also have some perks available if you decide to help fund this production:


For $10, you'll get a shout-out on our Facebook page and a picture with all three cast members after the show if you are able to attend one of the performances.

For $25, in addition to the above perks you get for donating $10, you'll get a free ticket to any performance of your choosing, with tickets being $12-15, look at it in the sense that you are donating some money while getting a ticket to the show in advance.

For $50, in addition to all of the above perks for $10 and $25, you will also get your very own video thank you message made by the cast in character and in costume.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if you aren't able to donate, the best way to help out is by going to see the play, that's ultimately we are doing the show in the first place, to bring the story to life in front of the audience. You can also help out by spreading the word to your friends and family, word of mouth can often be the best form of advertisement. Here is the link to our Facebook Page where you can the production along throughout the entire process. Thank you so much for your support, it truly means the world to me.
https://www.facebook.com/ThisIsOurYouthNHFF15?f...

story:
Who We Are, What We Do, and Where We Wanna Do it.

The brainchild of local entrepreneur and restaurateur Howard "Howie" Nielsen, Photo City Improv is happy to announce its plan to become part of Rochester’s thriving live comedy scene. In order to bring comedic performers of all stripes to the same stage, Photo City Improv will be producing multiple original shows 5 nights a week (or more) featuring local and national professional comedic acts from the worlds of Stand-Up, Improv, Sketch, Music, and Variety. What’s more, we will offer world class food and drink specials at every performance. Throw in classes and workshops taught by some of the area’s most respected instructors, as well as entertainment industry veterans and you've got the makings for an explosion of live comedic presentations. 

  • The Photo City Players are some of the area's best and brightest comedic minds. This city needs a good laugh... 23 of us together have been rehearsing, writing, developing original comedy for months. Our intent is to generate material Rochesterians can relate and understand in the most personal of ways. 
  • Photo City Improv is Rochester's first venue dedicated to bringing all types of comedy together on one stage. Live Improv, Stand-up, Sketch, and Music,will be featured at each comedy-variety show.
The Snags We Encountered
Just as we were turning the corner to finalize the construction design and begin last stage of organizing we discovered that the plan for our kitchen would not be approved by officials. Part of an intricate plan that will help us maintain a successful business is offering our audience great food! Well this meant building a NEW KITCHEN in an area of our building that was not set up to do so. While the cost of this undertaking is steep and the amount we have set our goal at will not cover it completely it will certainly make it possible for us to do the hardest of the work as well as put some attention back on the areas that took a backseat to the kitchen.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • The funding we are asking is to defer only a portion of the cost of building this kitchen.  Additionally a few of the fine folks working to make this dream come alive have been doing so without pay so that we can stay on track and throwing them some well-deserved compensation would be a blessing. They did not get into this expecting it but with your help we can turn their sweat equity into cash.
  • While reaching our entire goal would be amazing, any portion will be used carefully to help us get back on track to be ready for our midsummer opening. 

The Perks

We put our heads together to come up with some great ways for you to GET IN ON THE ACTION, literally. Our perks offer everything you need for VIP experience which, for those of you brave enough, includes the opportunity to get on stage and strut your stuff with the pros. Who knows? This might be your big break. All Perks can begin to be cashed-in after Sept 1, 2015.

The BIG Picture

Photo City is the cornerstone of a much bigger project to bring a full-fledged entertainment district to a largely untapped area of the city. PHOTO CITY JUNCTION will ultimately feature a cavalcade of fun entertainment/restaurant hybrid establishments. Each unique from their menu to their presentations.
  • When complete Photo City Junction will help create 200-300 full and part time competitive paying jobs for restaurant industry workers and entertainers of all stripes in the City of Rochester.

Risks & Challenges

From finding an audience to keep production value and quality high all while maintaining a thriving specialty restaurant is the only part of Photo City Improv that is no joke.

FORTUNATELY each and everyone on the team from the Owner, the Artistic Director, the Chefs, and the Troupe are sincerely some of the finest in the area. With industry accolades that include Major Local Restaurateur Awards* and performance and directing credits in local and national TV, Radio, and Broadway, the PHOTO CITY IMPROV family is well-equipped to keep audiences coming back for more.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey we understand some folks just can't contribute monetarily, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • By spreading the word about who we are and and what we plan, you can make the difference in this campaign being a moderate success OR AN ABSOLUTE KNOCK OUT!
  • Please don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
The English Theatre Corfu is a non-profit, charitable association registered in Corfu, Greece. We automatically give 10% of every ticket we sell to local charities here in Corfu. From time to time – funds permitting – we also make special one-off donations to specific charities on the island and beyond.

We provide quality drama, educational opportunities and entertainment in both English and Greek.

Our productions so far have been theatrical stage productions but we our future plans include live streaming events & shows in association with Studio Kerkyra. Our aim is to broadcast our shows and events to the world.

So, What Do We Need

We have been given our very own venue free of charge at the unused school in the village of Pentati but it needs some repairs and building work. This venue will offer an indoor and outdoor stage both of which will be set up to live stream performances to the internet and record for future DVD and download sales.

We need to repair the toilet facilities, the floor and make general renovations plus finish building our indoor & outdoor stages.

  • Funds to repair the toilet facilities €1200
  • Funds for the floor and general renovations €2000
  • Funds to complete our stages including lights and sound equipment €8000

Whilst our goals are high this campaign target has been set at €1200 since with just the toilets being fixed we are able to start a schedule of entertainment.

What You Get

Choose a perk from our souvenirs or simply make a donation. Please bear in mind that the merchandise perks will mean a smaller donation towards getting the toilets fixed whilst membership will be a 100% donation.
  • 1 year ETC membership for 2 adults, members receive ticket concessions of 20%, membership to start 1st January 2016 €15
  • 1 year ETC family membership (2 adults & 2 children), members receive ticket concessions of 20%, membership to start 1st January 2016 €25
  • ETC T-Shirt - 100% pre-shrunk cotton with a classic loose-fit from €40
  • ETC Mug €30
  • Mouse mat €35

The Impact

Leading the way with technology the English theatre Corfu will be the first professional live stream and recording venue in Greece.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if your are unable to contribute, it doesn't mean that you can't help:

  • Please spread the word and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this page to Facebook and Twitter.

story:
Short Summary

  • For the past seven years, Miami Mayhem has been showcasing eight of our nation's premiere collegiate Garba-Raas teams in a fierce dance competition that provides an unparalleled South Asian cultural experience in the beautiful city of Miami!
  • This year, Miami Mayhem is back for the 8th time on February 28, 2015 at Julius Littman Theatre in North Miami Beach.

  • Every year we donate our proceeds to the incredible, Sunil's Home Orphanage in India. Through our passion for art and dance, we hope to raise awareness while helping children out of poverty and provide support to them as they reach their full potential. 
  • Every child should deserve a chance to dance. We hope to make that happen some day.

What We Need & What You Get

  • A portion of the funds raised are used to set up the competition every year. Catering to an event that will host over 1200 people, it is easy to tell that setting up Miami Mayhem each year does require funding. Every dollar raised is used to make Mayhem, Florida's premiere competition. Our event speaks for itself has it has received countless awards including Best Overall Event in the Raas community. 
  • What makes us unique, is that we try to give each team that comes to Mayhem a personalized experience as they compete and showcase their talents that they've been working on for the year as they try to win a bid to the nationals. We realise the rapport we share with not only the teams that come to Mayhem but our audience as well is continuing to rise because of the continued number of people that have been coming to Mayhem for the last 7 years.
  • We sell tickets to our event and our afterparty and the proceeds from those sales plus a portion of the donations go entirely to Sunil's Home Orphange in the state of Gujarat in western India. They provide a home and a place of shelter for these kids. 

The Impact

Why donate to Miami Mayhem? Our success over the last six years speaks for itself. We have become a fixture in the community, and our name and reputation have grown rapidly. With that growth, Miami Mayhem is a remarkable business and marketing opportunity to invest in. Our success has been greeted with both local and nationwide attention. Just three years ago, our Executive Chairs interviewed on ‘TV Asia’ to highlight our competition. Two years ago, several prominent magazines and newspapers, including Desh Videsh and Khaas Bhat, advertised Miami Mayhem. On top of these attributes, last year the event was featured on TV Asia, giving all of our sponsors recognition on National Television. We would like to offer you an opportunity to become a partner of Miami Mayhem as it continues to gain influence within South Florida and help support a global charity in Sunil’s Home. With the innovative ideas we have in store for this year, we need your help in bringing them to fruition. Thus, this is one opportunity we sincerely hope you consider.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We accept any form of donation, whether it's in cash or food or water. Any supply that could help us cut costs for running the event itself means more funds we can give to Sunil's Home. 
  • Moreover, just by attending our event you would be supporting us and Sunil's Home! 
  • Share our story and follow our progress on social media!

We sell tickets to our event and our afterparty and the proceeds from those sales plus a portion of the donations go entirely to Sunil's Home Orphange in the state of Gujarat in western India. They provide a home and a place of shelter for these kids. 
   The Impact
Why donate to Miami	Mayhem? Our	success	over	the	last	six	years	speaks	for	itself.	We	have	become	a	fixture	in	the	community,	and	our	name	and	reputation	have	grown	rapidly.	With	that	growth,	Miami	Mayhem	is	a	remarkable	business	and	marketing	opportunity	to	invest	in.	Our	success	has	been	greeted	with	both	local	and	nationwide	attention.	Just	three	years	ago,	our	Executive	Chairs	interviewed	on	‘TV	Asia’	to	highlight	our	competition.	Two	years	ago,	several	prominent	magazines	and	newspapers,	including	Desh	Videsh	and	Khaas Bhat,	advertised	Miami	Mayhem.	On	top	of	these	attributes,	last	year	the	event	was	featured	on	TV	Asia,	giving	all	of	our	sponsors	recognition	on	National	Television.	We	would	like	to	offer	you	an	opportunity	to	become	a	partner	of	Miami	Mayhem	as	it	continues	to	gain	influence	within	South	Florida	and	help	support	a	global	charity	in	Sunil’s	Home.	With	the	innovative	ideas	we	have	in	store	for	this	year,	we	need	your	help	in	bringing	them	to	fruition.	Thus,	this	is	one	opportunity	we	sincerely	hope	you	consider.

    Other Ways You Can Help 

We accept any form of donation, whether it's in cash or food or water. Any supply that could help us cut costs for running the event itself means more funds we can give to Sunil's Home. 
Moreover, just by attending our event you would be supporting us and Sunil's Home! 
Share our story and follow our progress on social media!

story:
What are we trying to do here? 

We're a group of actors, directors, teaching artists, and theatermakers who first met and worked together in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania at the University of the Arts. Since then, our adventures have taken us across the United States and overseas—to London, Australia, and Prague. The theatre we made and saw in these places has nurtured our collective passion for cultural exchange and engaging communities in the theatrical process. We now have an opportunity to do more of that exchanging and engaging—in Prague! We're going to produce THIS GIRL LAUGHS, THIS GIRL CRIES, THIS GIRL DOES NOTHING in the 2015 Prague Fringe Festival. We've got the venue secured and the playwright's blessing. Now, we just need to get the rest of our team to Prague. That's where you come in.


About the play: 

THIS GIRL LAUGHS, THIS GIRL CRIES, THIS GIRL DOES NOTHING is a wildly imaginative and profoundly humble play by Australian playwright Finegan Kruckemeyer. It is the recipient of the prestigious Rodney Seaborn Playwrights Award and was first produced in Buenos Aires, Argentina. It has since been performed hundreds of times and in four different languages.

THIS GIRL LAUGHS, THIS GIRL CRIES, THIS GIRL DOES NOTHING is a contemporary fairy tale about three sisters who are abandoned in the forest by their father and forced to find their own way in the world. One goes left, one goes right, and one stays right where she started.

"This wood is a doorway to everything that's outside our house and our village and our childhood and our experiences. There may be bears out there... The only thing we can not do is go back. And that's okay—life is not for going back." 

Kruckemeyer's play—about survival, finding yourself, and growing up—elegantly weaves together the fantastical and the everyday to narrate the separation of three sisters and the lifetime’s worth of stories they collect along their journeys home. 

About our team:

Our team is led by director BILL BUDDENDORF. Bill is a master of the Viewpoints technique, a highly imaginative, physically-focused method of creating character and story. This will be instrumental in mounting a production that transcends the barriers of language. Our production, though performed in English, will feature Czech supertitles. In addition to directing the play, Bill will introduce Viewpoints in a series of educational workshops with students at Prague Youth Theater. 

The cast includes BRANDI BURGESS, TAYLOR BOLES, LAURA EPPERSON, BRAD OGDEN, and SHANNON REMLEY. DANYA BARYSHNIKOV and RAQUEL GOLDSTEIN, two students of acting at Prague Youth Theatre, round out our company of actors.

About Prague Fringe

The Prague Fringe, now in its fourteenth year, is a nine-day celebration of theatre, comedy, music, dance, and storytelling. The festival showcases the work of hundreds of artists from all over the globe in a variety of venues across the Malá Strana district of Prague, one of the world's most beautiful cities. This year's festivities will take place from May 22nd through the 30th.

What your donation helps us achieve:

We are passionate about sharing this play with the people of Prague. That said, this is a post-2008 economy, and we know that you work hard for your money. If you choose to support us, you can rest assured that your donation will be used solely to mount this professional production. No member of our team will be compensated, in full or in part, by these crowdsourced funds. Instead, here's where your money will go:

  1. We have projected a budget of approximately $4,000 to fly four American artists to Prague (economy class!), house them (floors! sleeping bags!), and feed them (we'll eat light!) for the duration of their stay.
  2. The design for our production is inspired by the idea of making due with what you have, so the scenic elements and props will be minimal and relatively inexpensive. That said, we've dedicated $1,000 of our budget to the scenic and wardrobe departments. Our costume designer, Melissa Carson, is inspired both by Czech architecture and the changing of seasons. 
  3. The remaining $1,000 of our budget will be devoted to playwright royalties, performance rights, Fringe expenses (venue, marketing, and participation fees), and rehearsal space.

Other ways you can help:

Spread the word! Word of mouth is truly our greatest tool in connecting with new supporters. Email this page to the arts supporters in your life. Email it to the people who DON'T support art. Share it on Facebook. Tweet about it. Tumble it. Pin it. Snap crackle pop it. We really appreciate it.

http://thisgirlpraguefringe.weebly.com

The design for our production is inspired by the idea of making due with what you have, so the scenic elements and props will be minimal and relatively inexpensive. That said, we've dedicated $1,000 of our budget to the scenic and wardrobe departments. Our costume designer, Melissa Carson, is inspired both by Czech architecture and the changing of seasons. 


The remaining $1,000 of our budget will be devoted to playwright royalties, performance rights, Fringe expenses (venue, marketing, and participation fees), and rehearsal space.





Other ways you can help:




 Spread the word! Word of mouth is truly our greatest tool in connecting with new supporters. Email this page to the arts supporters in your life. Email it to the people who DON'T support art. Share it on Facebook. Tweet about it. Tumble it. Pin it. Snap crackle pop it. We really appreciate it.
http://thisgirlpraguefringe.weebly.com

story:
Short Summary

Found in 1983 as a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation, Clearfield Arts Studio Theatre's (CAST) purpose is to foster the promotion of community interest in theatre, music, art, dance, photography, and theatrical productions for education, civic, and benevolent purposes. 


We need your enthusiasm to bring high quality arts opportunities to our rural area in Central Pennsylvania.  

Right now, CAST is in a perilous situation. It is coming up for tax sale and struggling to keep the doors open. Please help us maintain our non-profit status by making a generous donation to our rejuvenation.

A membership drive under a new energetic 21st Century Board will work towards revitalizing our Downtown Riverwalk Arts Center. 

(A new board  of directors is officially voted in September 1 at the 7pm Membership Meeting.)


What CAST Needs

$3,600 to pay taxes that are past due.
(A short extension was granted by Clearfield County Commissioners.)
$2,300 for our first of four installments on our newly negotiated tax debt (due September 30th). A $25,000 wavier was granted on August 19th.
$9,100+ due in accounts payable
$1,200+ to cover the New Board of Director's first month of bills:  mortgage, electric, water & sewer, and other basic house nut costs.
$1,500+ for emergency repairs of facilities: new flooring and roof between office and upstairs costume shop, electrical issues, water leaks, and more.
$500+ to help start new programming

(Cast is made up of five (5) separate structures with a 2nd floor addition of the dance studio and three (3) music studios)

A TOTAL of $18,000+ is what we NEED TO BEGIN a rejuvenation process.

What You Get

People ask what they GET for a donation... 


(Main Stage Shot with last set.)

  • Clearfield Community gets a thriving business along the new Riverfront; 
  • We get an Arts Center that will offer activities EVERY day for the youth up thru the aging members of Clearfield Community -- right in the center of our own town;
  • Original Founding Members, Gayle Gearhart, Shawn Inlow, and Mary Beth Geppert, get to serve with a new energetic 21st Century membership, and
  • Our own DOWNTOWN COMMUNITY ARTS CENTER gets  A NEW BOARD in a NEW TOMORROW!
We are able to offer listing donor names in our next season's program; however, future plans might include a plaque naming initial sponsors, invites to our Gala Event, reduced rates on programs, and maybe even a season ticket or two. After the Sept. 1st membership meeting, a new board will address sponsorships for our Clearfield Downtown Arts' Center. Be sure to tell us your email!

(CAST, Inc.'s Loft Black Box Theatre potential)


(CAST's Dance Studio)

We hope you help us become the shapers of our own destiny through your generous donations.

(CAST, Inc.'s main auditorium sits 192 audience members.)


(The Multipurpose room offers multi set up options.)


The Impact on Clearfield  

We have a responsibility to the wider community to: 

  1. present the highest quality entertainment that is both available and affordable in a venue that is welcoming, and
  2. give them the opportunity to be entertained, to escape, and perhaps dream. 
We are a community venue and one of our ambitions is to become an artistic hub and laboratory where local artists and professionals meet, exchange, develop their craft, and create.

  • We want to be a friendly welcoming venue that values diversity and balances professionalism with a volunteer ethos.
  • We aim to be perceived as a vibrant and healthy environment where individuals are respected and valued. 
  • We believe in being open and honest and transparent in all our interactions.
  • Above all we believe it is important that fun and humor underpins all that we do in order that we may maximize our ability to create and play. 

Risks & Challenges

BUSINESS PLAN

There are four key strands that underpin our longer term recovery:-

1.  effective negotiation and financial control

2.  increasing the number of presentations

3.  increasing audiences

4.  maintaining and in some cases lowering prices

(CAST Loft Lounge with a projector, screen, and kitchen facility - we need a stove though.)

THE ECONOMIC CONDITIONS

This recovery will take place in some of the worst economic conditions in living memory. There is evidence that the entertainment industry can survive in difficult times as we provide a means of escape. 

We must not be complacent, but remain realistic about the challenges that we face. We must be constantly vigilant and aware of what is happening in the economy that may jeopardize our ambitions. 

(CAST Loft Lounge view towards kitchen.)

Other Ways You Can Help Rejuvenate CAST

VOLUNTEERING

A volunteer ethos is at the core of everything we do. Volunteers support us in many ways with maintenance of the building, poster displaying, in the office, and much more.

Under the guidance of our Executive and Artistic Directors our programs will grow and develop providing many with the opportunity to work in a professional theatre environment and to develop skills and experience that they will be able to use in advancing their careers.

In other areas we will help people develop key life skills and give them an important opportunity to improve their work ethics and skills, even if their work is not ultimately in the arts. 


(CAST's Lobby)

(CAST Music Studio A and C's hallway.)

(CAST's Music Studio B)

(CAST Loft Black Box Theatre space)

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Nicola Kealy and I run Rhythm Room: A space for Inclusive Theatre. Rhythm Room was set up in 2009 by myself and Mischa O' Mahony to facilitate the growth and development of budding actors and actresses with an intellectual disability.

Rhythm Room runs weekly theatre workshops and we make inclusive theatre. Our most recent work was CAN I FIT INTO THIS? at Smock Alley Theatre, Dublin in 2013.

Love | Loss | Life is a new play by Rhythm Room which will take to the stage on the 5th and 6th of November in the Axis Theatre, Dublin. Weaving together original live music, digital media and theatre this is Rhythm Room's most ambitious project to date. The work is completely original and both the story and movement have been devised by the actors through Rhythm Room's process based approach.

LOVE LOSS LIFE is set to the rhythm of a heartbeat, it is a journey through life: death and disappointment, loss and fear, pain and sadness, hope and courage, love and endurance.

Our work is all about opening the door of the Arts to minority groups and encouraging people's development creatively, imaginatively and socially through the process of theatre. We have shown that we are capable of creating interesting work that speaks to a wide audience and that we are able to deliver it in a professional manner. We are constantly pushing ourselves out of our comfort zone and want to bring our work to a wider audience.

What We Need & What You Get

We are not funded by any arts organisation and the money we make from ticket sales will help to pay for the cost of the production. We need €2000 to help us complete our project comfortably, this money will help pay for printing costs, costumes and venue insurance.
In return for funding us you will get our sincere gratitude and depending on what you fund you can receive a signed programme, a ticket to the play or a Rhythm Room workshop for a group of your choice.

The Impact

Rhythm Room's approach is organic and inclusive. The idea for Love Loss Life began three years ago in our Thursday afternoon group. The Actors wanted to express their thoughts around the themes and from that point we began to develop the idea for the play.

In supporting our work you are enabling the wonderful performers at Rhythm Room to share their creation with a wider audience. In making a donation you are saying Yes! to Inclusive Theatre and providing an opportunity for Rhythm Room's growth and development.

Our work is all about opening the door of the Arts to minority groups and encouraging people's development creatively, imaginatively and socially through the process of theatre. We have shown that we are capable of creating interesting work that speaks to a wide audience and that we are able to deliver it in a professional manner. We are constantly pushing ourselves out of our comfort zone and want to bring our work to a wider audience.

Risks & Challenges

There are always risks and challenges in getting a play from the page to the stage. Our biggest hurdle is time and money but we have always succeeded in the past. The group are dedicated and passionate about their work and completely focused on getting on that stage on the 5th of November.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially we would really appreciate it if you could spread the word about the campaign and the play and help us get bums on seats!

story:
Who is Atlantic Stage?

Atlantic Stage is an ensemble of professional resident artists committed to artistic excellence, community enrichment, and educational outreach.

The purpose of Atlantic Stage is to enhance the cultural landscape of the Myrtle Beach area by providing quality theatrical experiences of Classical, contemporary, and new works that are entertaining and thought-provoking. Our productions are meant to bring our community and patrons pleasure while sparking their curious and critical minds. 

Atlantic Stage has been producing an average of five (5) shows a season since 2008.  We plan to continue providing professional theatre to the Grand Strand community in a new black box style theatre.  

Atlantic Stage is passionate about the stories we share and we strongly believe in the communal power of theatre. We have the ability to build a culturally rich theatrical legacy here in the Grand Strand and we invite you to be a part of it! 

____________________________________________________________

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for $150,000 to build our dream theatre.  Approximately $100,000 will go toward construction costs and the remainder will cover audience seating, equipment, and operating expenses.

We want what we call a black box theatre, a space that is highly flexible depending on the theatrical needs of each piece.  Building this new black box space at the Myrtle Beach Mall gives us maximum artistic flexibility in selecting the shows we will produce for years to come. Audiences will have the ability to experience shows from different perspectives and viewpoints within every season and our artists will have even more freedom to produce the stories that matter to us all.

In our design we have a welcoming lobby space, a 99 seat black box performance space, a mezzanine level for our tech operators, and a lighting grid.  The space we have obtained has been completely gutted and we are ready to build with extensive plans in hand.  Starting basically from scratch in a 6000 square foot empty room calls for a lot of work to be done.  
We have a full range of perks for everyone helping us with this project.  You'll see a range of different benefits we offer (such as Atlantic Stage swag!) as well as tickets you could obtain.  You can also donate to purchase one or more seats in the theatre or book the entire house for a special preview performance for your exclusive private guest list.  Swag can be redeemed after the conclusion of the campaign on March 5th.  It will be ordered based on demand (so we can be smart with the money you've so generously donated!) and shipped within 45 days.  Ticket perks are redeemable immediately and can be used for any of the remaining productions in Season 8.   
If we don't raise our entire goal we will do what we can with what we get.  We started without our own space seven years ago and always found somewhere to share the stories that are relevant with our audiences.  $150,000 builds our dream theatre, and you can be a part of making that dream a reality! 
________________________________________________
The Impact

Theatre tells stories about the resilience of our human spirit. Theatre gives us the right and privilege to conjure up what is possible, to illustrate what is hopeful, and to celebrate what is different. Live theatre has the power to transform the lives of artists and audiences alike. Your contribution will make these transformations possible.  Live theatre allows us to experience something together with a community of people.  The lasting impact of these shared experiences is exponentially greater than anything we could experience alone.  

Contributing to Atlantic Stage's transformation now will potentially affect thousands of lives in the years to come.  Atlantic Stage will always be in the Myrtle Beach area, should you choose to experience a show with us. However, even if you never have a chance to visit us, please know that our community will forever be positively affected by supporters like you.  

We've never built a theatre before, however, we have a respectable educational and artistic track record that reflects our commitment to artistry and community involvement. Since our founding in 2008, Atlantic Stage has:

 Produced 35 shows, including a children’s show, an entry into the annual Piccolo Spoleto Festival in Charleston, and two World Premieres (with a third opening in January, 2016!);

 Donated over $10,000 of opening night receipts to local charitable organizations such as the Blue Star Mothers of Coastal Carolina, Canine Angels, Grand Strand Optimists Club, Horry County Fire Fighters’ Relief Fund, Horry County Literacy Council, and North Strand Helping hand;

 Established memberships in the National New Play Network and the South Carolina Theatre Association’s Professional Division;

 Offered adult classes and workshops in acting, audition techniques and textual analysis, taught by visiting and resident professional artists, often in conjunction with currently running productions;

 Employed visiting professional artists from Atlanta, London, and New York to work with us as actors, directors, and stage managers;

 Provided over 75 creative and technical internship opportunities to local college students; 

 Provided 15 creative and technical apprenticeship opportunities to local middle school and high school students;

 Started the annual New Voices PlayFest – an opportunity for new and experienced playwrights to have their new work read by professional actors and to receive feedback about their work from audiences and from industry professionals.  Featured plays may also be considered to receive a World Premiere production in a future season;

 Developed a strong core of over 300 loyal season subscribers;

 Developed a large and growing audience of over 5500 unique patrons;

 Sold over 25,000 tickets to satisfied customers from all over the world;

 Remained entirely debt free!  (You can help us stay this way!) 

We plan to grow upon this work and know that our new theatre will become our biggest asset as we move forward. We need your generous financial backing to continue the mission of providing artistic excellence, community enrichment and educational outreach for years to come!

Thom Penn, Producing Artistic Director

www.atlanticstage.com

_________________________________________________________

Risks & Challenges

One of the greatest risks of moving to a new space is the potential loss of our loyal patrons.  In an effort to minimize this risk, we creatively converted another space in Myrtle Beach Mall, without making any structural changes, into a functioning theatre.  It's not ideal, but we felt it was important to continue producing quality work while we wait for the construction of our new theatre to be completed.  We plan to continue producing in this "transitional" space until we can officially make the move to our new black box.  Thus far, we have not only held onto our existing audience base, we have also managed to attract many new patrons. Over the past seven seasons, we have proven that if we can get them in the door once, they'll come back, again and again.

Another substantial risk is the failure to reach our fundraising goal.  We have created a second set of plans that will enable us to occupy and produce in the new space, minus a few of the bells and whistles included in "Plan A," until such time as the original plans can be completed. However, we can't let this fear of failure stop us! We're dedicated, we're ready and we're here to stay! Onward!   
__________________________________________________________

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that not everyone can make a monetary contribution, but there are other ways you can help.  If you believe in what we're doing and want to be a part of transforming lives in the Grand Strand community, then make some noise about us!

If you know people that love theatre and/or the Grand Strand, and who may be interested in contributing, please tell them about us.  It's as simple as using the Indiegogo share tools to use the power of social media. Also, LIKE us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/AtlanticStage, so you can keep up-to-date on our happenings. You can do it!

Still Small Theatre Troupe is a quirkily designed theatre ministry and charity serving the New England area.

Inspired by medieval charitable groups that used the proceeds of theatre to support Madrid's hospitals for 300 years, we're designed to be an arts group that gives rather than takes.

But we need a little help getting there.

Still Small is designed to be self-sustaining, with proceeds from our shows being shared between our own needs and the needs of charitable causes. Since 2013, we've done just that, supporting things like education for low caste children, empowerment for local low-income families, and help for persecuted Christians. We keep our costs low by working on a volunteer basis and maintaining a minimalist aesthetic that puts the focus on the people and the performance rather than the trappings of it.

This is where you come in!

In order to truly be self-sustaining, we need start-up capital in order to pay for things like gas to get to shows, small stipends to help our volunteers afford the time commitment, equipment like props, lights and costumes, and operating and marketing costs.

Cool things have been happening ... 

In addition to highlighting and supporting charitable causes through our work, we've noticed a number of other benefits – some expected, some less so! The combination of spiritual exercise with the close interpersonal work of theatre has resulted in a uniquely strong community among those who have worked with us, and participants frequently cite the experience as one of the most powerful ones of their spiritual lives. Our actors with disabilities, in particular, have also spoken movingly of the confidence, encouragement, and empowerment they have gained from being part of this work.

... please help cool things continue for a long time!

The troupe has also pioneered numerous new theatrical works since its inception, enriching the arts world and the opportunities for audiences and participants throughout Massachusetts. Audience members consistently comment on ways that God has used performances to touch, challenge, and inspire them. In 2013, our production of The Prophet Project was recognized with the Making a Difference in Christian Service Award from Gordon Conwell Theological Seminary for drawing together people from a variety of socioeconomic, ethnic, and denominational backgrounds to produce high quality, Christ-centered theatre. We look forward to what He's going to do next!

Anything you give will be a help in making this a sustainable charitable conspiracy -- even if it's just a moment you take to pass on the word to a friend! Even if you can't give financially, the gift of your prayers is so important and appreciated!

Visit us at www.stillsmalltheatre.com for updates and info!

story:
Short Summary

In 2015, through the power of music and the love of dance, Individual Unit was founded. The Edmonton based group is undoubtedly one of the forces pushing Hip Hop culture. 

During the day, you can catch the trio teaching for free in downtown Edmonton, working with the youth, cyphering, travelling across Canada to participate in competitions, recording videos and exchanging ideas on how to improve circumstances amongst the community. Individual Unit has developed incredibly since they first met in 2012 and the collective consists of members that dance, produce music, and visual arts. 

Change The Game (CTG) is a dance camp merged with a dance competition. We are planning to go to Calgary from the 17th till the 22nd to partake in Change The Game. This would be life/career altering as it would allow us to connect with worldwide talent. With these new connections, we would be able to bring dancers to share with Edmonton and show them what our beautiful city has to offer.

What We Need

Travel to Calgary: $250
Camp + Competition + Lodging: $2250
Includes
  • Unlimited Class Workshops
  • All Access to CTG Parties
  • Qualifier Dance Battles
  • Main Event CTG Finals
http://ctgproject.com/registration
The Impact

The reason we want to participate in this top tier event is because it will give us more knowledge and skills, that we are able to bring back to our city to spread among the community, and most importantly, to the youth, through our dance. Once we are able to better direct the youths and communities energies into art and culture, it will be an uplifting force, giving people an outlet for freedom of expression, and building the support to be able to accomplish their goals.

Other Ways You Can Help

For the people who are unable to afford contributions, we ask that you please help us by spreading the word of our endeavors.

story:
Hello! My name is Georgette Verdin and I am the Co-Artistic Director of Interrobang Theatre Project. I also have the honor of directing our first production of our Sixth Season entitled Katrina: Mother-in-Law of 'Em All. As a Louisiana native, this subject is near-and-dear to my heart. There is no place on earth like New Orleans, La. The traditions run deep--they're edible, drinkable, and danceable. 

Interrobang Theatre Project is a non-profit Chicago theatre company that was founded in 2010. We focus on producing visceral and timely works, rarely produced texts, and new American plays.  We're asking for your help to bring Katrina: Mother-in-Law of 'Em All  to Chicago audiences. Interrobang is committed to commemorating the unimaginable bravery and strength of hundreds of thousands of individuals who endured the wrath of Hurricane Katrina and suffered in its aftermath just ten short years ago. We fervently believe in the healing power of storytelling. 

KATRINA: MOTHER-IN-LAW OF ‘EM ALL  written by New Orleans native, Rob Florence, is set in the famous Mother-in-Law Lounge, located in New Orleans’ Tremé neighborhood. It follows six individuals as they recount their true, harrowing and yet somehow hopeful stories about surviving one of the worst disasters in U.S. history. Both hilarious and poignant – this piece reaches beyond New Orleans, beyond Hurricane Katrina, and taps into our primordial need as humans to survive even under the worst of conditions. 

Katrina is the first of three plays in Interrobang Theatre Project's sixth season entitled ‘Unnatural Disasters,’ in which we investigate how individuals and communities navigate their way through the chaos and absurdity of worlds turned upside-down. The power of Katrina lies in its up-close and personal accounts of ordinary people acting in heroic ways to save themselves and their neighbors. Rob's script bypasses the political debacles and media circus that was the storm coverage, and instead - through these stories - allows the audience an opportunity to experience the grit of folks trying to survive hour-by-hour. True, there was fear and outrage and heartache, but as deep as the flood waters, there was also hope that one of America's most unique cities would rise again.

YOUR HELP

As a company, we are committed to paying all of our performers and designers. In total, we'll pay out $6,100 in artistic stipends for this production. In fact, the majority of our production budgets go towards making sure our team isn't work for free. We've all done our fair share of free gigs and while it may be a positive experience and even make us feel warm and fuzzy, it doesn't help pay the rent. This is where you come in! By helping us to raise our $2,000 goal, you're actually covering a third of our artistic fees for this show! That's huge! For Interrobang, like for many theatre companies, making theatre viable is an ongoing struggle. We need your support, whether it be monetary or simply putting our campaign on blast to the whole of your network via email, twitter, Facebook, tumblr, etc. This couldn't be easier with Indiegogo's share tools! 

Help us tell a story that shouldn't be forgotten in a way that's completely unforgettable! Your support means everything!

story:
Aluminous is a fiscally sponsored project of Intersection for the Arts, a non-profit arts service organization that has been in existence since 1965. Contributions for the purposes of Aluminous must be made payable to Intersection for the Arts and are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Our Story

"I'm an optimist and I believe in the future, which is why I created Aluminous."
Michael French, founder & artist director of Aluminous

Aluminous is a multimedia, multiracial theatre company based in Oakland, California that creates immersive performances using theatre, film, music, visual installations, and anything else we can lay our hands on. This is our second year in Oakland and in that time we're mounted productions of "The Last Days of Judas Iscariot" by Stephen Adly Guirgus and "H20" by John Jury. We've also produced original compositions by Marko Grubic, "An Eerie Beauty," and "Nothing Comes From Nothing" by John Steven Morgan (we discovered John playing a raucous stride piano outside the MacArthur BART station), and we've  created a twenty minute visual installation for "Judas" called "Prayer." We've also provided FREE entrance to those 18 years old and under to our performances and $15 tickets for Oakland residents, which made them $10 cheaper than our general public ticket price!

The goal of Aluminous is simple, to create projects and performances that represent the times in which we live and set your soul on fire!  Yes, our time is often one of struggle and heartbreak, but we believe it's also a time of great beauty, great courage, great optimism, and great passion, and there's no better place to see these things at work than in Oakland, California.

Why We Need Your Help!

Aluminous has assembled an incredible team of passionate, committed artists and collaborators ready to give all they can so the artists of Oakland have a voice.

  1. Our budget for 2015/16 is approximately $24,000. We need to raise $8,000 from our Indiegogo campaign to help us fulfill our vision for the year. We will begin this vision with a re-imagining of Edward Albee's masterpiece"The Zoo Story", with a multiracial cast and a first time director at the helm. We will continue in the summer with our Site Specific Short Play Festival for East Bay playwrights, and conclude with a yet to be named second production that we hope will be a new play by an Oakland playwright. All monies contributed to our campaign will be split equally between these three projects; 50% to help pay the many artists and collaborators that are currently working for less than minimum wage, and the remaining 50% to ensure that each project has the highest production values possible (the remaining money for our yearly budget will be raised by fund raising events, individual donors, local sponsorship, and in-kind exchanges).
This is a campaign for a company rather than a single event that may be forgotten in two months. At Aluminous we want to re-frame the idea that to be an artist means you have to be penniless. Artists need work!! Artists need to be employed! When you contribute to our campaign you will be helping to employ, support, and nurture the next generation of American theatre makers, which in some cases will mean artists who have had only minimal contact with the tools and opportunities that Aluminous can provide, and in other cases it will help more mature artists develop and grow. Either way, it's vital that artists are given a chance to work and be seen, and don't forget that every dollar you contribute is tax deductible to the extent permitted by law!

            
Every little bit helps and we can't do this without you! Please contribute what you   
                                                                         can!  

Other Ways You Can Help!

Spread the word about this campaign to friends, family, on facebook, twitter, and to strangers with kind faces! If you know someone who cares about the arts in America let them know about us and this campaign (Indiegogo has some very useful share tools that you can use). Also, if you live in the Bay Area of California, come and see our performances and projects! There's no more powerful way to support an artist than to show up and see his or her work in person!

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Caroline Anderson and I am the creator of the Caroline Anderson Show! I moved to Los Angeles California in May of 2014 to pursue my career in television by bringing back good clean family comedy!

The Caroline Anderson Show combines situational comedy sketches, with improvisation, musical numbers and audience participation to bring laughter to people of all ages! We strive to make our show family friendly so that anyone can come and see the show and leave happy- there really aren't that many shows that do this now a days.

 This show is the best one yet, but we need help to make this show as successful as it can be! This is our 3rd show we've produced since January and we're only getting better as we go along!

What We Need & What You Get

So here's what we're needing our money for:

Theater Space- Surprisingly it's expensive out here to rent a theater. We not only need it for the 2 nights of the show, but we also need it for the week of the show for our tech rehearsals!

Props and Costumes- Sure- the acting is GREAT, but to take it to that next level we want to look the best we can! We need things like doorways (which we would build ourselves), moving walls, tables, chairs, hats, canes, microphones, etc! There are so many little things that add up to put on a great show!

Filming: As we are trying to step up our game and become more and more of a professional show we are also teaming up with two filming crews- the first crew is going to help us produce our video commercials which will be played in between sketches in the show! Our second crew we're working with is doing a multi-camera filming of the show where they will live cut the show making it feel like a real in studio production! These crews are awesome and very professional so we want to make sure we they are taken care of by providing them with food and giving them some money- luckily they are friends in the business so they want to help us out!

The Impact

 By donating to this show you are helping us get closer and closer to making this dream a reality. The more we pursue this dream, the more we get the support and fan base that we need to make this show a success!
Not only are the donations appreciated, but your prayers, well wishes, and willingness to share our show with others has made a huge impact and has given us the push we need to continue doing what we love!

Other Ways You Can Help

Donating is much appreciated and much needed, but we could also use prayers, well wishes and spreading the word! Please share this campaign with anyone who you think could help us in our journey!

If you're in town when we do the show- SHOW UP!! We put this show on because we want you there! Follow us on all of our social media and stay connected for any updates and stay in the loop!!
