story:
The Story of the Play


                          


When the world turned against Ronald Reagan’s foreign policy, one woman came to his defense: Jeane Kirkpatrick. The first woman to serve as America’s ambassador to the United Nations, Jeane fought to make Reagan’s case before the world community. Now, for the first time, the Reagan White House is the subject of a new play: HER EXCELLENCY—a dark comedy in two acts.

                                

    The World Turned on Reagan's Foreign Policy

The arms-for-hostages scandal cast a shadow over Ronald Reagan's foreign policy. Jeane Kirkpatrick was in conflict with Nora Astorga, Nicaragua's ambassador to the United Nations.

                                                    

                           Nora: Jeane's Nemesis

Jeane and Nora, mocked as “Amazonian Bitches” by delegates to the male-dominated U.N., clashed in a war of words as each tried to sway world public opinion. Their confrontations became legendary as they worked feverishly to prevail—each coming to respect the other before fate intervened.
 

                                                 

                             Nancy Opines . . .

Nancy had none of it, blaming Jeane for the World Court ruling against the U.S. and for the "arms-for-hostages" becoming the "Iran-Contra" scandal. She demanded that Jeane neutralize that "Nicaraguan Bitch," something Nancy felt would be easy to do, given that both Jeane and Nora were Sagittarians, and Sagittarians are good at slaying each other.


      Playwright Statement: The Power of Women

When Americans think of powerful Latin American women, they think of Frida Kahlo or Eva Peron. But there are scores of incredible women: Nora Astorga is one. A patriot who fought in the jungles as a guerrilla, she served her country as ambassador to the United Nations. That Jeane Kirkpatrick and Nora Astorga were the first women to represent their nations, the U.S. and Nicaragua, at a time when the nations were at conflict, created great drama--and gossip. The intervention of Nancy Reagan added to this volatile mix. This dark comedy is a tribute to pioneering women who used the United Nations as the stage to make their cases before the world community.


                   Kirkpatrick and Astorga Clash

And who the heck is Nora Astorga, you ask?

Fund our reading and find out! Powerful and brilliant, she took on Jeane and held her own! Their clashes—in the Ladies Room at the U.N., no less—were legendary.


                            Our Thanks to You!

Check out the fantastic PERKS that are our thanks to you for supporting this new play! Help us get the word out by using the Indiegogo share tools!


Great Stories Make Great Theater

Let’s bring on Jeane, Nora, Ronnie, and Nancy to the stage and let the sparks fly!

                           About the Playwright:

Educated at Cornell University, I'm an economist and writer. For two decades I worked in finance, primarily at private banks and other financial institutions. During this time I wrote more than 20 books. At Cornell I studied play writing under Paula Vogel. And recently, I've turned to writing plays. My interest is in writing pieces about strong, courageous women. HER EXCELLENCY is about Jeane Kirkpatrick and Nora Astorga, a political dark comedy. At present I'm developing a piece, which would be the first for either of these women, to explore the relationship between Frida Kahlo and Louise Nevelson, who were rivals and lovers.

                              About the Actress:

SHARON TALBOT, JEANE KIRKPATRICK, recently appeared in two films, “Contract Removals”, and “EVOL”.  Broadway: Don’t Drink the Water, Musical Jubilee; Off-Broadway: The Legend of Sharon Shashanovah, JB; “The Importance of Being Earnest”, The Housewives’ Cantata”.Regional:: Born Yesterday, A Streetcar Named Desire, The Elephant Man, Deathtrap, Talley’s Folly, Chapter Two, One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest, Promises, Promises, As You Like It, A Phoenix Too Frequent, The Merchant of Venice, Measure for Measure, and her own play, A Field of Glory, presented at the Kennedy, Raleigh NC, in the summer of 2010. University of Denver, Phi Beta Kappa.  Trained in New York and London.  Proud mom of Rob, 20. sharontalbot2@aol.com; http://bit.ly/DianaMariaGarcia; www.sharontalbot.com.  Performer/writer of the web series: “Diana Maria Garcia”.
story_txt:
The Story of the Play






                           

When the world turned against Ronald Reagan’s foreign policy, one woman came
to his defense: Jeane Kirkpatrick. The first woman to serve as America’s
ambassador to the United Nations, Jeane fought to make Reagan’s case
before the world community. Now, for the first time, the Reagan White House is the subject of a new play:
HER EXCELLENCY—a dark comedy in two acts. 



                                 


    The World Turned on Reagan's Foreign Policy
The arms-for-hostages scandal cast a shadow over Ronald Reagan's foreign
policy. Jeane Kirkpatrick was in
conflict with Nora Astorga, Nicaragua's ambassador to the United Nations. 

                                                     
                           Nora: Jeane's NemesisJeane and Nora, mocked as “Amazonian Bitches” by delegates to the
male-dominated U.N., clashed in a war of words as each tried to sway world
public opinion. Their confrontations became legendary as they worked feverishly
to prevail—each coming to respect the other before fate intervened. 
                                                  
                             Nancy Opines . . .
Nancy had none of it, blaming Jeane for the World Court ruling against the U.S. and for the "arms-for-hostages" becoming the "Iran-Contra" scandal. She demanded that Jeane neutralize that "Nicaraguan Bitch," something Nancy felt would be easy to do, given that both Jeane and Nora were Sagittarians, and Sagittarians are good at slaying each other.


      Playwright Statement: The Power of Women

When Americans think of powerful Latin American women, they think of Frida Kahlo or Eva Peron. But there are scores of incredible women: Nora Astorga is one. A patriot who fought in the jungles as a guerrilla, she served her country as ambassador to the United Nations. That Jeane Kirkpatrick and Nora Astorga were the first women to represent their nations, the U.S. and Nicaragua, at a time when the nations were at conflict, created great drama--and gossip. The intervention of Nancy Reagan added to this volatile mix. This dark comedy is a tribute to pioneering women who used the United Nations as the stage to make their cases before the world community.

 
                   Kirkpatrick and Astorga Clash

And who the heck is Nora Astorga, you ask? 
Fund our reading and find out! Powerful and brilliant, she took on Jeane and held her own! Their clashes—in the Ladies Room at the 
U.N., no less—were legendary.


                            Our Thanks to You! 

Check out the fantastic PERKS that are our thanks to you for supporting this new play! Help us get the word out by using the Indiegogo share tools!

Great Stories Make Great Theater
Let’s bring on Jeane, Nora, Ronnie, and Nancy to the stage and let the sparks fly!                           About the Playwright:Educated at Cornell University, I'm an economist and writer. For two 
decades I worked in finance, primarily at private banks and other 
financial institutions. During this time I wrote more than 20 books. At 
Cornell I studied play writing under Paula Vogel. And recently, I've 
turned to writing plays. My interest is in writing pieces about strong, 
courageous women. HER EXCELLENCY is about Jeane Kirkpatrick and Nora 
Astorga, a political dark comedy. At present I'm developing a piece, 
which would be the first for either of these women, to explore the 
relationship between Frida Kahlo and Louise Nevelson, who were rivals 
and lovers.                               About the Actress:SHARON TALBOT, JEANE KIRKPATRICK, recently appeared in two films, “Contract Removals”, and “EVOL”.  Broadway: Don’t Drink the Water, Musical Jubilee; Off-Broadway: The Legend of Sharon Shashanovah, JB; “The Importance of Being Earnest”, The Housewives’ Cantata”.Regional:: Born
 Yesterday, A Streetcar Named Desire, The Elephant Man, Deathtrap, 
Talley’s Folly, Chapter Two, One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest, Promises, 
Promises, As You Like It, A Phoenix Too Frequent, The Merchant of 
Venice, Measure for Measure, and her own play, A Field of Glory, presented at the Kennedy, Raleigh NC, in the summer of 2010. University of Denver, Phi Beta Kappa.  Trained in New York and London.  Proud mom of Rob, 20. sharontalbot2@aol.com; http://bit.ly/DianaMariaGarcia; www.sharontalbot.com.  Performer/writer of the web series: “Diana Maria Garcia”.

story:
Short Summary

NIGHT TERRORS is the 2015 haunt for Fear Beyond Haunts, LLC.  This year, we are moving out of the home haunt business and, along with the Fleet Reserve Association and Operation Homefronts, into our own location here in Pearl Harbor, HI!

Fear Beyond Haunts Presents NIGHT TERRORS

The mission of Anthony and Natali Pittore, the founders of Fear Beyond Haunts, is to not only scare the daylights out of their visitors, but to also help raise money and awareness for the organization Operation Homefront.   As an active duty sailor in the U.S. Navy, 

Operation Homefront is a charity that offers support for military members and their families in times of difficulty. They work ceaselessly to offer financial, food, and repairs assistance; and to help the families of our service members and Wounded Warriors.

What We Need & What You Get

NIGHT TERRORS will be our first year transitioning from home haunting to a real location!  We were surprised with a two-month timeline and no funding!  Therefore, my wife & I, here at Fear Beyond Haunts, are singlehandedly funding, designing, and building everything!

The Impact

Through our partnership with Operation Homefront, whom our profits are donated to, we will be assisting in the support of thousands of Wounded Warriors and their families.  As an active duty sailor in the U.S. Navy, the mission of Operation Homefront is very dear to me, and working with them is an honor. 

Risks & Challenges

As of now, time and money are our only constraints!  We are doing everything we can to build the best and scariest haunted attraction we can!  We've met dozens of devoted volunteers who also want to help out!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, don't worry!  We still need your help!  We are always looking for physical donations (props, supplies, etc.) and manpower!  Contact us at www.FearBeyondHaunts.com and we'd love to work with you!

Thanks so much for your time,

Anthony & Natali Pittore
Founders
Fear Beyond Haunts, LLC

story:
this is a Short Summary

I am a writer and an actress.

this is my first commissioned work.

in addition to the support we are receiving from our venue,

the incomparable dixon place,

we are raising funds to pay our fabulous artists (Jess Almasy, Matt Baguth, Kate Benson, Karen Boyer, John Del Gaudio, Ann Marie Dorr, Jill Frutkin, Fernando Gonzalez, Christopher Heilman, Hannah Heller, Hannah Kallenbach, David Neal Levin, Teri Madonna, Elianna Mullins, Christopher Nunez, Nazli Sarpkaya, Lawrence Schober, Hannah Spratt, Brendan Titley, and Dan Veksler)!

this is What We Need & What You Get

  • we need to raise at minimum $7,500 to pay ea designer, crew member, and performer a stipend for their two months of work. if we raise more, we can add more funds to our materials budget for KAREN BOYER'S wild garb + CHRISTOPHER HEILMAN'S glorious set
  • YOU CAN HAVE YOUR VERY OWN PERSONALIZED TIGER SPIRIT ANIMAL POSTED ON YOUR FB WALL IF YOU DONATE! FREE DRINKS! TICKETS TO THE SHO! PARTYING W THE BIG CATS!

this is The Impact

  • this is a play about women and grief and children
  • this is a play about police / citizen assault
  • this is a play about our capacities to be violent

these are some Risks & Challenges

we've got a very short rehearsal period w a large cast to develop this play within.

i've been making theatre for over 25 years and feel confident we will find this plays inherent rhythm it wants to operate on. its definitely decently terrifying. this is also my directing debut

our designers are going to have to be inventive fast and resourceful simultaneously as we create a set on wickedly tight purse strings that can collapse nightly over a month and stay intact

there are Other Ways You Can Help

if you are into supporting us you can make a donation here thru dixon place as our fiscal sponsor, and/or buy tickets to the sho!, and/or spread the word about this 'raiser and the play. indiegogo has share tools

follow us...

on Instagram https://instagram.com/tigertigerplay/

and Twitter https://twitter.com/tigertigerplay

and that's all there is to it

gracias

story:
We Love to Dance, Teach and Share

Welcome and thanks for viewing this page.

We are the 1984Posse. A breakdance group/community based in Groningen who have dedicated our life to teaching kids and helping the scene grow. We have been active for over 15 years already and right now.. we need YOUR help!

Throughout all these dancing years we have been teaching and training in various places. From small churches and studios to big gymnasiums and dancestudios. We always had a dream though.. our own dancing studio! In 2014 that dream became a reality!

We found our own space, invested all of our time and money in it to transform it to an proper dance studio and opened the place. We began with extra classes and teaching more and more kids the basics and fundamentals. And it payed off! 

 Welkom en bedankt voor het bekijken van deze pagina.

Wij zijn de 1984Posse, een breakdance groep/community uit Groningen. Wij investeren in de scene in Noord Nederland en helpen talentvolle jongeren met breakdance lessen. We doen dit inmiddels al meer dan 15 jaar.. en nu.. nu zijn we JOU hulp nodig!

We zijn jarenlang bezig geweest met lesgeven en trainen op verschillende plekken. Van kleine kerkjes en vergaderzaaltjes tot grote gymzalen en dansscholen. Al die tijd hadden we een droom.. onze eigen dansstudio! In 2014 werd deze droom werkelijkheid!

We vonden een eigen plekje en investeerden al onze tijd en geld om er een echte dansstudio van te maken. Na de opening begonnen we met extra lessen en meer ondersteuning voor de kids en students. En dat loonde!

With structurized teaching methods and endless enthousiasm we teached the kids the ways of the bboy (a breakdancer). After a couple of months the kids started winning battles and events and made a name for themselves. Meanwhile Tim won the national competition Young BBoy League:

 Dankzij de juiste methodes en een oneindige enthousiasme hebben we de kids het echte bboy (een breakdancer) leven bijgebracht. Na een paar maanden begonnen de kids battles en evenementen te winnen en naam te maken. Ondertussen won Tim de Young BBoy League, het NK voor onder de 18:

We were on a roll and proud of what we accomplished thus far. And better yet.. we got more energy and ideas to really help the kids and students to bring their dance skills to the next level. Unfortunatly.. disaster struck.

After a heavy rainstorm there was a water leak. Unfortunatly the water leak was located in an out of sight. When we discovered the leak, it was too late. The subfloor was soaked and filled with mold and the dancefloor was ruined. We had to remove it all, leaving our studio pretty much.. worthless.

 We waren lekker op dreef en trots op wat we bereikt hadden. En nog beter.. we hadden meer energie en ideeen om de kids hun skills naar een hoger niveau te tillen. Helaas sloeg het noodlot toe..

Na een zware storm kregen we te maken met een waterlek. Helaas was dit lek op een dusdanige plek dat ie uit het zicht was. Toen we het lek ontdekten was het al te laat. De ondervloer was doorweekt en zat vol schimmel en de dansvloer was verwoest. We hebben het allemaal moeten verwijderen waardoor de dansstudio.. onbruikbaar werd.

- The mold is everywhere.. -
- De schimmel zit overal.. -

- Not only does it look bad.. the smell is unbearable -
- Het ziet er niet alleen vies uit.. het stinks ook nog eens verschrikkelijk - 

- Talk about contrast.. such a beautiful wall, and such a dirty molded floor -
- Wat een contrast.. een supermooie muur en een smerige beschimmelde vloer - 

Currently we do not have the fundings to invest a lot of money again. All the money we had was spend on the initial build of the studio and was invested back into the community. If we do not reach the right amount of money, we basicly have to start again from scratch.

 Momenteel hebben we geen geld beschikbaar om opnieuw te investeren. Al het beschikbare geld hadden we een jaar eerder al geinvesteerd en het overige deel werd terug gestoken in de community. In principe kunnen we weer van voor af aan beginnen dus.

What We Need & What You Get

So yeah.. Currently we need money to clean the place and get rid of all the water damage and build a new floor.

  • 500 euro for cleaning
  • 500 euro for a subfloor
  • 1500 euro for a new dance floor
  • 500 euro for the remaining water damage
If we reach our goal, we will re-open the dance studio with a big party! At this party we will showcase what we have been working on with the kids and give a demo of the 1984posse skills. Everyone backing this project in one way or another is welcome at this party and will receive free drinks depending on the amount donated.
 Dus ja.. Momenteel hebben we geld nodig om de studio te reinigen, de waterschade te herstellen en een nieuwe vloer te leggen.

  • 500 euro voor de schoonmaak
  • 500 euro voor een ondervloer
  • 1500 voor een dansvloer
  • 500 euro voor de overige schade
Indien we dit bedrag bij elkaar krijgen, openen we de studio met een groot feest. Tijdens dit feest zullen er demos en showcases zijn van de kids en de 1984posse. Iedereen die ons support middels dit project is welkom en zal een x-aantal drankjes gratis krijgen (afhankelijk van de donatie).

The Impact

If you choose to invest/donate money to this project, you will help not only us, but every kid in the future that wants to dance. We help kids achieve their goals and turn them into breakdancing superstars. We currently have a teaching method that really works and all the kids are super excited. Furthermore you will help us with the growing of a community. We are always planning workshops, special classes and events and need a studio to do so and fall back on. 

 Indien je kiest om dit project te steunen, help je niet alleen ons en onze dansstudio, je helpt ook elk kind dat in de toekomst graag wil dansen. Wij helpen kids om hun doelen te bereiken en veranderen ze in breakdancende supersterren. Onze methodes zijn bewezen en de kids zijn superenthousiast. Daarnaast help je de community. We zijn altijd bezig met workshops organizeren, extra lessen en evenementen en een studio om op terug te vallen is hierbij essentieel.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to help us out financially, you can help us out by spreading the word. Share our project on social media and get as much people involved. Every small amount of money is welcome offcourse, but exposure is also very valuable.

 Indien je niet in staat bent om ons financiel te helpen, kun je ons helpen door ons verhaal te delen via bijvoorbeeld social media. Hoe meer mensen we bereiken, hoe groter de kans van slagen.

story:
SofA Productions

We are SofA Productions, a group of actors and directors all with one simple aim - to create beautiful theatre and unforgettable experiences. We believe that no matter what the context of the show, the audience should leave the theatre feeling more inspired and happier than when they arrived. This is especially true when it comes to children's theatre!

Since 2000 we have been creating theatre for children filled with detailed beauty and joy. We care deeply about our work and our responsibilities as artists and fully embrace the fact that what we are doing is essentially creating memories for life - and therefor make sure these memories are never less than breathtaking!


Once Upon A Time...

Our Children's show Once Upon A Time is a collection of three fairy tales from around the world that we've brought to life in our unique and delightful way. 

We've been performing Once Upon A Time at fringe festivals and in London every year since 2000 and every year we pick a new batch of fairy tales to tackle. Over the years we've come to realise the endless possibilities (not to mention massive challenges!) that adapting fairy tales to the stage come with, and we've become really good at what we do.

This year the show includes the story of the Mouse Family that go on an adventure to visit the sun, the tale of Fearless Hans who's not afraid of anything and the timeless Little Red Riding Hood in our version where Little Red doesn't need anything but her own wits to save her grandma from the Big Bad Wolf!

The children are welcomed by the creatures of the Wild Woods that guide them throughout the performance, and the show ends with everyone getting the opportunity to meet all the characters from the stories.

We design every step of the way from when the children enter the theatre to when they say goodbye to the characters so that we can create unforgettable experiences that leave the children with excitement and inspiration that stay with them for a long time.


Why we need your help

We are a non-profit organisation and do this simply because giving children enjoyable and meaningful memories for life is simply one of the most enjoyable and fulfilling things you can do.

We have been doing very successful runs at our home in London for many years but we want to expand and give more children the chance to experience Once Upon a Time. The Brighton Fringe comes with enormous possibilities for us to develop and grow as a company - and for a lot more children to experience our magic - but it does however come with many additional costs for us.

Our total budget is £7000 to be able to take our whole production team and our shows to Brighton. The £3500 that we are asking for through indiegogo will simply go towards the cost of our team of 33 actors and directors being able to travel to and stay in Brighton. We are currently in negotiations with sponsors for our remaining production costs.

With your help we can affect so many more children than would otherwise be possible and we're eternally grateful for any help you can give us in achieving this cause! What we are asking for is the absolute minimum for us to be able to take our show to Brighton. Any excess we receive will firstly go towards renting a larger van to transport an even more extensive magical forest to the fringe, and the rest will be used to create more details in our props and costumes, making our sho even more magical!




Happily ever after...

It should be clear by what you've read so far that we are very passionate about what we do.

Today, in the fast paced and technology filled world we live in, we sometimes forget about the simple joy of a great story, filled with captivating characters and an invitation to explore the world around you.

We believe that we have the experience and skill to simply design a beautiful and fascinating world on stage, filled with magical characters behaving as if real people - that the children are invited to experience as if they were a part of it. Our acting and directing is based on a thorough understand of why people live the way they do. This means that we can create theatre that is at the same time utterly magical as it is true to life - allowing both children and adults to enjoy and learn from seeing how other people (and animals!) live and think.

Our goal is for the children to leave the theatre with inspiration for life and the world around them. If you think this sounds like something worthy pursuing and are able to help us out in any way we can't thank you enough!

This is what our audience has to say about our show:

''Very sensitively done, a great introduction to live theatre for the little ones.'

'The special effects are fantastic!'

'Very unique experience.'

'My 3-year-old says: "I love the queen!"'



Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount you can donate, large or small, will help us a lot on our way to creating memories for life. You can also help us by:

  • Spreading our campaign as much as possible! (Use IndieGoGo's share tools!)
  • Get in touch with us with any helpful words on our way!
  • Visit our website www.sofaproductions.co.uk
  • Come to our show!!


Once again, from the bottom of our hearts: 

Thank You!

SofA Productions
story_txt:
SofA Productions

We are SofA Productions, a group of actors and directors all with one simple aim - to create beautiful theatre and unforgettable experiences. We believe that no matter what the context of the show, the audience should leave the theatre feeling more inspired and happier than when they arrived. This is especially true when it comes to children's theatre!



Since 2000 we have been creating theatre for children filled with detailed beauty and joy. We care deeply about our work and our responsibilities as artists and fully embrace the fact that what we are doing is essentially creating memories for life - and therefor make sure these memories are never less than breathtaking!




Once Upon A Time...

Our Children's show Once Upon A Time is a collection of three fairy tales from around the world that we've brought to life in our unique and delightful way. 



We've been performing Once Upon A Time at fringe festivals and in London every year since 2000 and every year we pick a new batch of fairy tales to tackle. Over the years we've come to realise the endless possibilities (not to mention massive challenges!) that adapting fairy tales to the stage come with, and we've become really good at what we do.



This year the show includes the story of the Mouse Family that go on an adventure to visit the sun, the tale of Fearless Hans who's not afraid of anything and the timeless Little Red Riding Hood in our version where Little Red doesn't need anything but her own wits to save her grandma from the Big Bad Wolf!



The children are welcomed by the creatures of the Wild Woods that guide them throughout the performance, and the show ends with everyone getting the opportunity to meet all the characters from the stories.



We design every step of the way from when the children enter the theatre to when they say goodbye to the characters so that we can create unforgettable experiences that leave the children with excitement and inspiration that stay with them for a long time.






 Why we need your help
We are a non-profit organisation and do this simply because giving children enjoyable and meaningful memories for life is simply one of the most enjoyable and fulfilling things you can do.
We have been doing very successful runs at our home in London for many years but we want to expand and give more children the chance to experience Once Upon a Time. The Brighton Fringe comes with enormous possibilities for us to develop and grow as a company - and for a lot more children to experience our magic - but it does however come with many additional costs for us.
Our total budget is £7000 to be able to take our whole production team and our shows to Brighton. This means that we can create theatre that is at the same time utterly magical as it is true to life - allowing both children and adults to enjoy and learn from seeing how other people (and animals!) live and think.
Our goal is for the children to leave the theatre with inspiration for life and the world around them. If you think this sounds like something worthy pursuing and are able to help us out in any way we can't thank you enough!

''Very sensitively done, a great introduction to live theatre for the little ones.'

'Very unique experience.'

story:
The Project

"Cabaret" is a word that some people hear and don't immediately understand: is it stand up comedy; is it musical theatre; is it jazz, is it a concert...WHAT is it? For me, the simple answer is: cabaret is the art of storytelling through songs. The long answer is: cabaret is a musical, comedic, interactive practice that encourages audiences to have their own emotional moments and connections articulated through music. It is intimate, interactive and fluid. It is funny, it is moving, and...depending upon audience and venue...it is an every changing performance.

Now, if that seems a bit mysterious to you, imagine the challenge of selling this fluid concept to theatres at home and abroad who aren't regular presenters of cabaret. Or, more specifically, of my version of cabaret.

This is a very exciting project because it's going to produce a snapshot of my work - my version of cabaret - that I can use to sell my shows to theatres and booking agents across Canada and around the world. Staging a live show in Toronto this summer, we (me and my pal, 4x Canadian Screen Award winner, Mike Bickerton) are going to record the performances and shoot interviews to create a behind-the-scenes mini-documentary series that gives an inside look into a Sharron Matthews cabaret.

WTF: What...the...funds (are going to)

Money makes the world go around...and also gets sh*t done in the production world. We need to spend some money to bring this idea to life, in some of the following ways:

  • Venue costs for the live performance
  • Camera equipment and operators - we're taking the production value up a notch from the old school camcorder
  • Audio equipment and operators - a girl's gotta sound good!
  • Editing labour costs - to put together a series of videos that will highlight the live show experience

I have been waiting for the last 5 years for a time when I would have the proper funds to support this project myself, a project that would be fully realized on every level. BUT EVERY buck I make goes right back into the business of touring cabaret, into administration and promotion, into new arrangements, buying new costumes, new websites, hiring production assistants to help me with all the many aspects of self-production. This is not a project that I want to skimp on...so, after a lot of soul searching, I decided to come to you.

Every dollar will go into creating a series of promotional videos that will bring the live experience of a Sharron Matthews show to people ALL AROUND THE WORLD. The reach of this series in the digital age means that my shows can be booked anywhere...you're truly investing in WORLD DOMINATION!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goals are ambitious but quality costs money. 

  • The funding goal is $12,000 CDN 
  • To entice you to part with your dollars, we've thought up some creative perks; click the Perks link to find out how this game of "show me the money" is going to go down

The Impact

For years I have been working with the same scratchy videos to demonstrate my work to new audiences, to presenters, to bookers and to festivals. These videos are wonderful snapshots of a moment in time BUT to reach bigger audiences, to be taken seriously in this High Def world, a polished video of my work will make ALL the difference.  Without being TOO dramatic, it is the difference between getting booked and NOT getting booked.

This video project will help give me better access to the best arts trades shows and festivals around the world.  I may be 47, but this LADY STILL HAS GRAND DREAMS! After having many chats with Mike about it, we both agreed that we wanted to make it more than a performance video. We want to stir people to not only be excited about my work but also about cabaret and cabaret in Canada. We want to capture not only live performance but document rehearsal and what happens behind the scenes. It is not just a performance video...it will be an interesting look into my work and into Cabaret in Canada. It will also hopefully encourage other artists young and old(er) to consider this practice as a means of telling THEIR stories.

I have funded and produced three world tours to London, New York, and Scotland, the first one years before the invention of crowdfunding engines like this. With Mike Bickerton, who has spent then last 15 years of his life producing live TV, our skill sets combined set us up for the BEST possible outcome. THE VERY BEST!!

THANK you for reading! Thank you for considering!

story:
The story behind what we're doing

One of the most fun shows I've ever been a part of as both an audience member and an actor is the Rocky Horror Show.  The idea that you can go to a show and enter into the action is an amazing concept, and some of the most fun you can have inside a theatre.
I have decided I want to bring Rocky Horror Show to the South Bay PERMANENTLY for two reasons. First, I think Rocky can add a great dimension to the struggling arts community in the Silicon Valley.  Performing arts has had a relatively rough set of years even though there has been an influx of people and capital moving into the South Bay.  This is a show that has been a staple of musical theatre since the early 70s (I won't debate with some purists), and it can add a lot of happiness and value to the community as something we can call our own.
Secondly, we work really hard in the Valley.  I mean, really hard.  I've been loving what I do at my job for 10 years, but I realize that we should take a bit of time to develop some fun avenues for the folks in the South Bay.  This is my attempt to do so.
These upfront donations will help to cover the costs of our great theatre, San Jose Stage, as well as give us a decent budget for building a pretty stellar set.

An Added Incentive

The selflessness of the Rocky community is far and wide, and I want to use the show as a vehicle to join the fight against Chidren's Cancer.  A portion of the proceeds will benefit children who agonize through this fight every day..


The Box Office is officially open!

You're not outright giving us money when you support this cause.  For every $50 we receive, you will receive 1 ticket to the show, and a portion will be donated to St. Baldrick's.  And if you don't want your ticket and are happy to support performing arts in the South Bay, please put "give my ticket away" in the comments and we will gladly give your ticket to a college student who might not be able to afford it.

A bit about Matty Gregg

For those of you who don't know me, I have raised over $100,000 for our wounded veterans in the last few years through varying ventures.  I don't believe that something is really worth doing unless there is an altruistic benefit.  Seeing the sadness that cancer brings to families firsthand, I think it's a good time to focus there (and have a great time doing it!)
I also have a longstanding history in theatre, having co-founded the NH Theatre Awards and performed and produced in award winning community and professional productions.

story:
This performance will be presented in BUDAPEST (Hungary) as a PREVIEW at the Italian Institute of Culture on May 23rd 2016/Lo spettacolo avra' la sua ANTEPRIMA all'Istituto Italiano di Cultura a BUDAPEST (Ungheria) il 23 maggio 2016...


Italian premiere will be at TEATRO MAGNOLIA of ABANO TERME (PADOVA) on July 6th 2016/ La prima italiana sara al TEATRO MAGNOLIA di ABANO TERME (Padova)


The second performance will be in ROME yet to be confirmed and aided by your contributions!!! / IL secondo spettacolo sara' a ROMA tra l'8 e il 10 Luglio da confermare anche in base al vostro contributo!!!


FUNDS RECEIVED WILL HELP THE DANCERS COVER ADDITIONAL COSTS FOR TRAVELLING AND PUTTING ON THE PERFORMANCES (travel, accommodation and promotion)
IL RICAVATO DI QUESTA CAMPAGNA CI DARA' LA POSSIBILITA' DI RICOPRIRE I COSTI AGGIUNTIVI ASSOCIATI ALLA MESSA IN SCENA DELLO SPETTACOLO (Viaggio, alloggio e promozione)


INTERNATIONBALLET(An evening of international 21st century ballet)

This project has the aim to present world class modern ballet to it's artists home country.

International dancers will join their Italian colleagues from the "Hungarain State Ballet" in presenting this first edition of the show and bringing their cultural experiences to Italy.

The evening will present a rich variety of repertoire from pas de deux to new creations in both classical and neo-classical styles. From Romeo and Juliet to creations by Eagling and Duarte and two premiers that are the result of a collaboration of italian artist living abroad: The musician and composer Christian Calcatelli and Dancer and Choreographer Mark Biocca

The cast includes six Italians originally from all different regions of the country and dancers from: Hungary,Croatia, Ukraine, Japan, Moldavia and Russia.

The international quality of the event is not only provided by the ballet dancers but also through the musical and choreographic choices.

The artists will also be giving a workshop for local students on the morning of the days following each performance.

The aim is to present the show in Padova and Rome at the beginning of July 2016.

All funds collected through sponsorship will be to cover the costs of the performance, travel and accommodation for the dancers.


internationBalLET 2016(serata internazionale di balletto all'insegna del XXIesimo secolo)

"Nasce con lo scopo di presentare balletto del ventunesimo secolo di alto livello.

Artisti internazionali uniti a ballerini italiani ingaggiati all'estero che riporteranno a casa il bagaglio culturale acquisito in uno spettacolo ricco di nuove coreografie e di repertorio dal Balletto Nazionale Ungherese di Budapest.

All'interno della serata si viaggerà dallo stile classico, neo-classico e moderno. Dal passo a due di Rome e Giulietta al  le creazioni di eagling e Duarte con una prima italiana di I.F.E.L balletto frutto di una collaborazione estera di artisti Italiani.

Il cast oltre ai  ballerini provenienti da varie regioni italiane includerà' talenti Ungheresi, Croati, Ucraini, Giapponesi, Moldavi e Russi.

Oltre agli artisti presentati, la ricchezza di stile internazionale e' nelle scelte musicali che dei coreografi di fama internazionale.

Gli artisti proporranno in oltre uno stage di danza classica con repertorio per livelli Intermedio ed Avanzato nel giorno seguente alo spettacolo."

story:
UPDATE: 

Through the generosity of Drs. Judy Shih and Joel Axelrod, major donors to the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, every dollar raised through our campaign will be matched to double our impact in providing assistance to artists attending the 5th National Asian American Theatre Conference and Festival (ConFest) in October 2016.

A big part of the expenses of ConFest is subsidizing registration fees and travel costs for artists. With this wonderful challenge grant, every dollar we raise will be doubled ... making it possible for this fundraising campaign to earn $14,000!

------------------------------------

The Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists (CAATA) is an organization that supports the vibrant, growing and changing field of Asian American theater. We organize the National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival (ConFest) and preparations are underway for the fifth convening at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival (OSF) from October 1-8.

Since the first national gathering in 2006, CAATA has rallied Asian American theater artists and professionals to dive headfirst into the deep, challenging conversations that surround what it means to be engaged in American theater as a person of color.

This year’s ConFest at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival is a historic partnership with one of America’s largest theater companies. The theme Seismic Shifts: Leading Change in the American Theater will engage people in passionate dialogues about social injustice and inequality in American culture and what we, as theater practitioners, can do about it.

Over the course of eight days in Ashland, Oregon, the 2016 National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival will bring theater productions, panel discussions, plenary sessions, new play readings, workshops, special events, and most importantly, a space for Asian American theatre practitioners and our allies from across the country to connect and build the relationships that help keep the community vibrant and alive. It will be an opportunity to see some of the amazing work being presented by theater artists across the country.

What Your Help Can Do

We ask you to support CAATA and the upcoming ConFest. Your contribution goes directly toward advancing Asian and Pacific Islander artistic work in the American theater landscape and raising the visibility of the Asian Pacific community, the fastest growing population in the United States.

The 2016 National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival is expected to cost $240,000 for eight days of programming. This includes:

  • staging seven Festival productions, plus numerous showcases and readings

  • hiring technicians, operators and front of house staff

  • honorariums for artists, speakers and panelists

  • travel stipends for ConFest participants

  • printing Conference and Festival materials

  • hosting receptions and other opportunities for attendees to convene

  • ConFest marketing and outreach

Most of the cost will be covered by government and foundation grants. But in order for this historic, national gathering to be successful, we need the support of all members of the American theatre community: artists, administrators, audiences and beyond.

About Us

The Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists (CAATA) envisions a strong and sustainable Asian American theater community that is an integral presence in national culture: evocative of our past, declarative of our present, and innovative towards our future. Our mission is to advance the field of Asian American theater through a national network of organizations and artists. We collaborate to inspire learning and sharing of knowledge and resources to promote a healthy, sustainable artistic ecology.

CAATA is in the process of an exciting strategic plan that will ensure Asian American theatre is a leading force in American theatre. The planning for this ConFest has inspired us to create innovative and sustainable ideas, as well as a strong value system, that we are eager to implement.

With this wonderful challenge grant, every dollar we raise will be doubled ... making it possible for this fundraising campaign to earn $14,000!------------------------------------The Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists (CAATA) is an organization that supports the vibrant, growing and changing field of Asian American theater. We organize the National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival (ConFest) and preparations are underway for the fifth convening at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival (OSF) from October 1-8.Since the first national gathering in 2006, CAATA has rallied Asian American theater artists and professionals to dive headfirst into the deep, challenging conversations that surround what it means to be engaged in American theater as a person of color.This year’s ConFest at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival is a historic partnership with one of America’s largest theater companies. The theme Seismic Shifts: Leading Change in the American Theater will engage people in passionate dialogues about social injustice and inequality in American culture and what we, as theater practitioners, can do about it.Over the course of eight days in Ashland, Oregon, the 2016 National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival will bring theater productions, panel discussions, plenary sessions, new play readings, workshops, special events, and most importantly, a space for Asian American theatre practitioners and our allies from across the country to connect and build the relationships that help keep the community vibrant and alive. It will be an opportunity to see some of the amazing work being presented by theater artists across the country.What Your Help Can DoWe ask you to support CAATA and the upcoming ConFest. Your contribution goes directly toward advancing Asian and Pacific Islander artistic work in the American theater landscape and raising the visibility of the Asian Pacific community, the fastest growing population in the United States.The 2016 National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival is expected to cost $240,000 for eight days of programming. This includes:
staging seven Festival productions, plus numerous showcases and readings
hiring technicians, operators and front of house staff
honorariums for artists, speakers and panelists
travel stipends for ConFest participants
printing Conference and Festival materials
hosting receptions and other opportunities for attendees to convene
ConFest marketing and outreach
Most of the cost will be covered by government and foundation grants. But in order for this historic, national gathering to be successful, we need the support of all members of the American theatre community: artists, administrators, audiences and beyond.About UsThe Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists (CAATA) envisions a strong and sustainable Asian American theater community that is an integral presence in national culture: evocative of our past, declarative of our present, and innovative towards our future. Our mission is to advance the field of Asian American theater through a national network of organizations and artists. We collaborate to inspire learning and sharing of knowledge and resources to promote a healthy, sustainable artistic ecology.CAATA is in the process of an exciting strategic plan that will ensure Asian American theatre is a leading force in American theatre. The planning for this ConFest has inspired us to create innovative and sustainable ideas, as well as a strong value system, that we are eager to implement.

story:
About FENGARI Ensemble

FENGARI Ensemble is a newly founded theater and performing arts company based in New York. We strive to produce diverse work and want to tell stories we believe matter and need to be told. Dolores will be FENGARI Ensemble’s first production in collaboration with professional Guest Artists from every field in the theater. We put together a great production team and cast of all-female artists with many different backgrounds and a great amount of knowledge.


Summary of Dolores (by Edward Allan Baker)

Set in Providence, RI, in 1984,  two sisters find themselves caught up in the cycle of generational abuse. With her family out of the house, Sandra’s peaceful morning is destroyed when her sister Dolores stumbles through her door. Seeking refuge from her abusive husband, Dolores is desperate for a safe haven. Sandra is forced to decide if her troubled older sister and her mountain of problems are worth the inevitable wrath of her own husband. In his one-act, playwright Edward Allan Baker adroitly weaves humor into the dark tale as it races to its surprising conclusion.

Who we are - the core team

KATHLEEN MCNENNY (Director)

Kathleen is a professional actor and director. She has taught and coached actors for many years and is now excited to direct Dolores. Her credits include: Broadway: Fish in the Dark, Enemy of the People, A Death of a Salesman, Coram Boy, The Constant Wife, After the Fall, A Few Good Men. Off- Broadway: Gates of Gold, Mind Game, Three Travellers, Comedy of Errors, Twelfth Night, Winters Tale. Regional: Outside Mullingar (Philadelphia Theater Company), Equus (Guild Hall), Moon for the Misbegotten (McCarter), Richard III (New Jersey Shakespeare Festival), Beyond Therapy, Good German (Westport Playhouse, CT critics nom. Best Actress), Our Town, Sylvia, Sight Unseen, Human Events (George Street Playhouse). TV: Blacklist, House of Cards, Person of Interest, The Black Box, The Good Wife, New Amsterdam, Law and Order (original, CI and SVU), Third Watch,  Pennsylvania Miners Story MOW, numerous failed pilots. FILMS: A Happy House, Morning Glory, Music and Lyrics, School of Rock, Life with Mikey, It could Happen to You.  Her teaching credits include: Juilliard, Rutgers, Temple, UCSD, Cap 21, and the Actors Center. Most recently she directed, wrote, and produced PILLOW TALK about event planner Preston Bailey. Kathleen is a graduate of the Juilliard School of Drama.  For more information visit:  kathleenmcnenny.com


PAULINA COSSIO (Actress/Producer)

Paulina is a professional actor and was born and raised in Mexico City. She started acting at the age of 6 when she became interested in commercials. At age 9 she got into an acting conservatory for kids and completed the program at age 12. By this time she had already booked a recurring role in a Mexican soap opera. She continued expanding her knowledge about acting and at age 13 she found her love for dubbing and voice overs.
When she was 14 she moved to Miami with her parents where she continued studying theater and booked her first co-star role on Burn Notice. She also starred in the Spanish play La Vervena de la Paloma. Paulina recently graduated from The Tom Todoroff Conservatory and is happy to say that Dolores is her first NYC theater production.


LUISA MUHR (Actress/Producer/Founder and Artistic Director of FENGARI Ensemble)

Luisa is a professional actor, singer, and director. She was born and grew up in and around Vienna, Austria. Her background reaches from movement, experimental, and puppet theater, to Yiddish and musical theater where she has performed in ensembles and as a solo artist (as an actor, singer, and/or dancer) in numerous roles and plays. Most recent credits include: several productions with the Bread and Puppet Theater (under Peter Schumann), Swan Song (Box Collective), Empire Travel Agency (Woodshed Collective), Richard III, Andorra, The Jazz Singer (Dora Wasserman Yiddish Theater). Luisa holds a B.F.A. in Theater Performance with Great Distinction from Concordia University (Montreal, Canada) and graduated from a two-year Private Professional Master Class Training Program in NYC. In June 2015 she founded FENGARI Ensemble together with actor and director James Leaf. Luisa has taught as a Performing Arts Teacher (in acting, singing, and dancing) for Stagecoach Theatre Art Schools and has been a private acting and vocal instructor for several years. She is currently teaching the Theater Enrichment Program at the Bedford-Stuyvesant Collegiate in Brooklyn, New York and just got selected as one of the new work/study faculty members at the renowned Mark Morris Dance Group. She is also working on the FENGARI Ensemble production of COCKPIT (by Steve Bellwood). For more information visit: luisamuhr.com


NATALIA VIKHLIAEVA (Set Designer)

Natalia was born to a family of a linguist and a journalist in 1979. Natalia has been a world traveler since an early age. She was growing up in Paris, Moscow, Lima and then, Philadelphia, where she did her BFA in Graphic Design at Temple University. Natalia moved back to Russia in 2003 to pursue her career as an artist/graphic designer. Her multi-cultural background enabled her to have a wider experience as a young professional, as well as build up connections in art communities in different parts of the world. She has worked on a multitude of design tasks ranging from fashion magazines (Cosmopolitan) and weekly political periodicals (Russian Reporter, Expert) to art directing music/theater/festival projects (Usadba Jazz, Afisha festival, Archstoyaniye, Dance Parade, Figment, Brooklyn Wild Life Festival). Aside from FENGARI Ensemble she is currently working with Step Theater on a new production VASILY + FEDERICO as a set and costume designer.


TAMAR LOPEZ (Stage Manager)

An aspiring actor and psychologist, Tamar's love for the theater began in her bedroom where she played pretend with her dolls and action figures. Tamar went on to study theater at the Abron's Art Center as well as Talent Unlimited High School. Tamar is a recent graduate of the City College of New York with a degree in Psychology and Theater. She is an organized and committed stage manager with former experience and keeps the team on track. Tamar is excited to be working with in an all female production. She hopes that the message of this play can reach a wide variety of audiences and begin a discussion with the goal of ending violence against women.


Other artists and collaborators involved so far:

JULIA LENARDON (Dialect Coach)

Julia Lenardon is a professional actress and Voice/Speech/Dialect coach. Credits include: New York: Broadway: Assistant Voice Coach Matilda, the Musical. Off Broadway: Associate Voice Coach Tamburlaine (Theater for a New Audience (TFANA)), This Will All Be Yours (Briar Patch Productions for New York Midtown Musical Theater Festival), Oh my Gad (Gad Elmeleh, Joe’s Pub, The Public Theater). Julia's teaching credits include: ART/The Institute for Advanced Theatre Training at Harvard University, Michigan State University, The National Theatre School of Canada, Tom Todoroff Theatre Conservatory, NYC. Film and TV coaching includes: X-Men: Apocalypse, Brooklyn, 12 Monkeys, Pacific Rim (Post), Pam Am & Revenge (for Karine Vanasse), Immortals, Assassins' Creed Series (Ubisoft), On the Road.


MARISSA GHAVAMI (Talk Back Guest/Founder and CEO of SHEARED (501(c)(3) Nonprofit Spreading Hope for the Exploited and Abused through Resources, Education and Discourse))

Marissa founded SHEARED (Spreading Hope for the Exploited and Abused through Resources, Education and Discourse) in 2014, along with Dr. Bruce Hardy and Debbie Ghavami, and currently serves as the nonprofit’s Chief Executive Officer. Having survived a one-on-one cult, Marissa healed from Complex Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (C-PTSD) and Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES). She then set out to create an organization that addresses the gaps she saw preventing countless others from healing from abuse, the ramifications of which she found greatly impact society as a whole. Marissa is an actor, singer, voice over artist and model, in addition to being an advocate. Credits include: David Chase's (Emmy-winning creator of the hit HBO show The Sopranos) feature film Not Fade Away as well as CBS’s Without A Trace, as well as dozens of theatrical productions. She has sung at the legendary Apollo Theatre in New York City on NBC's Showtime at the Apollo and been named their Star of Tomorrow as well as at New York City hot spot 54 Below. In 2012 she completed a two-year actor training program at The William Esper Studio. Marissa is also a 2015 ASTEP (Artists Striving To End Poverty) Fellow. She is passionate about merging the arts and advocacy, using the arts as both a healing tool and a platform for positive change.


What you can expect...An adventurous evening of awareness!

Not only will you get to see our production of Dolores but we also managed to organize a collaboration between our team and Marissa Ghavami, Founder and CEO of SHEARED (501(c)(3) Nonprofit Spreading Hope for the Exploited and Abused through Resources, Education and Discourse). SHEARED is a newly founded non-profit organization dedicated to spreading hope of true healing to survivors of all types of exploitation and abuse, reducing further instances of abuse and decreasing the harmful misunderstanding of trauma and its widespread effects among the public and professionals through resources, education and discourse. Marissa will hold a talk back after every performance of Dolores about her work as an advocate of raising awareness on abuse and how to get involved. More information about Marissa's organization can be found under: www.sheared.org


Producing Dolores - how it all came together...

It all started with actress and acting teacher Kathleen McNenny conducting a Scene Study Workshop in New York City. Kathleen matched up Paulina Cossio and Luisa Muhr to work on an excerpt from Dolores by Edward Allan Baker. Soon both actresses were so passionate about the play that they kept wanting to explore the depth of this one-act.

When the Workshop was over Kathleen, Paulina, and Luisa all were certain that the play should be produced. With Kathleen’s encouragement Paulina and Luisa finally decided to actually make their dream come true and take initiative to start the production process. Kathleen was so supportive of this decision that she offered herself as the director of the one-act. Starting off as three ladies this production has since grown to an all-female team with artists who are interested in female stories and bringing awareness to domestic violence, a topic concerning all of us.

We are also incredibly excited to make a collaboration with SHEARED happen


Why all female?

We are still in a time where women are less likely to get hired than men and with Dolores we created a platform where women with all different backgrounds, who are eager to get involved in a project like this, are welcome to participate and share their knowledge. Our production of Dolores, including the talk back on abuse, is a collaboration of women who create something together – something that they care about. FENGARI Ensemble also strives to keep the team of Dolores and its collaborators on board for upcoming productions and projects, guaranteeing female emerging artists and professionals a platform where they can explore, live their passion, and get involved in as many ways as they want.


Why this story - why support us?

It is important to realize that the topic of domestic violence concerns both, men and women. We must understand that this is not a “female topic” – it is a human topic.

We have to spread the awareness that one woman out of four gets somehow abused – one out of four! Isn’t that crazy?! What's even more striking is that in the U.S. incidents of domestic violence against women occur every 15 seconds. And these numbers only reflect the cases that were reported, so imagine how many more cases there actually are… Our first gut reaction was: How come we didn’t know about this?! And: How come no one else seems to know about this?! We knew that this needed to change…

When we heard this number we were shocked and knew that the story of Dolores is not an uncommon one. This is when we started realizing the actual importance of Dolores. We understood that this topic was bigger and more important than we had ever imagined it to be and there was no more hesitation: The story of Dolores had to be re-told as a reminder of what is going on in the depths and shadows of our society on a daily basis.
As actors and theater makers we strive to do what we do best: tell stories. So, what we can do is use our art for a specific cause. We want to make a change by drawing awareness and contributing to the solving and healing of women's issues (that is our issues as a society).

We are also excited to announce that we are now collaborating with the Kentucky-based organization SHEARED, founded and run by Marissa Ghavami. We would like to reach past our Flex Goal of $6500 to be able to raise money for SHEARED. Marissa is coming to New York and will hold talk backs about abuse and how to stop it after every performance of Dolores.


Our adventures, efforts, and highs so far

We have already been working on this play for a while now and keep exploring and finding new elements of it.
Some of our favorite experiences and adventures so far:

We managed to arrange a meeting with the playwright Edward Allan Baker who was such an incredible source of knowledge and such great help to us. Edward was one of the most open and kindest people we have met in a long time. He didn’t shy away from telling us everything about his play, it’s back story, and the lifestyle, history, and roles of the two characters he had created. We are forever grateful to have his consent in producing his incredible one-act.

While still working on Dolores during the Scene Study class we managed to drive to a suburb in Rhode Island and record local people there in order to be able to carefully study the dialect.

Having Julia Lenardon, an acclaimed dialect and vocal coach, on our team has always been a dream and the amount of help we have had from her to really work the very difficult Rhode Island dialect cannot even be described in words. We have had great sessions and keep striving forward with our dialect work. 

Another great thank you goes out to our dear friend Irwin Chusid, who provided us with a perfect song we can use in the play. The playwright specifically mentioned the song he wanted to be used in the play to resemble a Shirelles song but getting the rights for any band as famous as the Shirelles was impossible, so Irwin came to our rescue!

Last but not least, our prop, set pieces, and costume hunt brought us to Upstate New York and its many diverse little bazaars and yard sales. We have had great finds so far, did a lot of bargaining, and have now already started to build our set. We are excited to see the final product!

The most recent accomplishment was getting Marissa Ghavami, founder of SHEARED, to come to New York to hold talk backs on abuse and what to do after our shows.


Budget – How is the money distributed and where does it go?

Most of the money has to go into renting rehearsal spaces and the actual rental of the theater – which both is incredibly expensive in NYC.
Other big costs are definitely set and props, actually compensating our production and creative team, renting the lights and hire a light operator from the theater, printing costs and advertising, and the very important dialect coaching sessions to stay truthful to this amazing play and do it justice.


Flex Goals

It is really important that even when we have reached our goal of $3500 we please need you to keep supporting us! This first goal does NOT cover all our costs. We picked a lower goal, so that we can be assured to at least cover some of the costs. Looking ahead and calculating in what we have already had to spend, our expenses come to around $5500 (breakdown in percentages see budget diagram). This is mostly due to the expensive rehearsal space rental in NYC (although we always rehearse at the cheapest rental studio in town), but also to cover the rent of the theater and all other expenses. We are hoping to fill the theater on all 4 performances, so are expecting to cover more costs with the ticket sales, however that is not guaranteed.

So we really need your help to raise our next goals in order to make this production work!

$4000

This will help us to cover a big amount of our costs! Thank you!

$5000

Great! We are not too far away from covering all our main costs without having to depend on ticket sales – thank you so much!

$6000

Yay! We can pretty much cover our main costs! Thank you! You are also making it possible for the amazing production and creative team to receive a fair compensation for their incredibly hard work! This is very important to us since so much work has gone into developing Dolores.

$6500 and beyond

Hooray! Apart from guaranteeing the amazing production and creative team a fair stipend you are making it possible to actually compensate the cast and director for all their hard work and immense efforts! In addition to that we will donate any amount past our $6500 flex goal to SHEARED, a newly founded non-profit organization dedicated to spreading hope of true healing to survivors of all types of exploitation and abuse, reducing further instances of abuse and decreasing the harmful misunderstanding of trauma and its widespread effects among the public and professionals through resources, education and discourse. With this we want to support an organization that focuses on supporting survivors of abuse. You have helped to really make a difference and we are so very grateful! Thank you so, so much!


Risks and Challenges

One of the biggest challenges, apart from this being our first time producing anything ourselves, was finding an affordable venue in NYC. We looked into several options but then came across The Playroom Theater and it seemed perfect for our purposes. We wanted to make sure the venue was fairly accessible, so that people would actually come. It is so important to us to share this story with as many people as possible!
The other big challenge was finding an affordable rehearsal rental space. This really has ended up costing us the most so far. Although we are rehearsing at the cheapest studio rental space in town, costs are immense and hard to keep low.

Another challenge was how to reduce the costs on finding a set and props. We managed to get everything we need from bazaars and yard sales in Upstate New York which helped us keeping costs low, however a lot is needed for our set since it should portray a kitchen. Our amazing set designer Natalia Vikhliaeva is helping us to realize this without having to spend thousands of dollars.
Apart from our dialect coach Julia Lenardon (who also worked for an incredibly low price) our entire production and creative team is volunteer-based. To actually find a professional team that is willing to work for free or fully relying on our crowd funding campaign is not easy – simply because there is no guarantee for anyone  involved to get compensated. However, we are truly hoping to raise money so we can pay our team, even if it is only a small amount.  Everyone has been working really hard and it is very important to us to compensate each person involved.

We have already put a lot of work into it but the very specific and extremely difficult Rhode Island dialect has been a challenge. The first challenge was to even make the decision to do the one-act in this dialect but we wanted to be truthful to the play and do it justice, so decided we would take on learning the dialect, even though it was coupled with a lot of extra costs and much extra work.
Last but not least we had another problem with finding a space to build and store our set. Luckily our set designer had some extra space in her apartment, so the set will be assembled and built there for now. But we are still looking into affordable studios or shared workshop spaces where we could paint and build the set.


How it works - Perks

Pick a perk and go! It's all straight forward and easy, just follow the steps and you'll be done in a minute or less. All our perks are named after all-female-bands of the 60s, 70s, and 80s. We hope you'll enjoy picking one! And please share our campaign with your friends and family and anyone who could be interested!

Don't want to pick a perk but still want to support us? – Great! Just click on "Select Perk" and then on "No perk. I just want to contribute". Thank you so much! We really appreciate it!


To all Donors

Thank you so much for supporting us in this! This is for a good cause and we promise to do our very best to make this production the most professional and everything it deserves to be! We are doing our very best to shine light on a topic that is not getting a lot of attention and we could not do this without your help. From the bottom of our hearts: Thank you!


FAQs

  • Can I donate even if I live abroad (not in the US):  Yes, you can. We accept international donations and encourage everyone to help supporting this project.
  • Will my name be publicly displayed once I have made a donation: No, not if you don’t want it to. Simply select "Hide my name" when you make your donation.
  • Can I get involved with FENGARI Ensemble? Yes. We are always looking for eager people to get involved. Please contact us under fengariensemble@gmail.com and we will get back to as soon as possible on how you can get involved. Artists of all backgrounds (theater, music, dance, visual art,...) are welcome!


How else you can help…

  • Come to our show! :) (Tickets: Direct Link to TICKETS and via our website: www.fengariensemble.com)
  • Like us on Facebook and Twitter! (FENGARI Ensemble Page, FENGARI Ensemble on Twitter)
  • Join our Dolores Facebook Event! (Dolores Facebook Event)
  • Spread the word! Tell your friends and family about our campaign, the production itself, and share a link on facebook and twitter!

Please feel free to contact us if you have any questions: fengariensemble@gmail.com


THANK YOU!

Luisa, Paulina, and Kathleen
(in the name of the entire team)
