She is passionate about merging the arts and advocacy, using the arts as both a healing tool and a platform for positive change.


What you can expect...An adventurous evening of 
awareness! Not only will you get to see our production of Dolores but 
we also managed to organize a collaboration between our team and Marissa
 Ghavami, Founder and CEO of SHEARED
 (501(c)(3) Nonprofit Spreading 
Hope for the Exploited and Abused through Resources, Education and 
Discourse). SHEARED is a newly founded non-profit
organization dedicated to spreading hope of true healing to survivors of
 all
types of exploitation and abuse, reducing further instances of abuse and
decreasing the harmful misunderstanding of trauma and its widespread 
effects
among the public and professionals through resources, education and 
discourse. Marissa will hold a talk back after every performance of Dolores about
 her work as an advocate of raising awareness on abuse and how to get 
involved. More information about Marissa's organization can be found 
under: www.sheared.orgProducing Dolores - how it all came together...It all started with actress and acting teacher Kathleen
McNenny conducting a Scene Study Workshop in New York City. Kathleen matched up
Paulina Cossio and Luisa Muhr to work on an excerpt from Dolores by Edward Allan Baker. Soon both actresses were so
passionate about the play that they kept wanting to explore the depth of this
one-act. 
When the Workshop was over Kathleen, Paulina, and Luisa all
were certain that the play should be produced. With Kathleen’s encouragement
Paulina and Luisa finally decided to actually make their dream come true and
take initiative to start the production process. Kathleen was so supportive of
this decision that she offered herself as the director of the one-act. Starting
off as three ladies this production has since grown to an all-female team with
artists who are interested in female stories and bringing awareness to domestic
violence, a topic concerning all of us.We are also incredibly excited to make a collaboration with SHEARED happen 
Why all female?We are still in a time where women are less likely to get
hired than men and with Dolores we
created a platform where women with all different backgrounds, who are eager to
get involved in a project like this, are welcome to participate and share their
knowledge. Our production of Dolores, including the talk back on abuse, is a collaboration of women who create something together – something that they care about. FENGARI Ensemble
also strives to keep the team of Dolores
and its collaborators on board for upcoming productions and projects, guaranteeing female emerging
artists and professionals a platform where they can explore, live their
passion, and get involved in as many ways as they want.Why this story - why support us?
It is important to realize that the topic of domestic
violence concerns both, men and women. We must understand that this is not a
“female topic” – it is a human topic. 
We have to spread the awareness that one woman out of four
gets somehow abused – one out of four! Isn’t that crazy?! What's even more striking is that in the U.S. incidents of domestic violence against women occur every 15 seconds. And these numbers only reflect the cases that were reported, so imagine how many more cases
there actually are… Our first gut reaction was: How come we didn’t know
about this?! And: How come no one else seems to know about this?! We knew that
this needed to change…
When we heard this number we were shocked and knew that the
story of Dolores is not an uncommon
one. This is when we started realizing the actual importance of Dolores. We understood that this topic
was bigger and more important than we had ever imagined it to be and there was
no more hesitation: The story of Dolores
had to be re-told as a reminder of what is going on in the depths and shadows
of our society on a daily basis. As actors and theater makers we strive to do what we do best: tell stories. So, what we can do is use our art for a specific cause. We want to make a change by drawing awareness and contributing to the solving and healing of women's issues (that is our issues as a society).We are also excited to announce that we are now collaborating with the Kentucky-based organization SHEARED, founded and run by Marissa Ghavami. We would like to reach past our Flex Goal of $6500 to be able to raise money for SHEARED. Marissa is coming to New York and will hold talk backs about abuse and how to stop it after every performance of Dolores.
Our adventures, efforts, and highs so
far
We have already been working on this play for a while now
and keep exploring and finding new elements of it. 
Some of our favorite experiences and adventures so far: 
We managed to arrange a meeting with the playwright Edward
Allan Baker who was such an incredible source of knowledge and such great help
to us. Edward was one of the most open and kindest people we have met in a long
time. He didn’t shy away from telling us everything about his play, it’s back
story, and the lifestyle, history, and roles of the two characters he had
created. We are forever grateful to have his consent in producing his
incredible one-act.
While still working on Dolores during the Scene Study class we
managed to drive to a suburb in Rhode Island and record local people there in
order to be able to carefully study the dialect.Having Julia Lenardon, an acclaimed dialect and vocal coach,
on our team has always been a dream and the amount of help we have had from her
to really work the very difficult Rhode Island dialect cannot even be described
in words. We have had great sessions and keep striving forward with our dialect
work.  Another great thank you goes out to our dear friend Irwin Chusid, who provided us with a perfect song we can use in the play. The playwright specifically mentioned the song he wanted to be used in the play to resemble a Shirelles song but getting the rights for any band as famous as the Shirelles was impossible, so Irwin came to our rescue!Last but not least, our prop, set pieces, and costume hunt
brought us to Upstate New York and its many diverse little bazaars and yard
sales. We have had great finds so far, did a lot of bargaining, and have now
already started to build our set. We are excited to see the final product!The most recent accomplishment was getting Marissa Ghavami, founder of SHEARED, to come to New York to hold talk backs on abuse and what to do after our shows. Budget – How is the
money distributed and where does it go?Most of the money has to go into renting rehearsal spaces and the actual rental of the theater –  which both is incredibly expensive in NYC.Other big costs are definitely set and props, actually compensating our production and creative team, renting the lights and hire a light operator from the theater, printing costs and advertising, and the very important dialect coaching sessions to stay truthful to this amazing play and do it justice.Flex GoalsIt is really important that even when we have reached our
goal of $3500 we please need you to keep supporting us! This first goal does
NOT cover all our costs. We picked a lower goal, so that we can be assured to
at least cover some of the costs. Looking ahead and calculating in what we have
already had to spend, our expenses come to around $5500 (breakdown in
percentages see budget diagram). This is mostly due to the expensive rehearsal
space rental in NYC (although we always rehearse at the cheapest rental studio
in town), but also to cover the rent of the theater and all other expenses. We
are hoping to fill the theater on all 4 performances, so are expecting to cover
more costs with the ticket sales, however that is not guaranteed. 
So we really need your help to raise our next goals in order to make this
production work!
$4000
This will help us to cover a big amount of our costs! Thank you!
$5000 
Great! We are not too far away from covering all our main costs without having to
depend on ticket sales – thank you so much!
$6000
Yay! We can pretty much cover our main costs! Thank you! You are also making it possible for the amazing production
and creative team to receive a fair compensation for their incredibly hard
work! This is very important to us since so much work has gone into developing Dolores. 
$6500 and beyond
Hooray! Apart from guaranteeing the amazing production and
creative team a fair stipend you are making it possible to actually compensate
the cast and director for all their hard work and immense efforts! In addition
to that we will donate any amount past our $6500 flex goal to SHEARED, a newly founded non-profit
organization dedicated to spreading hope of true healing to survivors of all
types of exploitation and abuse, reducing further instances of abuse and
decreasing the harmful misunderstanding of trauma and its widespread effects
among the public and professionals through resources, education and discourse. With this we want to support an organization that focuses on
supporting survivors of abuse. You have helped to really make a difference and we are so very grateful! Thank you so, so much! 
Risks and Challenges
One of the biggest challenges, apart from this being our
first time producing anything ourselves, was finding an affordable venue in
NYC. We looked into several options but then came across The Playroom Theater
and it seemed perfect for our purposes. We wanted to make sure the venue was
fairly accessible, so that people would actually come. It is so important to us
to share this story with as many people as possible! 
The other big challenge was finding an affordable rehearsal rental space. This
really has ended up costing us the most so far. Although we are rehearsing at
the cheapest studio rental space in town, costs are immense and hard to keep
low. 
Another challenge was how to reduce the costs on finding a
set and props. We managed to get everything we need from bazaars and yard sales
in Upstate New York which helped us keeping costs low, however a lot is needed
for our set since it should portray a kitchen. Our amazing set designer Natalia
Vikhliaeva is helping us to realize this without having to spend thousands of
dollars. 
Apart from our dialect coach Julia Lenardon (who also worked for an incredibly low price) our
entire production and creative team is volunteer-based. To actually find a
professional team that is willing to work for free or fully relying on our
crowd funding campaign is not easy – simply because there is no guarantee for anyone  involved to get
compensated. However, we are truly hoping to raise money so we can pay our
team, even if it is only a small amount. 
Everyone has been working really hard and it is very important to us to
compensate each person involved. 
We have already put a lot of work into it but the very
specific and extremely difficult Rhode Island dialect has been a challenge. The
first challenge was to even make the decision to do the one-act in this dialect but we
wanted to be truthful to the play and do it justice, so decided we would take
on learning the dialect, even though it was coupled with a lot of extra costs
and much extra work. 
Last but not least we had another problem with finding a space to build and
store our set. Luckily our set designer had some extra space in her apartment,
so the set will be assembled and built there for now. But we are still looking
into affordable studios or shared workshop spaces where we could paint and
build the set.
How it works - PerksPick a perk and go! It's all straight forward and easy, just follow the steps and you'll be done in a minute or less. All our perks are named after all-female-bands of the 60s, 70s, and 80s. We hope you'll enjoy picking one! And please share our campaign with your friends and family and anyone who could be interested!Don't want to pick a perk but still want to support us? – Great! Just click on "Select Perk" and then on "No perk. I just want to contribute". Thank you so much! We really appreciate it!
To all DonorsThank you so much for supporting us in this! This is for a good cause and we promise to do our very best to make
this production the most professional and everything it deserves to be! We are doing our very best to shine light on a topic that is not getting a lot of attention and we
could not do this without your help. From the bottom of our hearts: Thank you!
FAQs


Can I donate even if I live abroad (not in the US):  Yes, you can. We accept
international donations and encourage everyone to help supporting this project.

Will my name be publicly displayed once I have made a donation: No, not if you don’t want it to. Simply select "Hide my name" when you make your donation. 

Can I get involved with FENGARI Ensemble? Yes. We are always looking for eager people to get involved. Please contact us under
fengariensemble@gmail.com and we will
get back to as soon as possible on how you can get involved. Artists of all backgrounds (theater, music, dance, visual art,...) are welcome!

How else you can help… 

Come to our show! :) (Tickets: Direct Link to TICKETS and via our website: www.fengariensemble.com)

Like us on Facebook and Twitter! (FENGARI Ensemble Page, FENGARI Ensemble on Twitter)
Join our Dolores Facebook Event! (Dolores Facebook Event)

Spread the word! Tell your friends and family
     about our campaign, the production itself, and share a link on facebook and twitter!

Please feel free to contact us if you have any questions:
fengariensemble@gmail.comTHANK YOU!Luisa, Paulina, and Kathleen (in the name of the entire team)

story:
About The Project

PENTEJOY is an award-winning musical that tells the story of the Apostles' journey from the Crucifixion to the Pentecost. Exploring the tension between faith and doubt, Pentejoy recognizes that we all live somewhere on the continuum between believer and non-believer, and seeks to validate and bless both journeys.
​

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to bring Pentejoy to the stage & to share its message with as many people as possible! The funds we raise will go directly towards deferring costs associated with producing a musical - hiring orchestra musicians and lighting technicians, creating costumes and set, printing the sheet music, and securing the venue. 

With your contribution, you become part of our family. Your help ensures that Pentejoy receives a professional, world-class production, and that its message of hope and faith lives on.

The Impact

Pentejoy, conceived by director and composer Joe Sireno, was originally produced in 1978 with a very low budget. It received some local notoriety and became popular in the New York/New Jersey area.

Today we’re giving Pentejoy a new lease on life with a modern production. Lights, set, and new orchestrations will help tell this story of hope, and will allow us to share it with you in truly glorious fashion. Our cast and crew have been working very hard to master the script, score, and choreography in anticipation of our opening night this April!

Challenges

Our production has been blessed by a number of wonderful volunteers who have sacrificed their time and energy, but we still need the talents of many professionals to ensure that Pentejoy will be everything that we want it to be. We want to compensate these extremely talented individuals fairly, and show respect for their work and their contributions.

Other Ways You Can Help

We greatly appreciate your contributions to this project. If, however, you are unable to donate, you can help in the following ways:
  • Share this webpage and spread the Word! Our aim is to reach as many people as possible.
  • Consider volunteering your time this spring during productions! Please contact us here. Thank You!

story:
Short Summary

We're Kick at the Dark Theatre and we're reaching out to YOU to help us in the production of Theresa Rebeck's Seminar, playing at the Theatre Nova Scotia Living Room this May 18-22, 2016.  Your support will allow us to pay our actors a viable wage and enhance production values for this timely and intriguing comedy. 

Who: Kick at the Dark Theatre Co. is a new Halifax-based theatre company which aims to present work that is both vitally socially conscious, and that embraces the power of imagination in theatre.  Our team includes Director/Co-Producer: Andrew Chandler, Stage Manager: Olivia McGinn, Actors: Jamie Bradley as Leonard, Nick Perron as Douglas, Morgan Melnyk as Izzy, Henricus Gielis as Martin, and Katerina Bakolias as Kate/Co-Producer. 

What: Seminar: A linguistically rich, funny, sexy, and thought-provoking comedy that features four young fiction writers who engage an older, established mentor in a writing seminar. A brash, brutally “honest” genius, with questionable priorities and troubles of his own, this mentor rips the blinders off his protégés and reveals the reality of their work, talent, and relationships, leaving the four young artists to cope with the “truth” he reveals. 

When: May 18th-22nd, 2016

Where: Theatre Nova Scotia Living Room, (2353 Agricola St.) Halifax, Nova Scotia.

Why: At times hilarious, caustic, moving and inspirational, the play questions our relationship with teachers (what we want from them, what we expect from them, and how we react when we get neither), as well as forcing us to confront the necessity of compromise in life and in art – how much can you comfortably “sell out” (ethically, financially, and personally) to make a living?  It also deals with specific issues of sexual agency, sexual exploitation and love, as they're expressed in the culture of artists, and in the power dynamic of adult student and teacher. We feel the truths and questions in this area are vitally important to both women and men, in the artistic community, in our lives as artists, and in society as a whole. 


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $3000.00, this funding will go towards paying our technicians and actors, space rental, promotion and set, props, costumes, etc.  We have agreed to share in any profits generated, in order to produce a piece of theatre that we are passionate about, and we believe, of vital importance to Halifax's theatre scene. 

Perks!

We have a number of different perks that we are excited to share when you donate to our production. Some of the perks include:

  • Motivational poster from a character in the play!
  • Life advice from Leonard!
  • Book recommendations from the cast!
  • Free tickets to the show!
  • Dinner with the cast!
Which perks you are eligible to receive are dependant on the amount you donate, check out the 'Perks' section of our campaign for more information!


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Check out Kick at the Dark Theatre Company on Facebook and Like us for more information about the show!

If you've read this far, you are a champion.  Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

We are a passionate group of New York City theater professionals who are putting on a production of Craig Wright's contemporary masterpiece "The Pavilion". 

Hailed by critics as an "an Our Town for our time," this play is by turns poetic and comic, romantic and philosophical. Peter returns to his twenty-year high-school reunion with dreams of winning back Kari, the girl he left behind after an unexpected pregnancy ended their relationship. Standing in Peter's way is Kari's bitter-as-ever resentment, her husband and the fact that Peter still hasn't grown up. As the night progresses, both Peter and Kari are led, through their interactions with a host of characters all played by a virtuosic Narrator, to face the consequences of choices made long ago and start back into life with newfound strength and bittersweet resolve. 

Directed by Michael Kostroff ("The Wire", "The Blacklist"), this innovative production will use 3-D projection to create the nuance and feel of the play's setting.  Starring Ayesha Adamo, Jon Adam Ross, and Jeffrey Delano Davis.

By donating to our production, you will help us to fund artists salaries, cover the theater rental, and meet our marketing costs (to name a few).  Watch our video, and consider helping us make this beautiful, unknown gem of a play come to life!

What We Need & What You Get

Though we have already obtained some early funding, we still have a while to go to meet our costs.  We could use your help with:

  • set, lighting and projection design salaries
  • director and actor salaries
  • video installation costs
  • marketing costs
  • set construction costs
We have many donation levels and perks available including tickets to the show and the opening night party!

The Impact

We know that there are many theater projects out there, but we believe this production is truly unique.  We've dug deep into the theater cannon to find a play that has not been routinely produced, and speaks to a wide audience.  We are incorporating 3-D video, and have brought on some of New York City's finest theatrical talent.  We have already obtained early funding and secured a theater space, the rights to the play, hired preliminary cast and crew, and a publicist.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate now? No problem.  Consider buying a ticket to the show for only $18!: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2342060

story:
Short Summary

We'll keep it brief..we know how busy you are...

Help us to Be Outspoken!! 

At Outspoken Arts we use the arts to explore the human experience, respond to social issues and create change - and we desperately need your help!!

We are in the 2nd phase of research & development of our production #ReGeneration - we've been accepted into the Camden People's Theatre festival 'Whose London Is It Anyway' which is great news! We will premiere our work-in-progress piece on Tuesday 19th January at 7.15pm. But just before Christmas we found out our funding had fallen through but we aren't gonna let that hold us back from getting our voice out there with a piece of theatre that is of the people & for the people - we need to BE OUTSPOKEN about the mass evictions & social cleansing taking place in Brixton. 

We need to talk about it using the only way we know that successfully creates change - by telling the story. And with first hand experience living on one of the estates being 'regenerated' in Brixton, this story offers a unique glimpse into reality. 

#ReGeneration explores the system of ‘gentrification’ through the lens of the increasingly segregated Brixton. It examines the relationship between councils and developers, the role of 'us' as artists, the pricing out that people experience & the sudden mixing (or non mixing) of classes. The clash & cohesion of different ‘London tribes’. We want to bring these different 'groups' together to create a platform for dialogue. 

What We Need..

We've dusted ourselves off, given ourselves a talking to and come up with a plan - we've stripped the project right back to the bare bones, every penny you contribute will be going towards paying actors to do the reading for the festival.

We'll do everything else. Unpaid. We urgently need to tell this story, it's everyone's story and getting it out there and heard is most important to us. 

We have a script (via our writer - Endy McKay), rehearsal space (with support in kind from Oval House Theatre), a performance space (Camden People's Theatre) and all the bits in between but to really move people we need tip top actor's to tell the story and help us to create that change.

We need 6 actors 

We will pay them £70 per day.

2x day rehearsal (£840)

1x day Tech run & performance (£420)

£1260 total - Every penny we are asking for is to pay them for their contribution.

Risks & Challenges

Bring it on! We know this is going to be challenging, we are both actresses (we being Chetna Pandya & Endy McKay), co founders & directors of Outspoken Arts & both mothers too but what's the point of looking back at your life and wondering how your contribution might have changed something. Why not be the change. So we are going to be drinking caffeine by the bucket load and getting it done. Risks & Challenges - none that we aren't ready to conquer! 

We have a strong community of creatives around us and our mobiles are armed at the ready to pull in some favours too :)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help out with some £££ you can still help! Here's how..

Spread the word about the show & us using social media

Tweet about us with these twitter handles

#ReGeneration #WhoseLondon @outspokenarts @CamdenPT @EndyMckay @Chetna_Pandya

Share this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools - know anyone with some spare cash? Send it to them!! 

How about Facebook 

www.facebook.com/beoutspoken

Check out our testimonials from R&D stage 1

“I think it would make a great theatre piece and a great site-specific piece. I definitely started imagining it taking place in really exciting, just-about-to-be-gentrified spaces, but I think a theatre version could work well too. I thought the writing and the performances were just great - really strong and really exciting.” Poppy Keeling, Complicite 

“WELL DONE!!! Its a really exciting and important project.” Amy Clamp, Pleasance Theatre 

“Loved it! Thought the actors were terrific and it demonstrated a huge amount of work for a week.” Catherine Alexander, CSSD

“I always end a day's work berating myself for talking too much! But then the next day, do exactly the same thing again, because I felt so passionate about the work you'd made. Well done and thank you. It was a really affirming experience being asked to contribute and think. Wow, being encouraged to think while working with women who inspire you, Win bloody WIN!! What a fabulous week that was. Very inspiring watching you and Endy making it happen. And I really appreciated being in the room. Bodes really well for the production that you galvanised all of us during the week. We'll all be there at the next occupation!” Ayesha Antoine – Actor
story_txt:

We are in the 2nd phase of research & development of our production #ReGeneration - we've been accepted into the Camden People's Theatre festival 'Whose London Is It Anyway' which is great news! We will premiere our work-in-progress piece on Tuesday 19th January at 7.15pm. But just before Christmas we found out our funding had fallen through but we aren't gonna let that hold us back from getting our voice out there with a piece of theatre that is of the people & for the people - we need to BE OUTSPOKEN about the mass evictions & social cleansing taking place in Brixton. 






We need to talk about it using the only way we know that successfully creates change - by telling the story. And with first hand experience living on one of the estates being 'regenerated' in Brixton, this story offers a unique glimpse into reality. 








#ReGeneration explores the system of ‘gentrification’ through the lens of the increasingly segregated Brixton. It
examines the relationship between councils and developers, the role of 'us' as artists, the pricing out that people
experience & the sudden mixing (or non mixing) of classes. The clash & cohesion of different ‘London tribes’. We want to bring these different 'groups' together to create a platform for dialogue. 


   What We Need.. 
We've dusted ourselves off, given ourselves a talking to and come up with a plan - we've stripped the project right back to the bare bones, every penny you contribute will be going towards paying actors to do the reading for the festival.
We'll do everything else. Unpaid. We urgently need to tell this story, it's everyone's story and getting it out there and heard is most important to us. 
We have a script (via our writer - Endy McKay), rehearsal space (with support in kind from Oval House Theatre), a performance space (Camden People's Theatre) and all the bits in between but to really move people we need tip top actor's to tell the story and help us to create that change.
We need 6 actors 
We will pay them £70 per day.
2x day rehearsal (£840)
1x day Tech run & performance (£420)
£1260 total - Every penny we are asking for is to pay them for their contribution.

Risks & Challenges Bring it on! We know this is going to be challenging, we are both actresses (we being Chetna Pandya & Endy McKay), co founders & directors of Outspoken Arts & both mothers too but what's the point of looking back at your life and wondering how your contribution might have changed something. Why not be the change. So we are going to be drinking caffeine by the bucket load and getting it done. Risks & Challenges - none that we aren't ready to conquer! 
We have a strong community of creatives around us and our mobiles are armed at the ready to pull in some favours too :)
    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't help out with some £££ you can still help! Here's how..
Spread the word about the show & us using social media
Tweet about us with these twitter handles
#ReGeneration #WhoseLondon @outspokenarts @CamdenPT @EndyMckay @Chetna_Pandya
Share this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools - know anyone with some spare cash? Send it to them!! 
How about Facebook 
www.facebook.com/beoutspoken
Check out our testimonials from R&D stage 1“I think it would make a great theatre piece and a great site-specific piece. I definitely started imagining it taking place in really exciting, just-about-to-be-gentrified spaces, but I think a theatre version could work well too. I thought the writing and the performances were just great - really strong and really exciting.” Poppy Keeling, Complicite “WELL DONE!!! Its a really exciting and important project.” Amy Clamp, Pleasance Theatre “Loved it! Thought the actors were terrific and it demonstrated a huge amount of work for a week.” Catherine Alexander, CSSD“I always end a day's work berating myself for talking too much! But then the next day, do exactly the same thing again, because I felt so passionate about the work you'd made. Well done and thank you. It was a really affirming experience being asked to contribute and think. Wow, being encouraged to think while working with women who inspire you, Win bloody WIN!! What a fabulous week that was. Very inspiring watching you and Endy making it happen. And I really appreciated being in the room. Bodes really well for the production that you galvanised all of us during the week. We'll all be there at the next occupation!” Ayesha Antoine – Actor

story:
The Canary's Silence campaign has been extended! 

We behind the Canary’s Silence are committed to exploring experiences that audiences have never seen or heard before and we are determined to get as many people in the seats as possible. 

Therefore, we are extending our indiegogo.com crowdfunding campaign with an added special perk, nearly equivalent to the price of a ticket, allowing us to “pre-sell tickets” and raise the funds for insurance, rentals, in-house technicians, local marketing, transportation, and gas.  

Of course, we are greatly appreciative to larger donors, which are such a huge benefit to this show and to this young artist’s future, which is so very bright.  

The Canary’s Silence is a performance work, three years into its making and a true collaborative process between deciplines and a host of creative individuals. 

The seed for the show was planted as an idea for an independent study by Jack Kavanagh under the supervision of Cirque Du Soleil choreographer Michael Montanaro. That idea grew into what we hope will dazzle audiences in Vermont and New Haven this summer!  But we need your help! ECA shows are back to back, August 19th and 20th at Educational Center for the Arts 55 Audubon St. The Shows start at 8PM.  Children are welcome but be advised the show is performed in the dark. 


Short Summary
OPEN RING CIRCUS is an arts and entertainment collective based out of the North Eastern USA and CANADA created by Jack Kavanagh. When constructing our shows, we strive to use only original music and make it a point of showcasing the young-and-talented, up-and-coming artists of the next generation.  We work closely with the musicians and other contributing artists to build a show that is both true to our and their artistic vision in order to present audiences with things they have not seen or heard before.
Our new show, Canary’s Silence, is a performance work that is three years into its creative process.  It began as an independent study by Jack Kavanagh under the supervision of Cirque Du Soleil choreographer Michael Montanaro. The next phase of this project is turning it from a dance show into a limitless circus show. With the amazing support of the New England Center for Circus Arts and your gifts, we will bring this show to the next level. 

The story is about a group of city-goers caught in an urban black-out. It takes you on a journey through an unfamiliar, dark, and unplugged urban environment. The show features large inflatable and sculptural set pieces, as well as, new innovative apparatus and mesmerizing imagery.


SHOW DATES 
Aug 12th in Brattleboro VT. At New England Center for Circus Arts 
(NECCA Austine Gym) Showtime 8pm
&
Aug 19th-20th New Haven CT. At Educational Center for the ARTS 
(ECA Arts Hall) Doors 7:30pm Show Time 8:00pm


What We Need & What You Get 

  • This campaign will help Jack and his collective of acrobats and artists present this show at the New England Center for Circus Arts in Brattleboro, Vermont, on August 12, 2016; and two nights at The Educational Center for the Arts in New Haven, Connecticut, this coming summer, 2016.  Raising a goal of $6,600 will allow "Open Ring Circus" to build and create this show in all its circus glory!
  • Our perks are simple.  Since we want you to see this amazing show, tickets are in nearly every Perk!  If you cannot make any of the performances, you can transfer your tickets to a friend.  In addition, our generous musicians,  BUFFLO, Zebrat, Raveen & GYM TEACHER, have generously donated free downloads of their original music featured in the show!
  • The funds raised will go to our performers, props, rental costs and insurance.

  • By giving to this campaign, you are providing the start-up funds for a new and  innovative American Circus Company. You are providing jobs for circus performers fresh out of school.  

  • The Impact of this show reaches far beyond our cast and crew. By donating to this production you are:
  •  Helping bridge relationships between international circus, theater, music and dance creators; 
  • Giving five emerging performers the chance to be in a small ensemble troupe (A dream for most all circus performers); and,

  • If our goal is met, we may have a chance to bring the show further than New Haven.

  • This show is cultivating an alumna relationship with The Educational Center for the Arts and our Director, Jack Kavanagh.

  • You are supporting circus; and when you support circus, you are supporting every facet of the arts plus athletics, 

  • The completion of this show will encourage a wave of creative productions from OPEN RING CIRCUS. 

Risks & Challenges

Putting on a show as ambitious as the Canary's Silence is a challenge regardless of where it is performed.  There are many moving parts in the performance.  Our performers will be traveling from Montreal to Vermont and Connecticut.  We need to feed them, insure them and support them.  We have the team to make this work.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are unable to donate to our campaign, we would appreciate your help in getting the word out about our show and campaign and tell your friends about the shows in Brattleboro, VT and New Haven, CT!  THANK YOU

story:
The Baffling Adventures of Question-Mark Man is an exciting upcoming Edinburgh Fringe show that needs your help.

We've now entered phase two of fundraising, check out our new trailer!

The show is a lighthearted family-friendly comedy that follows the baffling superhero Question-Mark Man and his amnesic side-kick Forgotten Boy in a series of hilarious adventures. Taking inspiration from the Marvel Films, the 1960s Batman and Robin and a variety of comic book tropes, this show features physical comedy, word play and crazy characters played by a talented cast. 

We're up in Edinburgh for two weeks, from the 15th to the 27th of August at 12:00. Our venue is The Space on the Mile venue located at Radisson Blu, 80 High Street, Edinburgh, EH1 1TH.

Produced by Bottled Spider Productions, this upcoming production has all the right ingredients for a comic success at Edinburgh and we hope your generosity will help us wow the Fringe-goers.  

Here's a little bit about us as a theatre company: Bottled Spider Productions is an emerging theatre company dedicated to producing new work and revitalising classic works with a contemporary focus. Based in Norwich, Bottled Spider boasts an array of Fringe experience, and we believe we have the skills and experience to make our latest show a hit success. Both our director and writer were involved in a show in last year's fringe and we want to utilise this experience, and a pool of skilled actors from the University of East Anglia to create a five-star show.

It is our goal to bring an engaging, funny and poignant show to the Edinburgh Fringe this year and set a foundation for Bottled Spider to expand into more ambitious projects.

Your money will go towards Fringe Registration costs, venue hire and accommodation whilst in Edinburgh. It will also fund important theatrical elements such as costume, set and make-up, helping this promising project fufill its potential. Your support will allow an emerging theatre company to develop into a home of consistently excellent theatre for years to come.

We can also offer a set of exclusive rewards to generous individuals who are willing to help us out, including a DVD of the show that will be filmed in Edinburgh in front of a live audience and many other exciting gifts.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read our pledge, please share the word and give generously, every pound will be cherished. We look forward to seeing you in Edinburgh!

Fond regards, 

Alec Mann and Scott Younger

 (Director and Writer of The Baffling Adventures of Question-Mark Man.)

story:
Welcome to our Campaign!


Who are we? 

We are a group of local actors who have formed the new, not-for-profit Haberdashery Theatre Company in Vancouver, BC. Our founding members (in alphabetical order) are John Cassini, Stephen Lobo, Jenn MacLean Angus, Brian Markinson, Lori Triolo and Kyra Zagorsky. We plan for this company to evolve over time to include new members: actors, directors, producers and writers who share our vision. 

The First Show

We are thrilled to announce that the Firehall Arts Centre is presenting our inaugural production, the Vancouver premiere of The Motherf**ker with the Hat, written by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Stephen Adly Guirgis. This award-winning play is a powerful piece of writing that deals with addiction, recovery, betrayal and loyalty. 

"This is by far the most accomplished and affecting work from the gifted Mr. Guirgis, a prolific and erratic chronicler of marginal lives." - Ben Brantley, The New York Times

"This whirlwind of a dark comedy does indeed have passion of Shakespearean intensity." - Christopher Rawson, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

Previews start January 16, 2016. 

Opening night is January 20, 2016. 

Check out our Gallery for photos of the cast!

Our Goal

Launching with The Motherf**ker with the Hat, we endeavour to produce contemporary and socially relevant plays, adding our voice to the Vancouver theatre scene by bringing independent productions - usually seen in smaller black box theatre - to larger audiences. 

How do we do that? 

  • By bringing the highest possible production value we can offer to our audience in regards to set design, lighting, music, cast, etc. 
  • By using social media to engage and invite more people to become theatre goers. 
  • Our ultimate goal is to get bums in seats for this play and the next. And the next after that. Audience attendance enriches our local art scene and the culture of our community.

Why are we doing this?

Because Theatre Matters.

We deeply believe there is no other experience like going to the theatre. Audiences hear the words of great playwrights and, most importantly, play an essential part by bearing witness to these stories. It is an event that is recorded only in memory and that is firmly rooted in the here and now. It exists only in that moment - where one can feel the molecules in the air change - in that sacred space shared by the actor and the audience.

How you can help

Any contribution is appreciated! We have some great incentives in the perks over to the right, to sweeten the pot and a portion of all donations will go to an organization that provides assistance with addiction, recovery and mental illness in Vancouver's DTES (Downtown Eastside).

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute in a monetary way, but you can still help! 

  • Please help us get the word out by telling your friends about our campaign.
  • Help create some buzz for us on Facebook and Twitter.
  • Share this Indiegogo campaign using this link or the links below.
  • Share the link to purchase tickets directly for the show.

We hope you can join us on our journey to bring this and more great plays to life and keep theatre going strong in Vancouver.

Thanks!

Haberdashery Theatre Co.

story:
MiniTHEATER   |   MiniTEATRO 

ABOUT US

Artefactus Cultural Project is a non-profit corporation, which began operations since March 2008. It currently has its own headquarters, located southwest of the city of Miami, in the United States. The corporation aims to research, production and promotion of theater, dance, music, film, visual arts, literature and other forms of non-traditional art, with emphasis on Hispanic culture. Its programs focus on the development of these areas, for which maintains programs as Artefactus Theatre, Artefactus Gallery and Artefactus Press, among others, being at this time the most solid choice for entertainment, recreation and artistic training for this community. The organization also promotes intercultural and international exchanges; also conducts workshops, meetings, conferences and festivals in the interest of promoting arts education, critical and creative thinking, and multicultural values ​​of the city of Miami.

ABOUT MiniTHEATER PROJECT

MiniTheater is a program of learning and artistic creation, aimed at children between 7-12 years; a small laboratory where children, led by specialists, learn to create their own stories and represent them on stage. The workshop encourages the child's participation in the creation of texts, songs, elements of costumes, props and set, among others.

This laboratory combines theoretical and practical lessons, in an atmosphere of creativity and play. It focuses on 4 specific areas: "Creative Writing": to hear stories and create narratives, songs and poems; "Body Language and Performance": to play with the body, the space and the characters; "Music and Dance": training to make music with the body and instruments, and for singing and dancing; "Forms and Space": instructions for building puppets, masks, costumes and set elements; and "The Game of Representation": where all parties come together in a show, built as if it were a fun puzzle.

The project is designed for periods of 2 months, with sessions of 3 hours per week. Two periods (March-April and July-August) will run on 2016 and a maximum of 20 students will be accepted for each period. Project staff consists of 1 director, 1 assistant and 5 professional in the areas of music, acting, dance, visual arts and literature. The show will last 60 minutes approx. and 4 presentations will be made.

MiniTheater will be developed at the headquarters of Artefactus, which features a 60 seats theater room, a reception area and an art gallery. This cultural space located in West Kendall.

The project total cost is $30,000.00 and will be conducted with funds from private organizations, friends of ARTEFACTUS and contribution of the Knight Foundation. This project was nominated for the People's Choice Award (Knight Foundation) and received the Knight Arts Challenge Award of this Foundation in November 2015.

HOW WE WILL USE THE MONEY

The money contributed will be used to supplement the payment of the professionals involved in this project. The team of selected teachers stands out for its extensive experience in working directly with children and for children; in addition they have academic studies in each of their specialties. Most of the teachers have degrees obtained Superior Institute of Art in Havana, Nova Southeastern University and University of Lima, among others.

Also we will allocate some of these funds for the purchase of materials and items such as cardboard, paperboard, paper and fabrics, among others, to be used in the preparation of masks, puppets, accessories of characters and complements of theatrical device, to turn the show into a large showcase, where can be seen the performances and art objects created by children, like pieces of a museum.

IMPACT

The MiniTheater Project will have a positive impact on the city of Miami, and especially on children and families in our community.

MiniTheater promotes theater values and its contribution to the integral formation of the individual. The participants will acquire skills and knowledge about theater, dance, music and literature, among other arts. Also will develop their artistic and creative skills while reaffirming identity and self-esteem; enhance the cultural heritage and the humanistic values; learn to work in team and  practice solidarity and respect for diversity; and finally recognize that their work is useful for their small environment and their community.

MiniTheater promotes theater values
and its contribution to the integral formation of the individual. The
participants will acquire skills and knowledge about theater, dance, music and
literature, among other arts. Also will develop their artistic and creative
skills while reaffirming identity and self-esteem; enhance the cultural
heritage and the humanistic values; learn to work in team and  practice solidarity and respect for
diversity; and finally recognize that their work is useful for their small
environment and their community.

story:
We are a team of artists that come from many different fields of the performing arts. Our team includes actors, dancers, musicians, visual artists and more.

In the context of the Greek crisis we practise 'urban farming’. We dig into the stories, experiences and history of an area to create a meaningful work of art. We have left the traditional theatre in order to explore and harness the potential of using alternative urban spaces as the sites of our performance.


In October 2015 we created a site-specific performance on the streets of Dourgouti, an area of Athens with a rich history of immigration, refugees and resistance.

Our team spent 18 months in Dourgouti researching and gathering information from residents and archives about the area that was once full of makeshift refugee huts. Huts, which had no foundation....

Armed with the stories of the neighbourhood, 40 performers (from both Greece and abroad) invited by the theatre group «Ohi Pezoume» climbed onto roofs and terraces, entered courtyards, crammed into corners and opened the doors of derelict shops. We made the spaces of Dourgouti our own, at least for a little while. We turned 25 of these spaces into the sites of our performance. We took our audience on small journeys between these points where they watched and interacted with the performers.

Our Aim

Our aim is to put on a new performance in Dourgouti, which will run throughout September 2016. The performance will include new actions, live art and the further exploration of the different spaces of the neighbourhood. We hope to enrich our performance and the neighbourhood by including more points of interaction, more collaborators and continuing to meet and work with local residents.

How can you help us?

If there is no possibility of a financial contribution you can still help us by sharing and promoting our campaign.

Είμαστε μια ομάδα καλλιτεχνών προερχόμενοι από πολλά διαφορετικά πεδία των παραστατικών τεχνών: ηθοποιοί, χορευτές, μουσικοί, εικαστικοί, κ.α.

 Στην Ελλάδα της κρίσης κάνουμε farming. Το θέατρο φεύγει από τη θεατρική σκηνή για να ανακαλύψει και να αξιοποιήσει τη δυναμική εναλλακτικών χώρων-σημείων μέσα στην πόλη.

Τον Οκτώβριο του 2015, δημιουργήσαμε μια περιπατητική παράσταση με πεδίο τους δρόμους του Δουργουτίου, μια γειτονιά της Αθήνας με ιδιαίτερη προσφυγική, αγωνιστική και μεταναστευτική ιστορία. "Καταλάβαμε" τον χώρο που κάποτε είχαν οι παράγκες των προσφύγων.
Οι παράγκες που δεν είχαν θεμέλια...

Με εφόδιο τις ιστορίες της γειτονιάς, 40 συντελεστές (performers), από την Ελλάδα και το εξωτερικό, προσκεκλημένοι της θεατρικής ομάδας «Όχι Παίζουμε», ανεβήκαμε στις ταράτσες, μπήκαμε στις αυλές, χωθήκαμε σε γωνιές, ανοίξαμε πόρτες εγκαταλελειμμένων κτηρίων και κάναμε αυτό το μέρος δικό μας έστω και για λίγο.

Φτιάξαμε σύντομα ταξίδια, συναντώντας τους θεατές σε 25 διαφορετικά σημεία της γειτονιάς.

Ο στόχος μας

Μια νέα παράσταση τον ερχόμενο Σεπτέμβριο του 2016 στο Δουργούτι που θα περιλαμβάνει νέα δράσεις, liveart, ανασχεδιασμό των διαδρομών στο χώρο και εμπλουτισμό αυτών με νέα σημεία συνάντησης και διάδρασης με τι θεατές, περισσότερους συντελεστές και συνάντηση εκ νέου με τι κατοίκους ..

Πώς μπορείς να μας βοηθήσεις;

·  Φτιάξαμε αυτή την καμπάνια, ώστε να συλλέξουμε το ποσό που χρειάζεται για να ξαναγυρίσουμε στη γειτονιά που τόσο αγαπήσαμε και με νέα διάθεση να επαναλάβουμε την παράσταση μας.

·  Αν, ωστόσο, δεν υπάρχει η δυνατότητα για οικονομική συνεισφορά, μπορείτε να βοηθήσετε κοινοποιώντας την καμπάνια μας...

Εναλλακτικός τρόπος συνεισφοράς  παρέχεται μέσω του διαθέσιμου τραπεζικού λογαριασμού με τα παρακάτω στοιχεία:
Επωνυμία: ΟΧΙ ΠΑΙΖΟΥΜΕ 
ΙΒΑΝ: GR0601401550155002101078667
ΤΡΑΠΕΖΑ: ALPHA BANK

story:
The Story

You have watched the 200th episode and hummed along a thousand times, lamenting the fact that there wasn’t more of it and imagining you could watch a full production with all-new, all-original, all-Supernatural songs. Well… It's here -  the parody musical theatre event all Supernatural fans have been waiting for! Come see John and Mary be terrible parents! Come see Sam attempt to be “Totally Normal”! Come see Dean eat pie and fall in love with the Impala! Come see Cas not get any references! Come see Azazel sing about his plans in a jazz number! All original songs, dance numbers and plot twists you will never suspect (although no alien robots in the second act)!

Get to know us better by watching the bloopers below!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fl4cebdMlGg&feature=youtu.be

About us

Coven Cat Productions is a brand new amateur theatre company, based in Edinburgh. It is the bigger, better and more international heir of our director’s first company which started operating 13 years ago in a small Eastern European country and has put on more than ten original musicals, promoting fresh ideas and winning awards at local festivals. We are big fans of the USA-based StarKid and we’re aiming at delivering the same level of music, comedy and heartfelt messages. Coven Cat Productions has brought together theatre enthusiasts from the UK and the rest of Europe, as well as the USA, many of them with years of experience on and behind the stage. Supernatural: The Parody Musical will be our very first production as a team and we are aiming high! Your contribution will let us bring this new musical to life at one of the world's largest and most prestigious performing arts festivals. Don’t Sam and Dean deserve that?


What We Need & What You Get

Our team consists primarily of students and bringing a show to the Fringe costs an amount of money we couldn’t possibly afford without your contribution. We need to raise at least $6000 in order to cover the cost of our venue for the festival and the bare minimum of props and tech. Everything above that target will allow us to bring you a better live experience and a much better recording for those of you who will be watching us online. In return, you will get to watch and participate in something you cannot find anywhere else. You will be part of a loving tribute to fantastic show which deserves for its universe to be expanded and for its fans to have more ways to enjoy the characters. We have some really great perks as a reward for supporting us! 


Why Should You Support Us?

Supernatural: The Parody Musical was created by, and stars, fans of the show. Our goal is to bring the key themes of the show – friendship, brotherhood, loyalty (and of course, cute actors) – into a new form. If you love the show, our musical will not disappoint. It’s funny, dramatic and touching in equal measure, and our actors aim to bring new life to their characters while also staying true to the core of their personalities in the TV show. We hope you’re as excited about this as we are, and give us a chance to show you just how brilliant a Supernatural musical can be by supporting us in any way you can. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on Facebook! Follow us on Tumblr and Twitter! Share and reblog! Tell your friends! Talk about us and comment on what we're doing! Basically, make sure everyone knows about us. Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

The Rose Grew Here Productions is a new and budding production company with the goal of helping young writers bring their stories to life. The organization is currently fundraising for it's first season. This includes Candyland  by Harold Hodge, which will premiere in December and a full production and film screening in the spring. Submissions of original plays and screenplays will be accepted in November to be selected for production.

For more information, check out our website:

http://www.therosegrewhereproductions.com/

What We Need & What You Get

We are taking donations to go towards the production budget of all three of our first season's productions. This will include space rentals, marketing, costumes, lights, etc.

That's where we need your help! Any contribution, no matter the size, can go a long way and can help ensure the success of the organization. By donating, you are helping provide young artists with a platform to established their voice and an opportunity to have their work produced.   

To show our gratitude, we are offering rewards for certain contributions! Check out our "Perks" page for more information.

Candyland

We are very proud to be kicking off our first season with the Award Winning Play, Candyland. The original piece by Harold Hodge with music and lyrics by Rob Milano, will be directed by Harold Hodge and Madeline DeFreece. Honored with the 1st Place Sarah Willis Award, Candyland is a story of lust, betrayal and a search for identity. Set in a dystopian future where everyone has been put in their “proper place” by an all-powerful Regime, Candyland serves as a cautionary tale of what a world without tolerance and acceptance can become. Make sure to see it in December!

story:
We Seek To Inspire

Public Works Theatre Company, based in Lafayette, Colorado, creates professional shows for family audiences. Our mission is to create new and exuberant theatre for families to engage our wonder, delight, and curiosity.

Our new show, Flight of Fancy, uses cartoon-like full masks and puppets to bring to life two delightful and eccentric characters who meet in a biodome*: one a lonely puffin seeking a friend, the other a thoughtful girl open to adventure by virtue of her curiosity. Set to a music score, a night of adventure in the biodome unfolds with a puppet cast of animal friends. 

*Biodome = cross between a zoo and a natural history museum

You can be a part of our mission to inspire children and adults alike through the magic of live theatre. Our past productions have earned backing from the Jim Henson Foundation, and Fringe Encore Awards in the Boulder International Fringe Festival.

What We Need & What You Get

We've been awarded grants totaling $6,000 from the Boulder County Arts Alliance and the City of Lafayette Cultural Arts Commission - which is great and we are grateful! But that only gets us part of the way there to cover our show's budget. We are seeking to raise an additional $3,000 specifically for the following:

  • Puppet design and creation
  • Set design and creation

We appreciate your help, so we've put together some great rewards for you, including:

  • Public accolades!
  • Tickets to the show!
  • Afternoon tea at East Simpson Coffee Co. with our Artistic Director!
  • An improvised puppet play just for you!
  • Replica of a puppet from the show!
  • Private performance of the show!

Take a look at our perk donation levels and choose one that's right for you!

Our Creative Team

The show was conceived by Sondra Blanchard, Artistic Director of PWTC, but as creative collaboration is at the heart of our theatre company’s process, Flight of Fancy will be developed with artistic associate Claire Patton (Quake Theater), who also performs in the show, and director Meghan Frank. The production also reaches across borders, with masks designed and created by South Carolina-based mask maker Vivian Appler, a professor of theatre at College of Charleston. Public Works Theatre Company is also partnering with Justin Hicks and Katie Webster of Denver-based Incite Productions for puppet making and set design (these amazing artists also build sets and props at the Denver Center for the Performing Arts!)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute (or even if you can), you can make a difference in other ways!

  • Please help us spread the word about our campaign and ask your friends and family to consider donating! Please consider emailing a link to this page to people you think would be interested in supporting this show.
  • Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and any other social media you use!

Show Dates

The show will have its world premiere this April at The Hive (the performance venue at East Simpson Coffee Co.), 414 East Simpson St., Lafayette, Colorado.

Show dates are:
Saturday, April 22 - 11:00 am
Sunday, April 23 - 11:00 am & 2:00 pm
Saturday, April 29 - 11:00 am
Sunday, April 30 - 11:00 am & 2:00 pm

Connect With Us!

Visit our Website!
Like us on Facebook!
Follow us on Twitter!

Thank You for Your Support!!
We'd also like to thank the Boulder County Arts Alliance and the City of Lafayette Cultural Arts Commission for their support.

story:
Hiya! My name is Shelly Hudson. I am the mom of an amazing 14yr daughter and a rockin’ dog named Trouble.  I am a creative entrepreneur with over 20 yrs of experience in arts & nonprofit management. I am also a graduate of Stevens High class of 94.  Go Cardinals!

The arts have been a huge part of my life for as long as I can remember. From taking the stage for the first time at the age of 5 to high school and community theatre and dance. Sadly, like many teens who grew up in the Sullivan County area, the arts experiences were limited and still are today. So I filled the void through involvement in a local nonprofit teen dance club, a hip hop dance team (yep that’s right a hip hop dance team in the 90’s… before it was cool) and community theatre. Yeah… I dig the arts.

Now skip ahead a few years, after going away to college where I majored in theatre at Dean College, I came home eager to share what I had learned. Not too much to my surprise there were still very few options for an outlet and even less willingness from the few local arts groups to bring in an “outsider”. Claremont, the only city in Sullivan County is one of the highest aging communities in the state. Young people are leaving in droves and lack of access to high quality, innovative arts and culture.

That is when Amplified Arts really began…. A thought...an idea.. "What would a space, where artist collaborated, supported and inspired each other to amplify their art, be like?"  A creative hub that included arts education opportunities and an intimate performance space.  At that point in time I had no idea how to make it happen. I just knew I wanted to explore and see where this concept would lead. Lucky for me, this vision led to start of my own nonprofit performing arts studio in Sullivan County where I worked with youth 5 – 21 for 11 successful years producing award winning theatre and film. It also led me to take on the role of executive director of our local Chamber of Commerce where I grew and developed the organization for 5 ½ years. and then informed my decision to move out of the area to an indie cinema in the state’s capital where for the past 4 ½ year I have developed skills in fundraising, programming development, staff & budget management.

I am now ready to bring Amplified Arts to fruition! I am ready to bring this exciting opportunity to my home town!

 So what is Amplified Arts?  Amplified Arts is an arts education and performance hub located in downtown Claremont NH, where artists of all genres create and inspire each other and the greater community through theatre, music, art and film… all under one roof!

Our learning space offers opportunities to learn new skills and find new talents. We will offer classes to support the art we are producing i.e. film editing, voice lessons or directing to name a few as well as host after school arts programming and E (Extended)L(Learning)O(opportunity) for K – College. We will also offer space for private music lessons and jam sessions.

Our performance venue offers locally and regionally produced live music and theatre. We will produce a season of in house semi-professional productions as well as showcase local directors and theatre companies. We will have live music to sharpen the senses that run the spectrum of style and taste.

Our art gallery is a location for artists and art lovers in Sullivan County. We will showcase a different artist each month during which time they will also teach art workshops and talk backs.

Our art house cinema screens film from around the world and across the street. We showcase indie films as well as local projects, cult classics and signature movie events.

What are we up to… Currently we are in phase one of our organizational build out. This includes branding work like our logo and website, producing programming like our first Downtown Movie Night and our upcoming production of The Importance of Being Earnest produced by our early career (13-18yrs) arts program called The Academy.

That is where you come in… We are looking to raise $10,000 to help cover this first phase. The funds will help with the cost of the branding work (our logo) and the needs for the upcoming production (rental, event insurance, printing etc.) Any additional funds raises will go to support phase two: business build out ( Secure our home, set up funds to hire our Producing Artistic Director and produce our first full season of theatre and community events!  

Other Ways You Can Help:

Spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign and Amplified Arts
Find us on Facebook and LinkedIn!
Visit our website - amplifiedartsnh.org
Serve on a committee!
Audition for a show!
Join the board!
Attend an event or show!
Help us raise the curtain on this great community arts resource!

story:
Short Summary

“The Little Black Fish” is one of the most celebrated contemporary children's stories in Iran.  We are producing it for the stage in the United States for the first time because we believe in the power of stories and the importance of producing great art for children. “The Little Black Fish” is a story that has inspired generations of Iranians to dream big and explore new horizons.  Mohammad Aghebati was commissioned by the Crescent Moon Project to produce the play for the celebration of Iranian New Year and we had two successful tryouts in NYC.  There was a lot of interest and children loved the show. We want to bring it to a wider audience by doing a full production, with a magical design that matches the wonders of the story. 

Samad Behrangi's short story is about a fish that lives in a small stream and wants to live a life with aspirations and purpose.  He embarks on an eye-opening journey with the spirit of a dreamer experiencing an awakening, but in the process he does more than that. The path leads him to wisdom, courage, awareness and study of complex social relations. The story of “The Little Black Fish” is a revelation, not just an experience. It is about stepping outside the confines of a self-centered life, and about drawing a distinction between the wandering and the stationary. It has a pedagogic value with numerous underlying political messages and shows a path to freedom, equality and justice, with a simple analogy for younger readers to understand. 


What We Need & What You Get

 We are fundraising to:

  • Complete the design (set, costume, video, light, sound, music) to create a truly magical show for children
  • Rent a theater space in NYC for ten shows and rehearsals
  • Produce a professional video of the show for those unable to attend
  • Pay the artists involved
  • Marketing and promotional work  

We plan to raise $27k by utilizing three fundraising platforms: 

  • Art Auction  ($15,000 goal) First phase is over 
  • Indiegogo ($12,000 goal)
  • Fractured Atlas (our fiscal sponsor and the ONLY TAX-DEDUCTIBLE OPTION)

Our auction is held on our website and is supported by 17 artists who have donated their work for this project.Many of the art works were specifically created with the theme of "The Little Black Fish". After our NYC premiere, we plan to tour nationally by pre-selling the show.  

Make a pledge today via our Art Auction, Indiegogo or Fractured Atlas from the links above. (Fractured Atlas is a 501C3 company and also our fiscal sponsor – that means you can make a tax-deductible contribution.) Any contribution, no matter how small or large, will make a difference. And all contributions will be rewarded but only those through Fractured Atlas are tax-deductible! Please check out the donation tiers to your right to find the level and gift that’s right for you! 


The Impact

The goal of the little Black Fish is to fulfill his ultimate quest: "How will my life or death impact the lives of others?” This iconic story can inspire real change, and encourage children to dream big, think critically, and be a positive change in the world. It is a timely story and our team has produced a mesmerizing play around it that employs music and multimedia to create a unique interactive experience. 


Who We Are

Maaa is a theater group based in New York with the objective of producing new play for young audiences.  

DIRECTOR: Mohammad Aghebati has decades of experience in working for young audiences in his native Iran.  He has received various awards for his plays including the Young Artist Medal of Honor from Iran’s former President Mohammad Khatami. For over a decade, he worked with Leev Theater Group, which is known as one of Iran’s most successful and critically acclaimed theater groups. Several of his works have toured various international festivals. He was selected and commissioned by Japan Foundation to direct a new interpretation of Oedipus Rex. “Hamlet, Prince of Grief” was presented as a part of the Under the Radar Festival at NYC’s Public Theater and received a great review from the New York Times. Since then, it has been presented at BYU, USC, and Ringling Festival. Aghebati is a graduate of Theater Directing at Tehran Art University and was a Special Research Fellow at Yale School of Drama.  His focus on young audiences is inspired by his deep belief in the power of art as an educational tool. 

PRODUCER: Mehrnoush Alia is a filmmaker. She received her MFA in film from Columbia University, and her BA from UC Berkeley.  She has produced over a dozen short films and two of Aghebati’s plays. Her directorial debut Scheherazade has won several awards and screened at over twenty film festivals.  

ACTRESS/MUSICIAN: Melis Aker is an American-born Turkish/Greek/Azeri actor, musician and writer. Her debut EP,Dirt, produced by Ayhan Sahin from Young Pals Music N.Y. Melis is currently based in New York, and will be receiving her MFA in Play/Screen/Lyric Writing from Columbia University.

ACTOR/MUSICIAN: Martin Shamoonpour is a multi-instrumental artist who has played with some of the most recognized underground Iranian music bands.  He has been working in theater over a decade and has collaborated with several prominent Iranian directors.  

ACTOR: Mari Vial-Golden is a Brooklyn based actress and also serves as the Education Associate for the Waterwell Drama Program at the Professional Performing Arts School. Off-Broadway: Pentecost (Atlantic Stage 2); Serious Money (Atlantic Stage 2). Regional: W;t (Triad Stage); Common Enemy (Triad Stage).  EDUCATION: BA, Middlebury College; British American Drama Academy.

Perks Pictures


Tote Bag with the original design of Farshid Mesghali, curtesy of the artist and Nazar Art Publication

Copy of the first official publication of "The Little Black Fish" after the Iranian Revolution of 1979,  signed by Farshid Mesghali, courtesy of Nazar Art Publication. 

NIMANY Lost Bartizan Dress                       NIMANY Secret Jungle Dress 

                                                                              NIMANY Orange Bracelet 


Other Ways You Can Help

· Spread the word by telling your friends, family and social networks about our play and this campaign. Please send the URL of this page with a heartfelt endorsement to everyone you know! "Like" and Share the link on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, by email or blog. Encourage people to follow us. We can be found online here:Facebook, Instagram, Twitter 

· Please join our campaign to tell the world what The Little Black Fish means to you.  It can be a picture, a short story, a work of art, whatever it means to you.  Let’s help the world learn about this inspiring story. 

· If you have other ideas on how to help please contact us!

During our campaign and beyond we will keep you updated on the progress of the play, and we welcome any feedback and comments. Thank you very much for helping us complete this journey!

With much love and gratitude!

Mohammad Aghebati & Mehrnoush Alia

story:
This summer, we're bringing Shapes Like Things, A Soup Play to the New York International Fringe Festival...

that is, if we can pay for it.

About the Play:

Danny’s dad was a scholar of Greek mythology, but Danny couldn’t read. Now Danny’s dad is dead, leaving a legacy of expert opinions and a web of memories for him to sort through. From emerging playwright Emily Sorensen, Shapes Like Things, A Soup Play explores a dyslexic boy’s struggle to connect to his father and the world when words don’t work for him. 


Shapes Like Things, A Soup Play is a new play brought to you by the playwright-director duo The Seedlings.


THE TEAM:

Written by Emily Sorensen

Directed by Alexis Wilcock

Set and projection design by Elsa GibsonBraden

Original music and sound design by Danny Tejera

Costume design by Rachel Sherman-Presser

Artwork by Remy Kass

and starring Leo DeFriend as Danny


About the Fringe:

We applied to be part of the New York International Fringe Festival this winter, and we were selected to be a part of the festival this April! Doing a production through the NYC Fringe allows us five performances this August in a New York City Fringe-affiliated space. The venues involved are places we have always dreamed of working! This production would be Shapes Like Things, A Soup Play's world premiere. As New York City-based theatre artists, this is the break we've been waiting for in getting our show off the ground, and putting our work in front of the people we want to see it and write about it.


WHAT THE FRINGE FESTIVAL GIVES US:

  • a world-premiere production of Shapes Like Things, A Soup Play
  • five shows in a New York City performance venue
  • a way to get our theatre work out there
  • some community support
WHAT THE FRINGE FESTIVAL DOESN'T GIVE US:
  • Funding (rather, we have to pay fees to be involved)
  • Rehearsal space
  • Actors
  • Production team members
  • Art design fees
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Set materials

What We Need:

We need $5000 (which is what we would obtain after the Indiegogo campaign takes out the service fee) to finance the costs of producing a play in New York ourselves. Every dollar counts toward paying for rehearsal space rental, props, costumes, and our team members' time.


What You Get:

We have several perks we're happy to send as rewards at each giving level, but the greatest product you'll see for your donation is ensuring that our production of Shapes Like Things, A Soup Play comes to life. If we do not reach our $5000 fundraising goal, we will not be able to produce the play; we just don't have the money.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Don't have more than a few dollars to give, but still want to help us out? 

  • SPREAD THE WORD. Tell your friends and share this page! Follow us on Twitter, like us on Facebook. Help us get out there.
  • VOLUNTEER. We need more team members to help us make our show dreams come true. In town in August and want to help us run our box office? Have a car for scenery? Let us know.
  • CONNECT US. Know other people who you think could give us a hand? Send them our way.

Go to ShapesLikeThings.com to contact us directly!


Thank you!

- The Shapes Like Things team

story:
“It’s a great, great human adventure. Imagine having a human being stand up on a platform and mesmerize an audience and sometimes even illuminate something for them. You don’t need machinery. It’s a very primitive art. That’s the beauty of it.”  
 Arthur Miller -- on the art of theater

This is an exciting time for Theater 808 as we prepare to devote our artistic vision, passion and energy to the “great human adventure” of rehearsing Helen Edmundson’s extraordinary play, The Clearing. 

Set against England’s 1652 attempt to solve its “Irish Question” by conducting a ruthless campaign to rid Ireland of the Irish, this powerful play is, at one and the same time, both huge and intimate. Through the struggles in a marriage between a free-spirited Irish lass and an English squire, Edmundson brilliantly illuminates not only our history but our humanity. A truly provocative and relevant work, The Clearing examines our universal desire for acceptance complicated by our innate fear of “the other”.

It is the perfect play for right now, and we are the perfect company to bring it to life. Our bold vision and dedication to truth in art will surely make it sing. We invite you to join us on this adventure!

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

We know in our hearts that giving is good for the soul, and since we were children we have been taught "it is better to give than to receive.” By giving to Theater 808, you get the benefits from both giving and receiving! Your generosity will make it possible for us to bring Helen Edmundson’s extraordinary play, The Clearing  to the first class Off-Broadway theater, 59E59, in a stellar production with the artists and resources we need to create the best possible production for YOU. A production that strives for excellence and reaches the high standards you deserve as our audience and collaborators. Yes, you are our collaborators, for without YOU, our curious and worldly-wise audience of theatergoers and supporters, our work on this stunning and timely play could go unsung. Helen Edmundson has said of her work: “I wouldn’t want someone to leave and not feel they’ve been made to think about the world they are living in.”  What a time it is to do just that!  We invite you to donate now and help start the conversation and ask the questions. Thank you. 

THE IMPACT

Theater 808 is an artist led company dedicated to producing the purest and most provocative interpretations of classic, contemporary and new works by way of a dynamic and deeply connected ensemble. Guided by the message of renowned acting teacher Fred Kareman, the company seeks to foster theater that is organic, spontaneous and alive -never ceasing to strive for excellence in our work. Theater 808 is also deeply committed to supporting other not-for-profits in the community either through monetary donations or affordable opportunities to experience the transformative power of live theater. Learn more about us at www.theater808.org

BE A PART OF 808

Theater 808 is a passionate, growing and vibrant not-for-profit. We welcome students and artists who are interested in internships to visit our website at www.theater808.org and  contact careymacaleer@mac.com. The interns are assigned projects and responsibilities which are vital to our up coming 2016 production of Helen Edmundson's The Clearing  at 59E59. Looking forward to having you join the Theater 808 Team!
story_txt:
“It’s a great, great human adventure. Imagine having a human being stand up on a platform and mesmerize an audience and sometimes even illuminate something for them. You don’t need machinery. It’s a very primitive art. That’s the beauty of it.”  
 Arthur Miller -- on the art of theater

This is an exciting time for Theater
808 as we prepare to devote our artistic vision, passion and energy to the
“great human adventure” of rehearsing Helen Edmundson’s extraordinary
play, The Clearing. 
Set against England’s 1652 attempt to
solve its “Irish Question” by conducting a ruthless campaign to rid Ireland of the
Irish, this powerful play is, at one and the same time, both huge and intimate.
Through the struggles in a marriage between a free-spirited Irish lass and
an English squire, Edmundson brilliantly illuminates not only our history but
our humanity. A truly provocative and relevant work, The Clearing examines
our universal desire for acceptance complicated by our innate fear of “the
other”.
It is the perfect play for right now,
and we are the perfect company to bring it to life. Our bold vision and dedication
to truth in art will surely make it sing. We invite you to join us on this
adventure! 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET


We know in
our hearts that giving is good for the soul, and since we were children we have
been taught "it is better to give than to receive.” By giving to Theater 808,
you get the benefits from both giving and receiving! Your generosity will make
it possible for us to bring Helen Edmundson’s extraordinary play, The Clearing  to the first class Off-Broadway theater, 59E59, in a stellar production with the
artists and resources we need to create the best possible production for YOU. A
production that strives for excellence and reaches the high standards you
deserve as our audience and collaborators. Yes, you are our collaborators, for
without YOU, our curious and worldly-wise audience of theatergoers and
supporters, our work on this stunning and timely play could go unsung. Helen
Edmundson has said of her work: “I wouldn’t want someone to leave and not feel
they’ve been made to think about the world they are living in.”  What a
time it is to do just that!  We invite you to donate now and help start
the conversation and ask the questions. Thank you.

dedicated to producing the purest and most provocative interpretations of
classic, contemporary and new works by way of a dynamic and deeply connected
ensemble. Guided by the message of renowned acting teacher Fred Kareman, the
