story:
Founded in 2000 by Frankie Martinez and Aisha Koswara, the Abakuá Afro Latin Dance Company has strived to break barriers and change the world’s perception of Afro Latin dance. From the conception of full length concert dance pieces, to the production of full length theatrical presentations, Abakuá was able to conquer performance and educational milestones which before had been untouched by Afro Latin dance. 

As the next step in this endeavor, Abakuá is seeking your help in funding a revolutionary film project that will deliver Frankie Martinez's work to the world! In an attempt to preserve this historic work for all time and offer it in a medium that will allow for people from all over the world to enjoy, the Company is setting out on a massive theatrical filming of the entire current and future repertoire. 

This project consists of two phases, which will bring us to our overall goal. "Phase One" consists of the filming of two, full-length half hour pieces, along with several smaller numbers to add as a pilot, costing a total of $10,000. Not only is this a huge financial and physical undertaking for the Company, we are also under massive time restraints, as one of our principal dancers will be moving to the west coast this summer, severely limiting our ability to fulfill this initial phase. 

Your donations towards "Phase One" will go directly towards covering costs for the following: 

1) High quality camera rental, as well as film equipment, lighting and crew.

2) Services of the film maker, for both the filming and editing process.

3) Location rentals and permits.

4) Costume, hair and make up for the dancers during filming. 

The initial $10,000 will produce a finished product to help in our proposal process for seeking and securing government grants and funding to fulfill our larger goal. "Phase Two" will consist of NINE (9!), half hour pieces filmed and made available to a global audience, online! This is an opportunity to deliver the work of this revolutionary choreographer and company to audiences and supporters world wide who have long yearned for access. It also provides us the opportunity to expose those with preconceived notions about Afro Latin dance to the potential of this art form, from the Company who has been trend setters in how Latin dance is showcased, trained and taught. 

The overall cost of the entire project is close to $50,000 and will require almost two years to complete, with releases of individual pieces arriving twice a year. 

Whether you are able to donate financially or simply by spreading word of our campaign, we thank you in helping us make this project a reality! The Abakuá film project is so much more than just an artistic endeavor, it would mark another historic milestone in our movement to bring respect and honor to the cultural treasure of Afro Latin Dance.

Thank you!

story:
Who We Are and Why We Need You...

 

Hi everyone, we are Michelle, Simon, Laura, Michelle, Kayleigh and Jacinta and we are the cast of Viva Hypnosis. The UK's first and (currently the world's) ONLY full-production stage hypnosis show. 

We have been given a once in a lifetime opportunity to take the show all the way over to Adelaide Fringe to make it's Australian debut.

We are completely self-funded and have currently built up the money to pay for our venue hire, marketing etc. As you can imagine, it's the most expensive venture for the team we have embarked on. And your contribution will go to fund the most important part of our venture - actually getting our team there. 

This could mean huge things for the show and for the cast ourselves. Not only do we get to open up a brand new audience base for the show, we get to perform the show we love and are all extremely proud of in a totally new continent, with a whole host of important people there to see it and help us move the show to the next level.

 

BUT this venture is not entirely selfish...We ALSO, have a very special agenda for getting out there. 

 

ALL of our profit from our ticket sales for the entire month we are out there, will go directly to a VERY special charity close to our hearts.

So by helping US, you're also helping someone in real need...and here's how...

 

Why Is This Campaign VERY Different? What Impact Will You Have?...

Please Read On...
 

Ok, so Viva Hypnosis is indeed ground-breaking in the way that it is the UK's first and ONLY full-production Stage Hypnosis Show. It's all about the team and the show as a whole - being an entire sensory experience for everyone = it's definitely not just one guy with 12 chairs. We've broken the mold. We've started to 'redefine' comedy hypnotism.

But for a crowd-funding effort, although it will be the first of it's kind to go to Australia where we are flying the flag for the UK (they are very fond of hypnosis over there and this could really take off!) we might not have a very (what's deemed) 'worthy' show, in the sense that it doesn't explore deep profound ideas, tackle important deep issues or make strong political statements...

It is entertainment for entertainment's sake. Inclusive comedy for escapism and whole-hearted laughter. And for the people on stage - an opportunity into another part of their mind. Where they feel completely relaxed and not worry about anything - they just HAVE FUN. 

Now if there was ever a time (particularly politically) to arguably justify the indulging in a bit of fun-for-all-the-family, light-hearted, good for you, escapist entertainment - it's now. 

But here's the thing. 

WE ARE worthy people. Simon, Myself and the rest of the team. We do a lot to help charities that we care about and nothing means more to us than helping others. 

So, by you helping us achieve our goals. We are going to make sure that we do something to help someone else. 

Someone who was there at the very beginning of Simon's career as a Stage Hypnotist.

 

A close friend of Simon's, Dominic Bergin, now at only 34 years old, has been given only 6 months to a year to live.

Here's a little more about his story...

From Dom: "I was diagnosed with Stage 2 Bowel cancer back in February 2014. I had two tumours in my large intestine which was removed in one go to take them away and hopefully stop it spreading elsewhere. I now have a permanent ileostomy. I was then given a 6 month course of Capecitabine Chemotherapy to help eradicate any other cancer cells. 

All seemed to be going well until March last year when I started to experience some different symptoms, tests were done but no sign of the cancer returning was found. 

In August 2015 I had a second operation to remove the rectal stump and make the ileostomy permanent, during the operation they had found that the cancer had returned and was attached to the rectal stump and had also grown into the bladder wall. 

This was now Stage 4 Secondary Bowel Cancer, it had also spread to the omentum and an area near my pelvis. Due to them finding this they were unable to complete the operation.

Once I was healed from the failed operation I was put on a new more intensive Chemotherapy of Folfiri regime, this seemed to be working and shrinking the tumour. Since March when the treatment cycle finished I have been off all treatment and the Stage 4 Secondary Bowel Cancer has now spread to my bones in my pelvis and also near the coccyx.  The treatment offered in the UK is pointless as i will die either way. So my only option is to come to Germany to have advanced immunotherapy that can save my life."

Dom has now started treatment at the Hallwang Clinic in Germany and it is all looking very promising, each day there is great news coming from patients that are also having targeted lifesaving cancer treatments there and gives everyone a great boost and there is a great atmosphere here amongst all staff and patients.

We want you to help us to help Dom continue his treatment in Germany.

Simon met Dom back in 2008 , his first season as a Stage Hypnotist, they worked together for many years in Greece and have stayed friends for years.

Simon was gutted to hear about Dom’s cancer as he had always been a fit and sporty bloke and promised to do something to raise funds for Dom’s treatment in Germany.

And this is it.

 

Once we get to Australia ALL OF OUR PROFITS from ticket sales will go directly to Dominic's campaign to help him get the life-saving treatment he needs and deserves. 
 

That's the deal. You help us get there. Once we get there - all of our profits from our ticket sales go directly to helping Dominic's campaign. 

And we've already started to sell tickets - (as well as hypnosis being very popular in Australia, we've always been popular before and sold out shows many times...) So this this could potentially add up to a lot for Dominic's treatment.

(And we will of course keep you updated on this as we go). 

We hope that's fair karma. And a fair exchange for your generosity to us. 

If you are interested in Dominic's story and would like to learn more about his journey, please visit his Go Fund Me page here: https://www.gofundme.com/doit4dom where we'd also love to encourage you to donate directly to his campaign directly too.

 

And As An Extra Thank You For Helping Us, We Also Have Some AMAZING Perks For You Too To Say Thanks! There Are Tonnes To Choose From...
 

We have some amazing perks for you. Including: 

- Private Hypnosis Masterclass with Simon
- Dance lessons with the girls
- Your own private Viva Hypnosis show
- Hypnotherapy tracks
- Signed posters
- Free tickets
- Bottles of custom bubbly
- Cases of Fosters
- Simon hypnotising anyone of your choice
- Koloa adoption packages
- Some tacky Australian chintz
- A Skype date with Jacinta's puppy
- And even a trip to Australia to see us perform there!

And more, more, more...

(Keep scrolling and looking down the right hand side to check out all of our perks you can choose from!)

Do check out the list, there are some funny perks, some amazing perks and some once-in-a-lifetime opportunities....
 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please help us spread the word - every share gets us more of a chance of making this happen AND means that we can go out there, do what we love AND raise money for a very special man and friend of Simon's whilst out there. Please help us make a difference.

Thank you for reading.

story:
UPDATE: This campaign officially ended on February 24th after raising $375. To make additional donations to help offset future productions costs, please visit https://www.gofundme.com/myzkky-an-energy-tale-....

 

About Me

My name is Anthony J. Piccione. I am a playwright originally from Connecticut and currently living in New York City. Last year in May, I received my BA in Theatre, with minors in Writing and Film Studies, from Eastern Connecticut State University. My many loves and passions include scriptwriting, theatre, film, poetry, music, blogging, volunteerism, politics, history, painting, cooking and more. I also have dealt with episodes of depression, social anxiety, and a high functioning form of autism called Asperger’s syndrome during my life. However, I’ve tried my best to overcome each of these things to ensure that I’m still able to do the things in life that I love, and hopefully break a few stereotypes that are still surrounding all people with ASD along the way.

I have already been lucky enough to have had some success in NYC. My one-act play The End of the Line at the End received its world premiere at Manhattan Repertory Theatre in October 2016, and my one-act play Two Cousins and a Pizza is scheduled to premiere at the Hudson Guild Theatre - as part of the Winterfest Theatre Festival - in February 2017. Before that, I had many other short plays produced at my college and at other Connecticut venues. I am hoping that the rest of 2017 and beyond will bring me even more success, and that I will be able to build on what I've already begun with my career as a playwright.

To learn more about me, you can visit my personal blog: www.anthonyjpiccione.tumblr.com

About The Play

An Energy Tale is a one-act children's play that aims to educate youth on the potential impact of climate change, in a way that is both fun and informative.

The play takes place in the year 2184, when the world is far different than it is in our time. While a young boy named Jimmy is sitting around and juggling rocks - the only mildly fun hobby left to do on Earth - he is encountered by a mysterious man known as Dr. Science. With Jimmy and Dr. Science, the audience is transported back to the past - to our present - to learn about how many important decisions being made today, from fuel sources to politics, have affected Jimmy's world...our future.

The play was written during my last semester of college for an assignment in my Scriptwriting class. That same semester, it became a finalist in the 2016 CT "Wright the World" playwriting contest, and ultimately finished in 2nd place.

The Goal Of This Campaign

This year, I am hoping to have the chance to finally bring this play to life as a full-production during the summer. I am excited to have the opportunity to potentially bring this play to Midtown International Theatre Festival - one of the most popular Off-Off-Broadway theatre festivals in New York City - this July and August. However, Midtown International Theatre Festival requests that playwrights put forward a minimum amount of funds upfront in order to be accepted, as part of their Profit Sharing Policy. Therefore, I have decided to start this campaign to help secure the minimum funds needed to be able to persue this opportunity.

What We Need & Impact

The goal of this campaign is to raise at least $337. That is the bare minimum amount that is needed to be paid, in order to participate in the festival. We will also be in need of additional funds raised beyond that will be used toward funding extra aspects of the production such as additional rehearsal space, costuming and set pieces, publicity materials, etc.

Remember that every dollar raised will help make a difference in achieving this goal, so even a small amount would be much appreciated!

Aside from anything to do with me, I believe that this play carries a message that deserves to be heard not just by kids, but by everyone who cares about the future of our world. I know some might question whether or not kids should be treated to an educational play that tackles a serious issue such as this, but I believe if ANYONE at all has the right to know about these issues, it's kids. They are the ones who will ultimately be affected by this issue in the long-term, and I believe that they need to be taught about these issues and the potential consequences so that they can know how to deal with them.

If you agree with me, that's just more of a reason for me to encourage you to chip in!  By donating to this project, you'll be increasingly the likelihood that this show has a chance to be produced in a fantastic venue, and in a festival that is well-attended each year, thus increasing the odds that more people will have the chance to see the message in the play that I speak of. The only way that can happen, though, is if we get the funds necessary.

Risks and Challenges

To those reading this, what I can promise is this: When I start a big project like this, I never give up on it, and I'm always determined to see it through. I think anyone who's followed me and my artistic endeavors over the past few years knows that much about me. That is especially the case for this project, which is one of my personal favorite plays that I've written today, in large part because of the message that it carries. If you donate to this project, I can assure you that I will do everything that I can to make sure that this play is produced, and any funds I receive here will go toward making that a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Beyond donating, there are other ways that you can help fund this project. After reading this, I hope you can share this to your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc. Indiegogo includes several of its own features that make sharing with others easy, so be sure to check those out!

Also, once the play does finally make its world premiere, I hope you'll be able to join us for the show in NYC! I promise you that when it happens, it will be one to remember!

I hope you will please donate to this project, and that you will share it with as many of your friends, family, acquaintances, etc. as you possibly can! Thank you for your interest, and I can't wait to have the chance to start work on this play! :)

This year, I am hoping to have the chance to finally bring this play to life as a full-production during the summer. I am excited to have the opportunity to potentially bring this play to Midtown International Theatre Festival - one of the most popular Off-Off-Broadway theatre festivals in New York City - this July and August. However, Midtown International Theatre Festival requests that playwrights put forward a minimum amount of funds upfront in order to be accepted, as part of their Profit Sharing Policy. Therefore, I have decided to start this campaign to help secure the minimum funds needed to be able to persue this opportunity.
What We Need & Impact
The goal of this campaign is to raise at least $337. That is the bare minimum amount that is needed to be paid, in order to participate in the festival. We will also be in need of additional funds raised beyond that will be used toward funding extra aspects of the production such as additional rehearsal space, costuming and set pieces, publicity materials, etc.
Remember that every dollar raised will help make a difference in achieving this goal, so even a small amount would be much appreciated!
Aside from anything to do with me, I believe that this play carries a message that deserves to be heard not just by kids, but by everyone who cares about the future of our world. I know some might question whether or not kids should be treated to an educational play that tackles a serious issue such as this, but I believe if ANYONE at all has the right to know about these issues, it's kids. They are the ones who will ultimately be affected by this issue in the long-term, and I believe that they need to be taught about these issues and the potential consequences so that they can know how to deal with them.
If you agree with me, that's just more of a reason for me to encourage you to chip in!  By donating to this project, you'll be increasingly the likelihood that this show has a chance to be produced in a fantastic venue, and in a festival that is well-attended each year, thus increasing the odds that more people will have the chance to see the message in the play that I speak of. The only way that can happen, though, is if we get the funds necessary.
Risks and Challenges
To those reading this, what I can promise is this: When I start a big project like this, I never give up on it, and I'm always determined to see it through. I think anyone who's followed me and my artistic endeavors over the past few years knows that much about me. That is especially the case for this project, which is one of my personal favorite plays that I've written today, in large part because of the message that it carries. If you donate to this project, I can assure you that I will do everything that I can to make sure that this play is produced, and any funds I receive here will go toward making that a reality.
Other Ways You Can Help
Beyond donating, there are other ways that you can help fund this project. After reading this, I hope you can share this to your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc. Indiegogo includes several of its own features that make sharing with others easy, so be sure to check those out!
Also, once the play does finally make its world premiere, I hope you'll be able to join us for the show in NYC! I promise you that when it happens, it will be one to remember!
I hope you will please donate to this project, and that you will share it with as many of your friends, family, acquaintances, etc. as you possibly can! Thank you for your interest, and I can't wait to have the chance to start work on this play! :)

story:
Cet hiver, le Collectif Rêver en couleurs présentera À L'AFFICHE, la première traduction québécoise de la pièce The Flick, d'Annie Baker, récipiendaire du Prix Pulitzer 2014 en théâtre. 

Où? Au Théâtre Premier Acte // Quand? Du 25 février au 14 mars 2020

https://www.premieracte.ca/programmation/2019-2020/affiche-111.html

 

DESCRIPTION DU PROJET 

Dans une salle de cinéma en piteux état, l’une des dernières à posséder encore un projecteur de films en 35 mm, trois jeunes employés sous-payés s’affairent à nettoyer la place. Dans les intervalles entre les séances de projection de films, au milieu des allées jonchées de déchets et de popcorn, Sam, Avery et Rose apprennent à se connaître en échangeant un small talk, de manière décousue et par à-coups. Ils ont besoin de parler de leur amour des films pour arriver à parler d’eux-mêmes. 

Alors qu’on voue une fascination parfois extrême aux acteurs et actrices du grand écran, dans À l’Affiche, ce sont plutôt ces anti-héros qui nous captivent. Ce sont eux qui sont « à l’affiche » au Théâtre Premier Acte. Ce sont des âmes solitaires aux tourments silencieux qui craignent de se retrouver à la traîne dans une société qui valorise le progrès à tout prix. La transition numérique que traverse le monde du cinéma fait écho à ce que ces personnages vivent : Comment s’inscrire dans notre monde moderne en constante et rapide évolution tout en restant vrai à soi-même? Comment savoir qu’on touche à la vérité – dans la vie, dans nos propres réponses émotionnelles, dans nos rapports avec les autres?

À l'Affiche, c'est plus qu'une comédie dramatique : c'est une expérience d'hyperréalisme théâtral! C’est humain, touchant, drôle, surprenant et pertinent dans le contexte de notre société où tout va toujours trop vite.

 

MERCI DE VOTRE SOUTIEN!!

Il s'agit de la première production de notre Collectif et nous en sommes très fiers.ères! Votre soutien est inestimable, chaque dollar compte! Les fonds amassés serviront à financer la location de locaux de répétition, l'achat de matériaux pour la construction de notre décor (une vraie de vraie salle de cinéma, avec les bancs et tout!), les cachets des membres de l'équipe ainsi que la publicité pour faire connaître notre projet. 

*** Nous avons pensé à vous !

En échange de vos dons, vous trouverez, à droite de l'écran,

des petites surprises amusantes gracieusement offertes

par nos partenaires et commanditaires.***

 

QUI SOMMES-NOUS?

Le Collectif Rêver en couleurs renferme des artistes professionnels, majoritairement de la relève, issus du milieu du théâtre de Québec et de Montréal. Nous nous sommes rassemblés parce que nous étions animés du désir de porter à la scène un texte contemporain criant d’actualité avec la volonté d’estomper les barrières linguistiques, sociales et raciales dans la pratique de l’art théâtral.  

  • Traduction et mise en scène : Angélique Patterson
  • Distribution : Patrick Émmanuel Abellard, Catherine Côté, Jean-Philippe Côté, Charles Fournier
  • Concepteurs : Mathieu C. Bernard (éclairages), Maude Groleau (décor), Mélanie Robinson (costumes), Vincent Kearney-Deschênes (environnement sonore)
  • Assistance à la mise en scène : David Boily

 

REMERCIEMENTS : Melanie Robinson, le Théâtre du Trident, À Double Tour, Sebz Thé et Lounge, Première Ovation

story:
From Left to Right: Sammi Richardson, Courtney Mentzel, Shaquille Nelson, and Jen Marinelli

Hello! We are the Fab Four, an ensemble of 4 actors finishing up the last year of our MFA in Acting program at Brooklyn College and we're looking for backers to help fund our Spring Showcase! 

This year, the Brooklyn College MFA Acting class will be conducting an entirely virtual innovative, two-pronged approach to our showcase: we will be creating professionally filmed original scenes highlighting our unique talents and personalities, as well as professionally producing an online theatrical showcase to broadcast to industry professionals in late March/early April 2021. Together, these two components serve as our official introduction to the professional film, TV, and theatre world as well as the culmination of two years of rigorous study and practice. 

All of your generous donations will be funding the following:

  • Production costs (This includes filming equipment, editing, and location fees): $5,000 
  • Headshots: $3,000 

Any leftover funds will be given as a gift towards next year's MFA Acting showcase.

We welcome and are forever grateful for any and all contributions! We know 2020 has been a rough year for many. So, if you can't give, don't fret! Please help us out by sharing this campaign on social media and spread the word!

Thank you all so much for your love and support!

Many thanks,

The Fab Four (Sammi, Courtney, Shaq, and Jen)

story:
Help us create Othello Online!

 

The women behind Momentum Acts… an origin story

Dana Day and Naledi Withers met on their MA Performing Shakespeare course at Bath Spa University. Coming from backgrounds in theatre and dance it only seemed right that they would partner up for projects. These ladies worked together for the first two trimesters of their course and decided to finish their MA together. Feeling inspired during an online lecture with a local theatre director, a text message was sent:

“Want to start a company?”

Momentum Acts was born.

 

What is Momentum Acts?

Momentum Acts is an interdisciplinary Shakespearean theatre company. We make Shakespeare more approachable for people of all ages by combining his work with dance and physical theatre. Created in the height of the pandemic we strive to create interactive shows in unconventional places and continue to develop and adapt ourselves as artists to thrive in the face of challenges. 

 

What is Othello Online?

Othello Online is Momentum Acts’ first  immersive digital experience in which we are exploring the creation of a new social media performance form. It tells the well known story of Shakespeare’s Othello and enables you to follow the story of jealousy and greed as it builds through updates and posts across multiple social media platforms. You will be able to explore the profiles and pages and engage with the show, in your own way at your own pace, for as long as you wish!

 

Where you come in!

We need you to help us make this dream into a reality! 

 

With this campaign we are raising money for the initial development of our first digital project. The first phase of this project is 3 weeks of rehearsal and 1 week of recording with a cast of 5-7 actors. If we hit our minimum target of £3000 you will enable us to pay our cast at least £10 an hour.

 

At a time when the performance industry and freelance workers are struggling it is important to us to be able to provide fellow creatives with a fair wage for their time and skill, as well as providing an opportunity to continue working creatively. 

Your donations, no matter the size, will go towards paying our hard working actors.

 

If we exceed our minimum target the money will go towards the second phase of the project including the hiring of a professional video editor.



 

What you can get out of it

We are offering a wide range of rewards for different donation sizes.

A thank you message from our founders (£5)

Shout out on Social Media (£10) 

Invite to be a member of our preview Audience (£20) 

A virtual Hug from cast and a hand drawn picture of your favorite character (it may not be good) (£30) 

Have a character post about/with you in the show (£40) 

A little bit of everything (£75) 

 

Can’t afford to donate? That’s okay!

We ask that you share this crowd funder with whoever you can! Follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter just search @momentumacts. To learn more about us and what we have going on check out our website momentumacts.com and sign up to our newsletter. 

 

Thank you for all your love and support!

story:
Short Summary

A 14 year old girl who dreams of becoming a professional ballet dancer. She has been dancing ballet for 8 years and has been en pointe for 2. She will be able to go to New York City this summer and train with the internationally-renowned Gelsey Kirkland, Baryshnikov's former partner and a current ballet teacher.

What We Need  

Listed below is the cost of summer intensive program in NYC:

  • $4,125   5-week tuition
  • $4,250 room and board 
  • $450 round-trip airfare
  • $375 pointe shoes 

The Impact

This summer intensive program is valuable to her because it will improve her technique and better her as a dancer. She has been participating in summer programs at her home studio for the past two years and is ready to take this next step into the professional ballet world. She has also been accepted to other major ballet programs such as American Ballet Theatre, Orlando Ballet, and Ballet West.

story:
AUNTS is raising 3k to support the final performance event in our summer series AUNTS Goes Public! as part of OPEN CULTURE NYC. THANK YOU to everyone who donated and helped reach our first goal of 8k in support of our first two events on June 6th and July 18th! 

We're paying everybody! Artists, organizers, videographers, DJs, on-site helpers. AND THE EVENTS ARE ALL FREE AND OPEN TO THE PUBLIC! Make a tax deductible donation in support of this work (in lieu of buying a ticket). 

All contributions big and small are welcome and tax deductible to the extent allowed by law. AUNTS is a program of Before Your Eyes, Inc., a 501c3 organization.

AUNTS is organized by: Jordan Lloyd, Shana Crawford, Larissa Velez-Jackson, Jessie Young, Kadesmiles, and Laurie Berg. 

AUNTS had a great feature in the New York Times about our summer series. Read it HERE.

"I like to think of AUNTS as a roving adventure through performance and space...It's malleable and artist-run, open-ended and nonjudgemental." - Gia Kourlas, The New York Times

Check out the AUNTS website for event info and artist line-up. Thank you to all of the artists, organizations, individuals, spaces, organizers, and clamp lights that have made AUNTS possible since 2005.

ABOUT AUNTS: Through the AUNTS apparatus, artists (from the NYC contemporary dance community and beyond) come together to share the same space at the same time, negotiating the simultaneous presentation of their work in relationship to one another. Often taking the form of an immersive live event, audiences are free to move through AUNTS, engaging with as many or as few of its offerings as they like, choosing their own path through the event and creating their own experiences through chance encounters. The whole could be viewed as a work independent from, but no more/less important than, its individual constituent parts. Since 2005, AUNTS has organized over 60 events and hosted more than five hundred artists from all disciplines and at various points in their careers. 

AUNTS continues to evolve and expand to hold space for artists working under the circumstances and in the context of now. Allowing an artist’s work to be cared for – and seen – as it passes through the AUNTS model and into its next iteration.

LEARN MORE ABOUT AUNTS
LEARN MORE ABOUT BEFORE YOUR EYES, INC.

story:
Who We Are

The Road Theatre Company was founded in 1991 by a group of dedicated artists who were passionate about bringing new, socially relevant voices and challenging ideas to the American stage. Since then, we have become one of only a handful of companies in Los Angeles that produce new works. Why so few? Because producing new plays is a huge risk. Live theatre can be prohibitively expensive to produce, and producing a show no one has ever heard of presents challenges many theatre producers are reluctant to face.

The Road Theatre has been taking on those challenges for 25 years. We believe that it is essential for the health of the American ethos to advance the larger theatrical conversation of our national culture. Through this dialogue we animate and inspire both our artists and audiences with the realization that through art and action we are lifted into the searching of soul, the revelation of humanity, the awareness that we are not alone and the struggle to make sense of our existence on this earth – as it is and as we wish it to be.

"Living Treasures - Why L.A. Theatre Matters: The Road Theatre Company ... some of the best production values in the city with sets that are cinematic in scope and scale." - LA Weekly

The Road has two venues: a 44-seat black box theatre on Lankershim Boulevard, The Road on Lankershim, and a state-of-the-art 76-seat facility on Magnolia Boulevard, The Road on Magnolia. The size of these spaces creates powerful connections between audiences and performers, but it also limits the number of tickets we can sell to support our art. That leaves us with two choices: Either raise the price of tickets to the point where many of our audience members could no longer afford to attend, or seek additional support, so that we can continue making new plays accessible to all, regardless of their financial status.

That's where you come in! As a supporter of The Road, you will be helping us to continue our tradition of producing new works in a powerful, intimate setting in Los Angeles. You'll be helping us keep our ticket prices affordable, making live theatre accessible to people of all ages and backgrounds. And you will be helping to give a voice to both new and established playwrights, as well as an extensive company of artists, directors, designers, and technicians who believe, as you do, that theatre is a vital part of our national culture.

"Quite honestly, theatre doesn’t get much better than this." - NoHo Magazine

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $25,000 to help support the production of our next five shows. This is our promise to you, that The Road is going to continue our mission for many vital productions to come. The $5,000 allotted to each show will cover the following:

- Playwright & actor stipends

- Lighting & sound design

- Ticket subsidies for seniors, students, and other underserved audiences

Five thousand dollars does not cover the cost of a full production; instead, it covers a portion of the shortfall often left by ticket sales, and it provides The Road with a platform on which we can continue to produce new, socially relevant plays for the next generation of theatre artists and audiences.

"The Road Theatre Company is one of the reasons I love going to the theatre in LA.
I have never, ever seen a play produced by them that is anything less than brilliant."
- NohoArtsDistrict.com

As far as what you'll get in return... we're offering some AWESOME perks in appreciation of your contribution. Tickets to individual shows, season subscriptions, and Summer Playwrights Festival passes are just the beginning... we are also offering dinner with a playwright, walk-on backstage roles, a short play written and performed in your honor, special thanks to you on our Magnolia marquee, and more!

But what you really get, of course, is the satisfaction of supporting a cause you truly believe in -- giving new voices and challenging ideas a place to be heard.

Other Ways You Can Help

Big heart, small budget? Never fear! There are still many ways you can help The Road achieve our goal. Help us get the word out by using Indiegogo share tools to tell others about our campaign! Let the theatre-lovers in your life know that The Road is fighting to keep new plays alive on the LA stage, and with your support, we will thrive for another 25!

To find out more about The Road, please visit us at www.roadtheatre.org, or follow us on social media:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/roadtheatre/

Twitter: @roadtheatre

Instagram: @roadtheatre

#thrivein25

The size of these spaces creates powerful connections between audiences and performers, but it also limits the number of tickets we can sell to support our art. That leaves us with two choices: Either raise the price of tickets to the point where many of our audience members could no longer afford to attend, or seek additional support, so that we can continue making new plays accessible to all, regardless of their financial status.
That's where you come in! As a supporter of The Road, you will be helping us to continue our tradition of producing new works in a powerful, intimate setting in Los Angeles. You'll be helping us keep our ticket prices affordable, making live theatre accessible to people of all ages and backgrounds. And you will be helping to give a voice to both new and established playwrights, as well as an extensive company of artists, directors, designers, and technicians who believe, as you do, that theatre is a vital part of our national culture. 

"Quite honestly, theatre doesn’t get much better than this." - NoHo Magazine
What We Need & What You Get
We are seeking $25,000 to help support the production of our next five shows. This is our promise to you, that The Road is going to continue our mission for many vital productions to come. The $5,000 allotted to each show will cover the following:
- Playwright & actor stipends
- Lighting & sound design
- Ticket subsidies for seniors, students, and other underserved audiences
Five thousand dollars does not cover the cost of a full production; instead, it covers a portion of the shortfall often left by ticket sales, and it provides The Road with a platform on which we can continue to produce new, socially relevant plays for the next generation of theatre artists and audiences.

"The Road Theatre Company is one of the reasons I love going to the theatre in LA.I have never, ever seen a play produced by them that is anything less than brilliant." - NohoArtsDistrict.com

As far as what you'll get in return... we're offering some AWESOME perks in appreciation of your contribution. Tickets to individual shows, season subscriptions, and Summer Playwrights Festival passes are just the beginning... we are also offering dinner with a playwright, walk-on backstage roles, a short play written and performed in your honor, special thanks to you on our Magnolia marquee, and more!
But what you really get, of course, is the satisfaction of supporting a cause you truly believe in -- giving new voices and challenging ideas a place to be heard.
Other Ways You Can Help
Big heart, small budget? Never fear! There are still many ways you can help The Road achieve our goal. Help us get the word out by using Indiegogo share tools to tell others about our campaign! Let the theatre-lovers in your life know that The Road is fighting to keep new plays alive on the LA stage, and with your support, we will thrive for another 25!

To find out more about The Road, please visit us at www.roadtheatre.org, or follow us on social media:
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/roadtheatre/
Twitter: @roadtheatre
Instagram: @roadtheatre
#thrivein25

story:
Campaign Summary

JED Productions wants to make fringe theatre really accessible and sustainable for everyone, including the people on the stage and those watching it.

  • Most people know me as 'Jezza' and i've been aspiring to be a Fairy Godmother of Pantomime since 2004.  It was my first job as an actor, and one of my first professional writing jobs.  My shows have been seen by around 77,000 audience members between 2010 and 2015.
  • The call of the Bow Bells (or something similar) told me to produce my own pantomimes with the support of extremely talented people since 2013 at the Bridewell Theatre in London.  We want to continue making it fun, fresh and good place for people to come.  Many people's first experience of live theatre is Pantomime, but then we lost them to extortionate ticket prices.  I'd love to get them back and show them what fun live theatre still is.
  • If you can be the Dormice-turned-Footmen to my Cinderella, you are sticking up two fingers to non-sensical elitism and making theatre sustainable for the people who work in it (a rare thing these days) and making sure many people who don't always get to see theatre can see it.  We get a lot of people in who are Pensioners or have low income.  They come with a weak smile on their faces, and leave with a deep belly laugh.  You can help make their life better, if only for an hour.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what your amazing contributions can make happen:

  • Short of finding Jack's Magic Beans, we're using this platform to raise £2000.  We're appealing to you, everyday philanthropists, to make this happen.  At this point, we think it realistic to cover our main costs so that every penny we make at the Box Office can be split (profit share style) between the Cast and Technician, the very people who make the show what it truly is.  If we raise a Grand, they'll be walking away with approximately £350 each, unheard of in most profit share shows.
  • If Dick Whittington is right and the streets of Indiegogo really ARE paved with gold and we get the full £2k, this will go to the Cast and Technician too, in order to reimburse them better for the wonderful work that they do (travel costs etc).
  • Cinderella went from Rags to Riches, so we thought of something special for you, too.  For our perks we are offering a little slice of Pantomime history.  As far as we know we are the ONLY Lunchtime Pantomime in existence, so signed flyers, programmes posters and props can wing their way to you, or if you come to see the show, you can get them in person!  
  • If the results are more Baron Hardup than Aladdin's Magic Lamp, we'll use the money to cover costs as much as is possible to free up as much of the Profit Pot there is for this years Babes in the Wood (a good analogy for creative people if ever I heard one!)

The Impact

We're not going to change the world but we're going to make it a lot more fun!

  • Like a scullery maid in a dingy cellar, we all need to escape our daily lives for a while.  Sitting in a warm, comfortable local theatre for 45 minutes is a very good way of doing that.  The world is an uncertain place, but the comedy joy found at the Bridewell Lunchtime Pantomime can be relied upon!  It makes a difference to everyday people, just like you.
  • For the last three years we've pulled in around 650 people each year, an average of 54 people per show, which is a very respectable number for a fringe audience.  Some people come multiple times, each time bringing friends or just enjoying to for themselves (I think the record was one chap who came 5 times, he really did want to go to the ball!)
  • Most of you have never met me before and I wouldn't blame you for thinking a small theatre in the backstreets of London probably isn't paved with comedy gold...but we think it is.  The writing of the show is often commented upon, just check out the audience review videos in the video gallery below our main campaign video. Our gorgeous audience love the fact that there's a laugh in almost every line.  I've been devouring comedy since I was born, and every year I get to mix it up and share it with new people who laugh so hard they miss the next joke.  Please help me keep them laughing.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest risk, as ever, is that the show gets more 'Boos' than Cheers and no one bothers coming, but that would be very unlikely given our successful track record!

  • Like Daisy the Cow, I can be a stubborn heifer.  If it's raining I still spend many an hour flyering for the show, as do my amazing cast members.  I've worked on the script all year so you can be sure it will have the trademark graft and effort that all my previous work has had too.
  • If no one turns up, I shall wave the magic wand called humility and find out why.  Audiences have a great way of telling you they're not happy, and if they're not, re-writing is swift and effective.  But in the three years i've been doing pantomime at the Bridewell, and the four I wrote before that for schools (seen by around 25,000 people a year they were) I've never had an audience totally 'turn off'.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know some of you lovely people don't have a Magic Genie and just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help if you want to:

  • Can you make like a Giant and create a lot of noise for me about this campaign?
  • If you feel able, share this link around your social media networks and feel a golden Rapunzel-like glow around your head for such a good deed.

​Thank You for getting this far, that means you've really considered backing me, and for that alone I am grateful.  Have a great day.

story:
Angie Moon Dance Theatre was established in 2011 in Boston, MA. Since the birth of the company we have presented work at the Kennedy Center, Danspace, Dixon Place, The Manhattan JCC, Roger Williams University, University Settlement, Actors Fund Arts Center, Farmers Markets, Art Galleries, Abandoned Pubs in London, and many more! After a brief hiatus to earn my MFA at NYU/Tisch we are back in action, presenting work in NYC, and about to premiere “Hunting Year”, a new 45 min collaborative work that has been a year in a making. The shows are December 15th & 16th, at Triskelion Arts as a part of their Split Bill Series. 

 

This campaign is mainly to compensate my dancers for their unbelievable work throughout this  endeavor. My process is extremely collaborative, so I not only ask them to come and dance, but I also rely on their creative input as well. “Hunting Year” would not be what it is without them. I thank the universe constantly for their commitment to me, and my work. It is painful to me that I have not yet been able to compensate them. Up until this point I have always paid my dancers out of my own pocket, however what I can offer is not acceptable for the amount of time we have been rehearsing with a cast of 8 dancers. I hope to spend around $5,000 on compensating them. The rest of the money I have left over will be going towards breaking even on the rehearsal space I have rented out of pocket for the year (about $2,000 total) and lastly, the future of the company. We are starting to gain some steam and present work more regularly, and I am at the point where I want AMDT to run as a legitimate business. I not only want to continue to present my own work, but I also have some long term goals that will help keep my company running, AND hugely benefit the dance community, (explained below.)

 

(2-4 year plan)- Creative workshop for pre-professionals. As a multi media artist myself, I see the benefit of exploring many mediums of art. They all filter into my understanding of creativity, form, and composition as a whole. For this reason I wish to create a series of workshops or intensives for young makers who are interested in collaborating and learning about other mediums. There are countless dance workshops for dancers who want to work on their technique, but less for the dancers who want to seriously explore who they are as artists. I plan to make one that includes all different forms of art, where collaboration is encouraged, mentorship is offered, and projects are created. This will be application and portfolio based. 

(5-7 year plan)- Multi-media performance opportunities for early/mid career artists. As, I mentioned above, I am a huge believer in collaboration. This concert series will focus on getting a collective of early and mid career artists, (spanning many genres) together to go wild! In this series my goal is to select a collective of artists based on applications and portfolios, give them a space to work in, a stipend to split how they would like to, mentorship, and the time/resources to create a multi-media collaborative evening of art! These opportunities are also incredibly rare to come by, (if at all) and would not only encourage artists to collaborate and work together, but will also give them experience in handling a budget, and producing a show. 

 

Of course, these are HEFTY goals, and and there will be many many steps in between now and when they become active events. However I strongly believe in the potential of these events, and the positive impact they can have on the community. I believe they are ideas that can eventually travel, not only nationally but internationally. Seeing them as being far off in the distance is difficult, but I know to do it right (and to give them longevity) the foundation will need to be strong, which means lots of grant applications, fundraising, and a fabulous team of leaders to get the logistics ironed out. The leftover money will not be all we need to get these plans done, however it will be a starting point that will grant me the time and space to get the first steps in place. 

 

The Impact of this campaign, if successful will be more than what I think most people even realize. The dance world is full of opportunities for dancers, yet the vast majority of them are unpaid and if they are, it is often much less than minimum wage. I think sometimes it is easy to forget that these artists are dancers for a living, not as a hobby. They are committed to this lifestyle, it is grueling, it is expensive, it is time consuming, it is exhausting, and it is often unappreciated. It is not a hobby, it is their career. A little goes a long way, and if you break it down- What I hope to give them is still just under minimum wage, which is devastating. The impact of my plans stated above could potentially be career changing, not just for me, but for every artist who can participate. 

 

The arts are always risky to an extent. However I have a track record of being successful in what I set my mind to. I have successfully produced conferences, shows, workshops, and events. I have been a teacher for 15 years where I am lucky to travel the country spreading art to kids, and what makes me most proud is that in most of my career I have created my own opportunities. I decided at a young age that I wanted a career in dance, and I am thankful for my wild ambition and stubborn personality for making it happen!

story:
The Gray places priority on paying its dancers with hourly wages, giving them the financial support and the professional respect they deserve.  This can be a financial challenge for a dance organization, including The Gray, which is why this campaign is dedicated solely to the raising of funds to ensure fair compensation for all our hired dancers for the year 2019.  All proceeds from this fundraising campaign will go straight to the dancer’s wages. The more money raised, the more financial support there will be for the dancers.

With your support, The Gray will not only have the ability to compensate its dancers for their work, but it will also have the ability to create a sustainable business model for the company.  The funding raised from this campaign will allow for The Gray to focus on the development of a company structure that is more supportive of both the work and of the dancers.  We don't just research dance, but we also research ways in which we can make our company stronger and more stable.     

The Dancers, 2018: 

The dancers of The Midsummer gave their incredible minds, bodies, and spirits to the dance work, placing emphasis and empathy on the audience experience.  They were generous not only with their dancing, but with their emotional selves, breathing life into a public service with the intention of connecting with the audience.  We hope to see a lot more of them in 2019!

Corbin Hall (The Midsummer, Demetrius) 

Jim Kent (The Midsummer, Lysander) 

Sumaya Mulla-Carrillo (The Midsummer, Helena)

Leah Russell (The Midsummer, Puck)

Melissa Sanderson (The Midsummer, Hermia)

The Future:

The service provided by the dancers of The Gray in 2019 will involve working and collaborating with director and choreographer Beth Terwilleger.   It will include the development and performance of an immersive dance audio experience based off of the novel And Then There Were None by Agatha Christie, a revisiting of The Midsummer as a fully immersive and audience interactive experience, and the creation of a stage piece retelling of classical ballet characters from a new voice and new perspective titled The Hypothesis.  It also includes the early stages of the development of Dune, based on the science fiction novel by Frank Herbert.

It is also important to note that we do not view our professional dancers as hobbyists or as lucky to be doing something that they love.  Gratitude is important, but so is respect. These artists have dedicated their lives to the service and practice of dance and they deserve the respect of professionalism and compensation.

The Mission, The Gray:

We, at The Gray, place a lot of energy and value on enhancing the audience experience, as well as on discovering how well the service of dance is being received by the audience.  We try to cultivate empathy with the application of empathy in our work and in our attitudes towards the audience. The respect for the human experience, however, starts with the dancers and how they are treated.  Creating a deeper respect for the artist will only increase the quality of the service that the dance company is able to provide for the public.

The mission of The Gray is to create a research environment for dance that focuses on creating works that are able to connect deeply with the general public.  We believe that the development of mixed reality experiences, which combine immersive technologies and dance, will cultivate a deeper relationship with the public while allowing for both technology and dance to provide a greater service for our culture.   Becoming a company that can strongly support this mission will take time, resources, and a lot of hard work. It is an ambitious, yet worthy undertaking and we are prepared to fight for this end goal.

The Gray recognizes that there are many different forms of art and dance, and that there can be many different ways in which art can be created and expressed.  There is value in this diversity. The company model of The Gray was created based off of our mission and informed by our artistic passions and resources. We know that this is not the only way to exist in the field and are supportive of those who are different from us.

Images: Stefano Altamura, @salt.photo

Videos: Joseph Lambert, @jazzyphoto

story:
Short Summary

This is a story that takes place ten months after the JFK assassination and two months after the passage of the Civil Rights Act.  In September of 1964, the tenacious women of the LBJ White House launched what was previously unheard of:  a whistle stop campaign tour that would take the First Lady (unaccompanied by her husband) through hostile political territory.  The central character of the play is Liz Carpenter (Press Secretary to Lady Bird Johnson), who travels back in time from her 1980s hot tub to 1964 Jim Crow South via the caboose platform of the Lady Bird Special.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $10,000 in 60 days

We are seeking to raise $10,000 to launch a grand opening of Liz and LadyBird: WhistleStop 1964! in Austin, Texas (home to Liz Carpenter and Lady Bird Johnson). This production will be a springboard for further performances at festivals and other theaters across the U.S. and abroad.

Who Are We?

  • Writer/performer Sheila Gordon is a professional actor, dialect coach and professor of acting and voice at St. Edward's University in Austin, TX..  She has performed in many countries, including Italy, Scotland, Switzerland, Germany and Russia. She is an award-winning solo performer, and has performed previous solo shows in in NY, LA, Edinburgh, and Austin, TX. 
  • Director Rebecca Whitehurst is an internationally recognized theatre artist, choreographer, Fulbright scholar, and professor of acting and voice at Northern Arizona University.
  • Sound and projection designer Eliot Fisher is a member of the ARCOS Dance Collective

Your Money Will be Used for Production Costs

We have the following collaborators and physical costs to pay:  director, stage manager, sound/projection designer, videographer, space rental, program reproduction, sound/projection, costume fees, and support staff needed to run the show. The show will be professionally video-taped, so that we can further promote the show to festivals across the U.S. and elsewhere. 

  • We have some nice incentives and perks, so check them out!
  • If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will still be used to launch a grand opening in Austin, TX.  The bare-bones needs are physical theatre rental and videography, in order to further the outreach of the show.
  • If we do reach our entire goal, we will be able to
    • pay our artists for their talent and hard work
    • make the design of our production worthy of national recognition
    • submit this fabulous production to theaters and festivals across the U.S.--even beyond!

The Impact

  • You can help us spread the word about this piece history that was forged and created by women.
  • You can helps support experienced theatre artists in their pursuit to create high quality, original work
  • You can support us to shine the light on women's role in creating political history.  
  • We are artists who teach.  Collectively, we have an extensive audience of young adults. You can help to inspire young people (of all genders and persuasions) to participate in civic duties and become responsible citizens! 

Risks & Challenges

  • All new projects have risks and challenges.  Our challenges are monetary.
  • The only risk we foresee is lack of support. So PLEASE... SPREAD THE LOVE!
  • We are also applying for external grant monies for supplemental funding.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help in so many ways! 

  • You can contribute any amount of money... and we will be extremely grateful!
  • If you are unable to contribute funds...
    • You can give support by spreading the word!
    • Tell 1, 2 or 10 friends about our project...
  • Remember: you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
Short Summary
This is a story that takes place ten months after the JFK assassination and two months after the passage of the Civil Rights Act.  In September of 1964, the tenacious women of the LBJ White House launched what was previously unheard of:  a whistle stop campaign tour that would take the First Lady (unaccompanied by her husband) through hostile political territory.  The central character of the play is Liz Carpenter (Press Secretary to Lady Bird Johnson), who travels back in time from her 1980s hot tub to 1964 Jim Crow South via the caboose platform of the Lady Bird Special.

What We Need & What You Get
We need to raise $10,000 in 60 days
We are seeking to raise $10,000 to launch a grand opening of Liz and LadyBird: WhistleStop 1964! in Austin, Texas (home to Liz Carpenter and Lady Bird Johnson). This production will be a springboard for further performances at festivals and other theaters across the U.S. and abroad.

Writer/performer Sheila Gordon is a professional actor, dialect coach and professor of acting and voice at St. Edward's University in Austin, TX..  She has performed in many countries, including Italy, Scotland, Switzerland, Germany and Russia. She is an award-winning solo performer, and has performed previous solo shows in in NY, LA, Edinburgh, and Austin, TX. 
Director Rebecca Whitehurst is an internationally recognized theatre artist, choreographer, Fulbright scholar, and professor of acting and voice at Northern Arizona University.
Sound and projection designer Eliot Fisher is a member of the ARCOS Dance Collective

We have some nice incentives and perks, so check them out!
If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will still be used to launch a grand opening in Austin, TX.  The bare-bones needs are physical theatre rental and videography, in order to further the outreach of the show.
If we do reach our entire goal, we will be able to
pay our artists for their talent and hard work
make the design of our production worthy of national recognition
submit this fabulous production to theaters and festivals across the U.S.--even beyond!

We are artists who teach.  Collectively, we have an extensive audience of young adults. You can help to inspire young people (of all genders and persuasions) to participate in civic duties and become responsible citizens! 


Risks & Challenges

All new projects have risks and challenges.  Our challenges are monetary.
The only risk we foresee is lack of support. So PLEASE... SPREAD THE LOVE!
We are also applying for external grant monies for supplemental funding.


Other Ways You Can Help
You can help in so many ways! 

You can contribute any amount of money... and we will be extremely grateful!
If you are unable to contribute funds...
You can give support by spreading the word!
Tell 1, 2 or 10 friends about our project...

story:
Our project

We have couple of goals throughout this campaign and we feel very passionate about all of them:

*educating people in our country and showing them how to accept and value equity regardless to your identity - sexual, national, gender or religious
*showing young and upcoming artists how to express themselves, but, how to fight for their believes and projects, and how to make them from scratch 
*developing critical opinion based on knowledge and arguments 
*and just to make ya'll sit back, relax and have some fun!

So, your part in this is very important and we value it very, very much. We cannot succeed   without your help and contribution.

What We Need & What You Get

Since we are not founded by the government, the funds are a big issue .And that's where you step in!

As we said, we do all of our work ourselves - sewing, building, directing, etc. So we can save a bunch of money, but we still need it for:
*materials for costumes
*materials for the set
*space rental for rehearsals and performance
*lights and sound
*fees for participants 
*copyright
*make up
*promotion
*travel expenses

This project needs 26 000 USD, which would be ideal. We plan to give at least 5% of all income to a local animal shelter, 'cause we just love animals!

If the project does not reach the entire goal, we will still do our best to make this show happen, and to do something good for the animals, too.  However, if we reach more than we had hoped for, we need to do something meaningful with that amount. So, we talked it over, and we agreed to invest it in a participation on Edinburgh Fringe festival 2019.!

 

The Perks

We have prepared a lot of very fun perks for you!

A special "Thank You" wrap!
A"Happily Ever After Cabaret" key chain, postcard, fridge magnet, coffee mug, posters, t-shirts, tickets to the show, a bronze, silver and gold mystery boxes, a recording of "Happily Ever After Cabaret" show with backstage experience, accommodation and a city tour with cabaret crew, a Donor's after party, or even To Be A Producer!

You can see the details on your right!

 

Our Team

Anteo Ukušić, dancer, choreographer, dance teacher, actor.
With 13 years dance experience, and about 8 years performing experience, we present to you one of our choreographers. Coming from street dances, but shares passion for theater none the less. He performed in productions of modern, musical, cabaret and street dance shows and plays such as ˝Nothing is wrong˝ by MASA dance company, ˝Changes˝ by ZKM from Zagreb, and with those two even performed internationally, ˝Writing poems˝by Tala dance studio from Zagreb, etc. And beside that he appeared in several music videos from Croatian celebrities and a couple of commercials.



Magdalena Matijević, actress, dancer, choreographer.
She opened herself up to the dance  world at the young age of four. Her first steps were through jazz and ballet and after that it went on with contemporary and modern jazz. Today, she combines all of her knowledge and past experiences on stage and experiments with them. She has numerous musicals, cabarets, shows and theatrical performances behind her. Combined with great deal of patience and a flair for teaching, she makes a wonderful choreographer. 

 
Tomislav M. Čeleketić, singer, vocal coach, playwright, director.
He performed in various musicals and was rewarded for the most of them. His roles and character changes  are numerous: Jekyll and Hyde, Dracula, Sebastian, Count Monte Christo, Joseph and others. Beside musical theater, he performed in cabarets, gospel concerts, and as an actor in TV shows and classical theater. He had a lot of success as a writer: 15 of his shows  saw the light of day in theater and he has a book coming out soon.  
 
Veronika Gajšak, actress, singer.
Gratuated at 1. Croatian Broadway School for musical theatre in Zagreb. Attented many workshops learning Cehov,Strasberg and Stanislavski acting techniques, various dancing techniques and drama pedagogy. Experienced in theatre ( musical „Forrbiden doors“- Zagreb youth theatre (ZKM), musical Dracula – arts organisation „Backstage“ ), and TV( short movies, music videos, currently acting in series „ Backstage“). Active member of „Backstage“ arts organisation leading drama workshops and playing in current musicals.
 
Ingrid Samardžija, actress, dancer, acrobat.
Started when she was only 4 years old, a rich background in competetive sports as much as in dancing meetings and competitions, with numerous golden medals, makes a shiny addition to our cast. With experience in partner work and acrobatics, not only dancing, makes a perfect piece of the puzzle inside our cabaret. She performed in couple of dancing shows, on major sport competitions and music videos as well.

Filip Lazov, actor, dancer, model.
Very young and promising artist, still in training, but non the less, very professional and versatile. Besides his career in sports, he starred in various TV commercials and had a couple of leads in theatrical performances. Active member of BACKSTAGE with couple of ongoing projects. 
 
Anamaria Cvjetković, dancer , actress.
A very young person with many professional engagements behind her, already with 8 years of dancing in her resume. That combined with the love for a little bit older music, rather than today's trends is a perfect combination for this cabaret. She performed for a couple of celebrities in Croatia, on national television, as well as major sport competitions such as European Handball championship, and many others. She also performed on gala evenings, music festivals and dance productions.
 
Ana Barišić, singer and an actress
With her studies in cultural management behind her, Ana devoted herself to singing, acting and performing. Active in theater and cabaret.


Denis Rajčić, actor, dancer, fitness coach, comedian.
With a rich experience in croatian series, theater performances, music video clips and TV commercials. Denis has experience as an entertainer, dancer and animator in various projects. Also, he is a professional and personal fitness coach with 25 years of training and 13 years of contest experience. He was a  Fitness Model Champion (INBA Federation), 2 x Mr. Adonis and Men’s Health cover model, and now, a permanent columnist for Men’s Health magazine and bodybuilding portals – with over 150 published articles. Besides fitness and dancing, he is acting and  doing stand-up comedy. He recently launched his own brand, ”Train with a Smile’’, where he combines fitness and stand-up comedy.



Vanja Kordić Dević, make up artist, stylist, designer.
With a very rich experience in performing - as a singer, pool dancer, majorette and an actress - Vanja knows exactly what we need on the stage, on our bodies and on our faces. She incorporates all her knowledge of performing to make impressive statements trough costumes, make up, and sets.


 

Other Ways You Can Help

We value every way of contributing. If you cannot support this project financially, you can still help!
Share our project throughout Indiegogo tools, or just share trough social media.

https://www.facebook.com/udruga.backstage/?ref=...

https://www.facebook.com/Happyily-Ever-After-Ca...

Feel free to e-mail us and ask whatever you need to know!
udruga.backstage@gmail.com

story:
A brilliant rectangle of light. Eight feet by ten feet. In this tight, bright space one man paces. Alone. So begins “8x10,” a devised solo performance that seeks to illuminate the reality of solitary confinement in the U.S.

“8x10” started with a conversation between director Jared Culverhouse and dramaturg Paul Adolphsen while they were touring a closed prison in Johannesburg, South Africa where anti-apartheid activists were once held in solitary confinement. Struck by the terrible reality of isolation, and aware that many of the same practices are still used in the U.S., we began talking about making a piece focusing on solitary confinement.

In September 2016 Jared met James Savage, an actor and educator with his own personal and artistic passion to tell the story of those forgotten in prison. Someone close to James was jailed in the prison system, and the symptoms of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder brought on by this experience of incarceration deeply affected their relationship. As a performer, James was interested in exploring the way that solitary confinement and the prison system warp the human psyche.

In the fall of 2016 we got together and began making this play.

While fictional, “8x10” uses extensive research about the experiences of individuals in solitary to create an honest portrait of extreme isolation.

We are thrilled to be presenting “8x10” at the Cincy Fringe Festival from May 30 - June 11, 2017. Cincinnati is the perfect place to premiere “8x10.” The state of Ohio has the sixth largest prison population in the U.S. And according to the ACLU of Ohio, the state’s prison system currently holds 2,952 people in solitary. More than a quarter of these these individuals have a mental illness.

Given this context, we believe that “8x10” is uniquely situated to spark necessary conversations within the Cincinnati community around issues of social justice and mass incarceration.

HOW CAN YOU SUPPORT 8x10?

We are asking for a easy one-time donation of 50 to 100 dollars to help reach our goal of $5,000 for this not-for-profit production.

Your contribution will help us to raise awareness, prick consciences, and spur action. And it’ll help us get to the Cincy Fringe Festival from May 30 - June 11, 2017.

50% of the proceeds of the show will be donated to the ACLU of Ohio to help continue their fight against unfair practices in the criminal justice system. The remainder of the proceeds will go directly towards our next production of this play. 

All money raised through this campaign will go toward:

TRANSPORTATION

  • Car Rental for 2 weeks at $2,000 with taxes and fees and insurance
  • Gas for the trip there and back: $210 + $75 for in city commute and parking

REHEARSAL/WORKSHOP FEES 

  • $350 for rehearsal and studio space
  • $300 for postcards and posters to promote the performance
  • $300 for props
  • $725 dollars for set pieces; we are working with a local Cincinnati sculptor who will be manufacturing our set pieces for the show.

PER DIEM FOR JARED, JAMES, PAUL, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANT 

  • $21.00/day each = $1176.00

PERKS

We’re excited to give the following perks for those who make a contribution and help get us and “8x10” to Cincinnati:

$50+: Thank you note from us, a mention on our Facebook page, and two emails from the Cincy Fringe with updates about the show.

$100+: Thank you note from us, a shout-out on our Facebook page, two show postcards, and four emails from the Cincy Fringe with updates about the show, and a donation in your name to the ACLU of Ohio.

OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT US

If you don’t feel you can contribute monetarily, don’t fear! There are plenty of other ways to support us as we bring “8x10” to the Cincy Fringe Fest.

You can get the word out on social media and email by sharing our campaign with friends you think might be interested. And like our Facebook page and check back regularly to stay in touch with us and “8x10.”

Your donation will be greatly appreciated and instantly put to use to help raise awareness about solitary confinement at the Cincy Fringe Fest.

Please be generous, make a difference in a tangible way and donate today.

Thank you.

story:
The Edinburgh Fringe Sell-Out Drama Comes to the US!

After a success London preview and a sold-out Edinburgh Fringe premiere run, we are incredibly excited to be bringing Ladies in Waiting: The Judgement of Henry VIII to the United States! We will be heading to Hollywood Fringe in June and Capital Fringe in Washington D.C. in July!

But we need your help! We are looking to raise a bit of extra money to cover the costs of living for our performers, including housing for Hollywood Fringe and assistance with transportation.

This show has been an incredible project we have been working on now for almost two years and cannot wait to bring it to new audiences, with your help this summer!

What We Need & What You Get

As mentioned above, any donations received will assist in us covering housing for our actors and any further donations will help with transportation as we tour the show throughout the USA this summer! 

Rewards will range from social media shoutouts, listed in our program, and comp tickets to the show this summer! 

Other Ways You Can Help


LIKE our FACEBOOK page: http://facebook.com/LadiesinWaitingHENRYVIII

FOLLOW US on TWITTER: twitter.com/LadiesinW8ting

Spread the word to all your friends!
