story:
About the Play

“The sophistication of the concepts at hand and the sheer beauty of the language in this play makes it worthy of the word ‘intelligent’... devised among the predominantly female, multi-racial cast..Survival beyond the destruction of our current ecosystem is at stake in this relevant story of past, present and future times." — Teresa Marrero, TheaterJones.com

Anghared262 is a scientist from Omnivessel, a spacecraft that left the earth in the year 2050.  She is sent to the once-dying Earth with a mission of scouting for food samples.  When she encounters Earthroot, she enters her ancestral past and questions her allegiance to Omnivessel.  Earthroot, a peaceful, global, reindigenized matriarchy, must face the impending colonization as they lose two of their own to Anghared’s arrival. Find out what happens as we bring the possibilities of a radically healed future to life in the theatrical production Where Earth Meets The Sky written by Edyka Chilomé, Vanessa Mercado-Taylor, and Ariana Cook. Get your tickets for the world premiere here.   (April 14-29, 2018) 

 

About the Project

The staged play Where Earth Meets the Sky is the theatrical component of a larger transmedia storytelling project called Earthroot: A Collective Imagining. Led by queer women of color, primarily in the south, this project imagines possible futures in collective through the exploration of identity, decolonization, healing and reclaiming of ancestral knowledge. These themes are explored by radical thinkers and artists through a fictional narrative that spans over a thousand years in the future while rooted in ancient and present day spiritual and political movements for change.   

We invite you to be apart of this collective imagining as we bring together a powerful group of artists and activists. With your financial help we will be able to fund 4 amazing artists to join us on the design team. Their voices and contributions will be vital to honoring this story on stage and honoring the communities who will be in conversation with it. In addition, your contributions will support the creation of media and artifacts that will be used to strengthen the scope of the project on and off stage.

Help imagine futures with us and tell a story that reminds our community that another world is possible!

 

What We're Raising Money For

Blood Memory Video Design by Yoeme Homari $1,500
3d mapping and space projections $1,500
Community Video Design by Guadalupe Reveles  $2,000
Lobby Installation by Leticia Contreras $2,000
Project Manager Intern $2,000

Community Workshop- $3,000

Total to be Raised:  $12,000

Though we need financial assistance to make this happen, we welcome all forms of contributions from food, prayers, to artistic collaboration.

*World Premiere of the stage play Where Earth Meets the Sky is being produced in Dallas, TX by Cara Mia Theatre, Co. No portion of these funds are tax deductible. This fundraising campaign directly benefits the individual artists and not Cara Mia Theatre, Co.  

 

Meet the Creators

Edyka Chilomé

Edyka Chilomé is an international literary artist, storyteller, educator, and cultural worker based in North Texas. A child of Salvadorian and Mexican immigrant activists, she was raised in social justice movements grounded in the tradition of spiritual activism. She holds a B.A. in social and political philosophy with an emphasis on social justice from Loyola University Chicago and an M.A. in Multicultural Women's Studies from Texas Women's University where her research focused on the decolonial power of spiritual [Art]ivism. Edyka has been asked to share her poetry and speak on social justice issues on multiple media platforms and in spaces including Tedx, The Huffington Post, GLAAD, NPR, The Tucson Poetry Festival, Prindle Institute for Ethics, The Dallas Museum of Art, Duke University, The Black Academy of Arts and Letters, and The Texas Democratic Convention. She has published numerous articles, essays, and poems including a collection of poetry that explores queer mestizaje in the diaspora entitled “She Speaks | Poetry”, praised by the founder of Democracy Now en Español as "...a must read for those yearning to discover new ways to open up to deep personal and global transformation." Edyka was recently named top 25 most influential artists in the DFW in 2017 by Artist Uprising Magazine. Find out more about her work at EdykaChilome.com.


Vanessa Mercado-Taylor


Vanessa Mercado-Taylor is an Indigenous/Mestiza/Colombiana Theatre director, producer, actor and playwright who for more than a decade has created performances at the intersections of human rights and social justice.  She is the Chair of Drama and Humanities at El Centro College where she created the Hip Hop Studies Program and is the Academic Director of Free Minds, which provides access to the arts and humanities to low-income residents of Dallas.  Vanessa received her MFA in directing from Ohio University, trained with Dell’Arte International, was mentored by Dipankar Mukherjee and Meena Natarajan at Pangea World Theatre and is a company member with Cara Mia Theatre Co.  She created and directed an award-winning experimental show at the Prague International Fringe Festival with Limehouse Theatre which she co-founded in 2003 in Dallas, TX.  She completed an internship in Human Rights and the Arts with Pangea World Theater in Minneapolis where she developed HypheNATIONS, a series of performances created with the Latinx Community around issues of immigration, migration and displacement.
story_txt: About the Play“The sophistication of the concepts at hand and the sheer beauty of the language in this play makes it worthy of the word ‘intelligent’... devised among the predominantly female, multi-racial cast..Survival beyond the destruction of our current ecosystem is at stake in this relevant story of past, present and future times." — Teresa Marrero, TheaterJones.comAnghared262 is a scientist from Omnivessel, a spacecraft that left the earth in the year 2050.  She is sent to the once-dying Earth with a mission of scouting for food samples.  When she encounters Earthroot, she enters her ancestral past and questions her allegiance to Omnivessel.  Earthroot, a peaceful, global, reindigenized matriarchy, must face the impending colonization as they lose two of their own to Anghared’s arrival. Find out what happens as we bring the possibilities of a radically healed future to life in the theatrical production Where Earth Meets The Sky written by Edyka Chilomé, Vanessa Mercado-Taylor, and Ariana Cook. Get your tickets for the world premiere here.   (April 14-29, 2018)  About the ProjectThe staged play Where Earth Meets the Sky is the theatrical component of a larger transmedia storytelling project called Earthroot: A Collective Imagining. story:
Summary   

Hello! I'm Jonathan Tipton Meyers, a NYC writer and performer living in Los Angeles.  After losing my company, my relationship and my so-called "identity" at 50,  I became a  Rideshare driver to save my mortgage.  This hour-long performance chronicles my 2-year journey with UBER and Lyft and explores how navigating this massive city with strangers helped me relocate myself. I am ridiculously excited for you to come along on this wild ride. 

What your ticket and support will cover: 

My goal is to get this production up on its feet, in preparation for a longer run, a book and potential a tv series. This Campaign is about TICKET RESERVATIONS! I want you to COME ALONG in person or virtually!

100% of your support will go towards:

- The Sacred Fools Theater Studio, Insurance,  Director and Stage Manager. 

- Costs for being involved with the Hollywood Fringe

- 2 Camera Video Documentation with Photography

- Advertisements so we can make sure we have sold out shows and create as much exposure as possible

- Rehearsal and tech space

- Playbills and printing

Total needed = $1700!

Production Note: I don't plan on making a profit. Any extra money made will go towards advertising and promotion. 

Why it matters.

Whether riding to the airport, or a trip to the ER, blind or disabled people who had no recourse, or hipsters too drunk to navigate the 101 after 2 am, Rideshare has become a vital part of Los Angeles. Helping us not only get around, which was virtually impossible without a car, but also re-socializing a segregated city. By literally taking us out of our "bubbles" and connecting to places and each other, we can't help but acknowledge that we're in this city together. That's a good thing. I want to spread that message. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some folks can't contribute monetarily, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Make some "SHARING" noise through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram. 
  • You can visit www.wearetrafficblog.com and drop your email. 

And thank you so much for being a part of this already. Because, cars aren't the traffic. We are.

story:
The Project:

Please help Blue Mercury Theatre to produce Statements After An Arrest Under The Immorality Act for The Philadelphia Fringe Festival. Acclaimed South African playwright, Athol Fugard's rarely produced play is incredibly provocative and relevant especially in these racially charged times. This is a piece that challenges us to look at personal and societal prejudices and also to witness how love and intellect can challenge those beliefs. Actress and company member, Megan McDermott has been incredibly passionate about this piece since working on the role of Frieda in a scene study class many years ago. After returning to the Philadelphia theatre community this year, Megan recognized that The Philadelphia Fringe Festival would be the perfect time and place to highlight this gorgeous play! The two person show is a viscerally powerful story told with Fugard's beautifully poetic language. A timely piece that mirrors the current emotional state of racial tensions in the US, Statements is sure to start conversations in this year's Fringe Festival. 

Statements will be hosted by The Independence Library in center city Philadelphia for 15 performances during the 3 week Fringe Festival in September 2017. Because we are able to stage the play in a site specific venue, audiences will have the rare opportunity to be fully immersed in this powerful piece for the first time in its production history. We are also partnering with the library to further the community's knowledge regarding apartheid as well as to disseminate current information on the racial divide both in the Philadelphia community and the country at large, therefore opening a dialogue for change. Talk backs will be facilitated each week and the Library will be featuring Trevor Noah's best selling novel, Born A Crime  which shares Noah's story of growing up as a child of mixed race parents during Apartheid.

Our goal is to raise $8,000 in order to have high production value and to give the actors and designers a fair wage for their talents.Your generous contribution helps ensure audiences have a chance to empathize, communicate, and challenge our current situation through a play that brings us back in order to move us forward. 

Budget: 

* More than half of the proposed $8000 budget is allotted to paying the artists, designers, and production staff. We are very passionate about fairly compensating artists for their time, talent, and dedication. 

* In addition to the artistic staff, a quarter of the budget is set aside for the staff of the library. While the Library is generously donating the space and set for the show, we are paying the wonderful staff overtime salaries for keeping the space open for us after hours. As the daughter of a devoted librarian, Megan is committed to valuing the efforts of those in the profession. 

* The remaining funds will be distributed towards overall production costs including: royalty fees, insurance and registration fees, and Marketing/PR . 

The People:

Megan McDermott: (Frieda Joubert) Megan is thrilled to be a part of such a beautiful and important play. NYC credits include: Sweet Bird of Youth (Gallery Players), The Three  Sisters (The Wild Project), The Erpingham Camp (WorkShop Theatre), Big Love (The Wild Project), and The Motherline Story Project. Regional credits include: In The Next Room/The Vibrator Play, Time Stands Still, The Glass Menagerie, The Importance of Being Earnest, Twelfth Night, Why Marry?, Crimes of the Heart, Shakespeare in Hollywood, The Learned Ladies, Amadeus, The Three Sisters, Richard II, The Eight: Reindeer Monologues, Berkeley Square, Laughter on the 23rdFloor, Vietnam 101, Ivanov, Dulcy, and Spring Awakening. She has performed at The Wilma Theater, The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey, Delaware Theatre Company, Bristol Riverside Theatre, Act II Playhouse, EgoPo Productions, East Lynne Theater, Pittsburgh Irish and Classical Theatre, Philadelphia Theatre Workshop, Simpatico Theatre, and McCarter Theatre Center. Training: BA in Music from University of Delaware, MFA in Acting Certificate from The Actors Center Studio/NY, classical theatre intensives with The British American Drama Academy, and The Moscow Art Theatre. www.megan-mcdermott.com 

Brandon Pierce: (Errol Philander) Brandon's credits include Troilus and Cressida, A Midsummer Night's Dream, Metamorphoses, Exit Strategy, The Winter's Tale, Charlotte's Web, Hands Up, Fair Maid of the West, MacBeth, The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Henry IV, Dutch Masters, Sunjata Kamalenya, Romeo and Juliet, and The Comedy of Errors. He has shared his talents at The Arden Theatre, Delaware Theatre Company, Philadelphia Theatre Company, Pennsylvania Shakespeare Festival, Flashpoint Theatre, Shakespeare in Clark Park, Delaware Shakespeare Festival, Azuka Theatre, Revolution Shakespeare, Philadelphia Artists Collective, Delaware Shakespeare Festival, Experiential TC, The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey, and Primary Stages. Training: BFA in Acting from The University of the Arts. 

Leigh Bicica: (Director) Leigh E. Bicica is a Philly-based director, deviser, and producer who enjoys creating devised pieces, working with playwrights on new scripts, and directing highly poetic and thematic plays. Favorite projects include Spookfish (Neighborhood Fringe), Sorrows to the Stones (UArts), Rudy: An American Tall Tale (Dixon Place), Three Laps Around the Ocean (UArts), and Hidden (London Sinfonietta). She has assistant directed for KC MacMillan, Becky Wright, and Heinz-Uwe Haus. Current projects include developing a devised piece concerning freedom of press, social media, and millennials and assistant directing for a project about the Italian Market. Her work was last seen at Pretzel Park in Manayunk, where she had a blast directing Shakesbeer in the Park's Twelfth Night for Manayunk Theatre Company. She received her BFA in Directing from The University of the Arts.

No contribution is too small and all are greatly appreciated! If you can't contribute, then please share, share, share the campaign and definitely come to the show!

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

TARTE is a unique performance institution established by Ayse Eldek-Richardson in May of 2010. While the company’s primary emphasis is on performing Turkish classics and original works by Turkish and Turkish-American writers, plays and musical submissions with Turkish or Middle-Eastern themes are considered from American and international writers as well so as to present a repertoire of quality works to a wide range of Western audiences.

Our productions explore aspects of Turkish and Middle Eastern identity that may be unfamiliar or unknown to many in the United States. Turkish and Middle Eastern culture developed over many centuries and each work we produce has its own related signature and design reflecting a past or current aspect of that cultural development. We hope to broaden the perception of what Turkish and Middle Eastern culture is and what it can be.

TARTE's seasons included plays and musicals as well as readings and educational workshops aimed at younger audiences in the kindergarten to 5th grade age range through its Performing Arts Lab, AKA Drama Club. We also have a Dance Theater project. Of particular success, has been TARTE’s annual One Act Play Festival.

Past TARTE productions include: “To Love...”, a fictional love story about the founder of modern Turkey, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, performed at Symphony Space on Broadway and 95th Street on New York’s Upper Westside; an original children’s musical entitled, “Keloglan: Bald Boy; The Musical” and “Bellini and The Sultan,” a play by an American Kennedy Awards winning writer Ed Stevens that played to sold out audiences at the NY Fringe Festival in 2013. We did a co-production of “Unseen Visitor” with Athena Theatre this past season at the Symphony Space. We also sponsored a fund raiser for refugee children entitled “Peace at Home Peace in the World” engaging various artists to perform.

We want to bring you more original and unique performances by Turkish and American writers. This campaign will help us to do that.

We want to raise funds for the performance space which is $7500 for three weeks. The rest of the raised funds will go for set decor for two productions and expenses for the cast and the crew.

  • WE HAVE REALLY EXCITING PERKS! MAKE SURE YOU PICK ONE:)
With your contributions you will have your signature in amazing work.
 
Being a small performing arts company is difficult. We want you to help us move forward and give you the performance of a life time.
 
Please contribute and share the campaign link.
 

And that's all there is to it.

Thank you kindly

story:
Our continuing MISSION

Now well into our fourth season, we still wholeheartedly believe and full-throatedly proclaim our belief that:

In an age where the notion of “neighborhood” is fast evolving into a series of intangible on-line social media webpages, A Public Fit aims to reinvigorate the tangible community by working with emerging Las Vegas artists to create exciting, innovative and provocative professional theater. APF believes strongly in the communal power of great stories, dramatic ideas and the sincere engagement that audiences find in challenging theatrical events. A Public Fit genuinely hopes to unite professional artists and audiences through the most effective form of human connection, treating each production as the beginning of an unending conversation.

“To see what exquisite acting and directing are all about, buy your ticket now before they’re gone.  This is theatre at its best.”

-Mary LaFance, Talkin’ Broadway

www.talkinbroadway.com/page/regional/lasvegas/l...

As before, the staff of APF will be working merely to cover their expenses in order to make absolutely certain that the performers and behind-the-scenes artists get paid first.  Our everlasting cry:  A Public Fit respects artists too much to ask them to work for free.

“It’s rare to see theater that unabashedly aims to create a serious work of art that’s challenging, cerebral and emotionally impacting.”

-Jacob Coakley, Las Vegas Weekly

www.lasvegasweekly.com/ae/stage/2016/nov/09/a-p...

 

Our recent PAST

A Public Fit’s on-going series of free monthly staged readings captured the imagination of an ever-growing audience of theatre aficionados who braved SRO crowds.  Our first fully-realized production, Dawn King’s Foxfinder, was met with critical and commercial success, selling out its November 2014 run and garnering 11 Las Vegas Valley Theatre Award nominations - including wins for Best Play, Best Director and Best Lighting Design - nominations in every category for which it was eligible.  The following season, APF challenged the very role of the audience itself with its world-premiere production of “A Summons from the Tinker to Assemble the Membership in Secret at the Usual Place”, an original piece that once again dominated the Valley Awards, winning Best Ensemble Cast as well as the coveted Audience Choice Award.  APF’s second show that year, Gina Gionfriddo’s modern comedy Becky Shaw, saw multiple acting nominations as well.  Our 2016-2017 season left audiences gasping - Andrew Bovell's When the Rain Stops Falling, Martin McDonagh's The Beauty Queen of Leenane and Will Eno's The Realistic Joneses raised the Las Vegas production bar to a thrilling new high.  This is the kind of flat-out, take-no-prisoners theatre that A Public Fit continues to thrive on.  And it’s why APF was named Best Theatre Company in Las Vegas by the Las Vegas Weekly immediately following our inaugural season.  And then again, just this year by KNPR's Desert Companion.  

https://knpr.org/desert-companion/2017-02/best-...

“‘When the Rain Stops Falling’ is a triumph!  … The scenic design was stunning.”

-Michael M. Humel, editor-in-chief, Culture of the Senses

http://cultureofthesenses.com/when-the-rain-sto...

 

Our spectacular FUTURE

Three mainstage productions and four staged readings will make up our 2017-2018 season, beginning September 29 with a reading of Kenneth Lonergan's Lobby Hero.  Our mainstage season begins October 27 as APF takes on Margaret Edson's Pulitzer Prize winner W;t for our first ever 4-week run.  Turning our gaze to an American classic, A Public Fit will present Tennessee Williams' iconic The Glass Menagerie in February and close out the mainstage season with Other Desert  Cities by Jon Robin Baitz in April.  

“In the ‘entertainment capital of the world,’ it’s rare to see theater that works in this register.  It’s satisfying in ways that go beyond just a good show…”

-Jacob Coakley, Las Vegas Weekly

www.lasvegasweekly.com/ae/stage/2016/nov/09/a-p...

 

Our Vegas CULTURE

Las Vegas is evolving still.  As the valley’s neon glow continues to be a beacon for cultural emigrants from across the nation, A Public Fit has actively sought out to embrace those looking for an innovative, professional, theatrical oasis in the literal desert.  Our aesthetic is unique, our vision unparalleled, our commitment unrivaled, our energy unmatched.   And while Las Vegas still draws the most talented people on the planet to perform in its spectacular strip extravaganzas, the need for cultural expression of a more connective nature still burns fiercely in the breasts of these creative super-stars.  A Public Fit exists to give voice to these yearnings, to harness the prolific desires of those artistic visionaries that land here in the valley.

“The artistic team driving APF to the forefront believes and embraces the notion that theatre is for everyone, it will always be relevant and it is a vital part of our community's culture.”

-Melanie Jupp, Assistant Program Manager, Education and Outreach, The Smith Center

 

Our PLEA

Please help us continue what we’ve started - an even larger, continuing season with 3 fully-realized productions and 4 free-to-the-public staged readings; expanded, 4-week runs of shows; our continued commitment to explore the challenges of ‘found space’ production; the drive to maintain our standing as Las Vegas’ only professional theatre company.   Add your voice to the growing chorus of those who demand more from the Las Vegas cultural landscape.  Sing proudly with us our anthems of optimism and audacity.  We’ve proven that nothing that happens in Vegas stays in Vegas; in fact, what happens in Vegas should shake the artistic pillars of the nation!  And, of course, as a nationally registered and verified non-profit organization, all donations to A Public Fit are tax-deductible to the full extent of applicable tax law!

AND FINALLY:

This year APF has been given a wonderful gift:  an anonymous benefactor has pledged to match ANY increase made by donors from previous years!  Increase your contribution from $100 to $150, and this generous lunatic will match the $50 - WITH ABSOLUTELY NO LIMIT! There's no better time, no better opportunity to get the very most out of your support of Las Vegas' premiere theatre company! Donate now!
story_txt:
Our continuing MISSION
Now well into our fourth season, we still wholeheartedly believe and full-throatedly proclaim our belief that:
In an age where the notion of “neighborhood” is fast evolving into a series of intangible on-line social media webpages, A Public Fit aims to reinvigorate the tangible community by working with emerging Las Vegas artists to create exciting, innovative and provocative professional theater. APF believes strongly in the communal power of great stories, dramatic ideas and the sincere engagement that audiences find in challenging theatrical events. A Public Fit genuinely hopes to unite professional artists and audiences through the most effective form of human connection, treating each production as the beginning of an unending conversation.
“To see what exquisite acting and directing are all about, buy your ticket now before they’re gone.  This is theatre at its best.”
-Mary LaFance, Talkin’ Broadway
www.talkinbroadway.com/page/regional/lasvegas/l...
As before, the staff of APF will be working merely to cover their expenses in order to make absolutely certain that the performers and behind-the-scenes artists get paid first.  Our everlasting cry:  A Public Fit respects artists too much to ask them to work for free.
“It’s rare to see theater that unabashedly aims to create a serious work of art that’s challenging, cerebral and emotionally impacting.”
-Jacob Coakley, Las Vegas Weekly
www.lasvegasweekly.com/ae/stage/2016/nov/09/a-p...
 
Our recent PAST
A Public Fit’s on-going series of free monthly staged readings captured the imagination of an ever-growing audience of theatre aficionados who braved SRO crowds.  Our first fully-realized production, Dawn King’s Foxfinder, was met with critical and commercial success, selling out its November 2014 run and garnering 11 Las Vegas Valley Theatre Award nominations - including wins for Best Play, Best Director and Best Lighting Design - nominations in every category for which it was eligible.  The following season, APF challenged the very role of the audience itself with its world-premiere production of “A Summons from the Tinker to Assemble the Membership in Secret at the Usual Place”, an original piece that once again dominated the Valley Awards, winning Best Ensemble Cast as well as the coveted Audience Choice Award.  APF’s second show that year, Gina Gionfriddo’s modern comedy Becky Shaw, saw multiple acting nominations as well.  Our 2016-2017 season left audiences gasping - Andrew Bovell's When the Rain Stops Falling, Martin McDonagh's The Beauty Queen of Leenane and Will Eno's The Realistic Joneses raised the Las Vegas production bar to a thrilling new high.  This is the kind of flat-out, take-no-prisoners theatre that A Public Fit continues to thrive on.  And it’s why APF was named Best Theatre Company in Las Vegas by the Las Vegas Weekly immediately following our inaugural season.  And then again, just this year by KNPR's Desert Companion.  
https://knpr.org/desert-companion/2017-02/best-...
“‘When the Rain Stops Falling’ is a triumph!  … The scenic design was stunning.”
-Michael M. Humel, editor-in-chief, Culture of the Senses
http://cultureofthesenses.com/when-the-rain-sto...

“In the ‘entertainment capital of the world,’ it’s rare to see theater that works in this register.  It’s satisfying in ways that go beyond just a good show…”
-Jacob Coakley, Las Vegas Weekly
www.lasvegasweekly.com/ae/stage/2016/nov/09/a-p...
 
Our Vegas CULTURE
Las Vegas is evolving still.  As the valley’s neon glow continues to be a beacon for cultural emigrants from across the nation, A Public Fit has actively sought out to embrace those looking for an innovative, professional, theatrical oasis in the literal desert.  Our aesthetic is unique, our vision unparalleled, our commitment unrivaled, our energy unmatched.   And while Las Vegas still draws the most talented people on the planet to perform in its spectacular strip extravaganzas, the need for cultural expression of a more connective nature still burns fiercely in the breasts of these creative super-stars.  A Public Fit exists to give voice to these yearnings, to harness the prolific desires of those artistic visionaries that land here in the valley.

story:
LipZinc 

LipZinc Theatre specialise in new writing that is current and provocative; visually stimulating material with a touch of glamour and girl power. The gang have performed in both UCD, with 'Daddy Was a Boogie Man' and most recently the Smock Allies Scene and Heard Festival with 'Sugar Mice'. We are hell bent on bringing innovative, new and alternative Irish writing to the forefront of Irish theatre and we need your help to get started!

story:
Who We Are

TWObigsteps is a contemporary dance collective driven to expanding art communities through a collaborative, creative process. Composed of emerging artists from diverse backgrounds and regions, we strive to generate multi-disciplinary creations, allowing concepts to be translated into various mediums.

What We Do

We use our dance practice as a platform for collaborative art to be made. This means, through performance and creation opportunities, we try to engage as many artists as possible to forge short and long term relationships. We hope to foster experiences that can continue to expand the small Vancouver arts community, and use our practice as a way to help others achieve their dreams.

Working with emerging, underrepresented artists of all disciplines and regions, allows for a greater community of dancers to be able to share their experiences. Choreography is a platform where we can translate experiences to create conversation, engage, and stimulate. We hope to achieve this by making a framework that is accessible to a broad community and malleable for translation; while challenging assumptions through dialogue beyond our familiar circles.

Our movement vocabulary is based on kinetics, physicality, and improvisational techniques; movement generation is discovered through an experimental lab manner called 'Playtime'. These measures form a sanction where all possibilities are valid and aims to deepen exploration of the spectrum of human interaction.

Why We Need You

As we are beginning to grow our roots in Vancouver, it can be difficult to gain funds without a  well established backing. Government funding (even with the countless hours of writing proposals) are not always guaranteed and are harder for start-ups and smaller companies to obtain.

We have had incredible company members, as well as collaborators, working for us for free to kick this thing off the ground. But it is time that they get paid!

This is why we need you, our community. We need you to help us take those small steps in order for us launch into larger ones (TWObigsteps haha). We hope to continue to give opportunities, grow and engage the community, and further Vancouver's artistic voice.

For more information on our story and values, read director Marissa Wong's interview with Dance Central Magazine.

Upcoming Season

What we have lined up so far...
Your contribution will help pay these amazing artist and opportunities!

  • West Wave 26 in San Francisco (October 1 & 7)
    'Veils' choreographed by Marissa Wong, and performed by Khala Brannigan, Katie Cassady, and Claire Fisher. Live music and sound with Jamie Bradbury
     
  • Dance in Vancouver on November 25
    'Surrendurance' choreographed by Marissa Wong in collaboration with Katie Cassady, Stephanie Cyr, Sarah Formosa, Andrew Haydock, and apprentice Marisa Christogeorge
     
  • New creation with guest choreographer (March 2018), film collaboration with Kyle Murdoch, and more...

Thank you for your constant support and engagement, we hope to continue to build our community this next year!

story:
Short Summary

The Haunting Hour will engage, cultivate and connect a new generation of theater-goers and art-lovers in an evening of raw, edgy and dangerous storytelling by some of Maine’s most gifted and celebrated artists.

With your help we will be able to bring six well known Maine author's work to the stage for the first time ever while also supporting local Maine artists. You will be part of a unique launching that will continue and grow annually. 

Authors:

Authors involved in this inaugural production include:

John Cariani is an award-winning actor and accomplished playwright. His play Almost, Maine is one the most frequently produced plays in America.

Tess Gerritsen is an international best selling author and award winner.  Her medical suspense novels inspired the TNT television series “Rizzoli & Isles”.

Ike Hamill is a Maine based novelist and short story writer who blends fast-paced horror with sci-fi, paranormal occult and suspense.

Chris Holm is an award-winning author. His novel, The Killing Kind, was named a New York Times Editors’ Choice and a Boston Globe Best Book of 2015.

Callie Kimball is a playwright who's work has been produced nationwide. Her themes range from historical dramas to socio-political comedies and futuristic dystopias.

What We Need & What You Get

Budget breakdown:

Levels of support and what you can get:

$1,000 and up

  • Your name or your business logo projected on stage prior to all performances.
  • Sponsorship recognition with your name or business logo in the event program, advertising & promotion
  • 4 Tickets to The Haunting Hour with private reception following the performance

​$500-$999

  • Your name or your business logo projected on stage prior to an individual performance
  • Sponsorship recognition with your name or business logo in the event program
  • 2 Tickets to The Haunting Hour

​$100-$499

  • Sponsorship recognition in the event program
  • 2 Tickets to The Haunting Hour

$1 - $99

  • Sponsorship recognition in the event program

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and that's ok, but it doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign and this show.

15% of all ticket sales go to the Falmouth Memorial Library Expansion Project

story:
Our team consists of director & scenic designer Shannon Knox, composers & performers Sharon Chohi Kim & Micaela Tobin, and librettist Cordelia Istel.

We presented the first iteration of the opera last year at the 2016 Edinburgh Festival Fringe to five-star reviews. This year, we are honored to be invited to present the opera on October 6 & 7 at Highways Performance Space in Santa Monica, CA. This time around, we wanted to ground the work more in the lived truths of our community, so we created a series of creative prompts through which survivors of domestic violence were invited to share their experiences anonymously. These moving reflections were used to inform the music and textural design of the opera.

Additionally, in conjunction with our mission to provide a space of healing and solidarity, we are offering a free voice-healing workshop in Los Angeles on Sunday, August 20th at 6pm at 'We Live In Space.'  

Finally, if we reach our goal of $10,000 we will donate a percentage of the proceeds to the Downtown Women's Center, which "provides women the combination of housing, medical and mental health services, social networks, and financial security needed to end homelessness."

We have been able to move forward with our project this far all on our own, but now we need your help. We need to raise $10,000 in order to pay for all of the moving pieces that producing live theatre requires. Specifically: costume and design, set, props, performers and production crew, renting a rehearsal space, sound equipment, projection and video documentation, and the fees associated with re-configuring the theater space in order to create the immersive show we envision. 

If you donate, we have an exciting tier of perks that include:

  • Private singing lessons from Micaela or Sharon!
  • A group voice workshop you and your friends!
  • Original artwork from the show created by our amazingly talented director, Shannon Knox!
  • An entire concert program of arias and musical theatre songs tailored to your taste!
  • Special mention in our program and website!

We are so excited to bring this piece to our community in Los Angeles. This premiere will be a culmination of almost two years of development! Please help us get to this final step of our journey with Unseal Unseam.

Help us reclaim the female narrative in traditional opera.

Help us tell stories that have not been told through a new blend of musical genres.

Help us create a place for healing and solidarity.

Help us tell this story.

Donate today.

Follow our progress here: www.unsealunseam.com

Get in touch: unsealunseam@gmail.com

Join our mailing list: http://eepurl.com/c0q2mT

story:
Short Summary

A fully realized, written, connected, fun, yet meaningful evening of entertainment and charitable giving. That is what DDD is all about. 

For the last Ten years, I've been using my BFA in a way that I never imagined. The art of drag has allowed me to play some pivotal roles that I never thought would be possible. In addition to that, I've been blessed with an awesome fundraising platform. Every year on my birthday, I've put together a fundraiser for Broadway Cares and other local charities. Since this is the final year of my twenties, I want to make this fundraiser the biggest one I've ever done. I can't do that without your help. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The grand total for what we need will be in the neighborhood of $4,000. This all goes towards Renting the theatre, fees for the musicians, costuming, marketing, performance rights, and technical design for the show. 
  • Donors will have a few great perks that come with your donation depending on what level you reach. Perks like a private meet & greet after the show, a private invited rehearsal that lets you see behind the scenes where the magic happens, a personal thank you from Desiré herself, producers credit in the shows playbill, a huge discount on tickets, and more!
  • If we are unable to reach our fundraising goal. We will split the funds that were raised and send them to the charities that we had intended to send our profits to. 

The Impact

Like I said earlier, there is a huge disconnect in this city between the Theatre community, and the Drag community. If we can put this show together, I whole heartedly believe that it will be a step in the right direction of reconnecting the two. More importantly, it would help raise money that these organizations desperately need. 

To be 110% honest, I know there are risks to any sort of project like this. My background in creative problem solving, & finding solutions will help us overcome hurdles and challenges along the way. With your help, my team & I will be able to continue to make this show a reality. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us out by sharing this page and getting the word out. 

Like Elaine Stritch said, "I don't think there's any thrill in the world like doing work you're good at." 

This cabaret fundraiser will be a show unlike anything anyone has ever seen in this city. Let's work together to make not only my dream come true, but to set a new fundraising record for Desiré and her team! We must work hard at work worth doing. My heart and soul is going into this project. All we need is you. Join our team. You won't regret a single penny!

story:
NC Dance Collective is a collaboration of unparalleled modern dance leaders who have merged organically as a platform to celebrate our talents. The show directors are Hilary Jordan and Sarah Molaro, both who hold extensive backgrounds in dance, performance and show creation. The larger collective consists of many long time dance teachers, choreographers and strong, experienced dancers who are excited to develop a deep and memorable event.

Our talents demand that we show ourselves to the community, that we let ourselves be seen as the artists that we are, and that we deliver our hearts through our passion to dance.

Healing through art begins and continues as we embrace our abilities and create new pathways for relaying our art. The choice to perform also supports the essential venues where art can safely unravel. To collaborate cohesively also models healing for delivering our best selves in a proud and honorable offering that gives us all an opportunity to embody our moving art more deeply and in a supported way.

Our needs for this show are very simple, yet still require your help. Tickets will cover many expenses, so this fund is for our Dream Come True budget:

Your donations will support:

ACTUAL COSTS

professional venue for three shows,

lights,

sound,

marketing,

videographer,

photographer,

DREAM COME TRUE FUNDS:

choreographer stipends,

dancer stipends,

producer and director stipends,

musician stipends,

rehearsal space rental,

costumes,

flowers,

ancillary costs of productions,

Thank you for your generosity and support as we take another leap. With the bigger vision of evoking inspiration in our audiences we align with our truest expressions of our dance art. Your support allows our community to realize movement as both visual art and powerful therapy for artists and audience members. Your help ripples out to immeasurable pools of love, inspiration, and artistic prosperity, right here in Nevada County. Thank you for supporting your local movement artists.

Blessings and Reverence-

Sarah and Hilary and the Nevada County Dance Collective

The larger collective consists of many long time dance teachers, choreographers and strong, experienced dancers who are excited to develop a deep and memorable event.Our talents demand that we show ourselves to the community, that we let ourselves be seen as the artists that we are, and that we deliver our hearts through our passion to dance.Healing through art begins and continues as we embrace our abilities and create new pathways for relaying our art. The choice to perform also supports the essential venues where art can safely unravel. To collaborate cohesively also models healing for delivering our best selves in a proud and honorable offering that gives us all an opportunity to embody our moving art more deeply and in a supported way.Our needs for this show are very simple, yet still require your help. Tickets will cover many expenses, so this fund is for our Dream Come True budget:Your donations will support:ACTUAL COSTSprofessional venue for three shows,lights,sound,marketing,videographer,photographer,DREAM COME TRUE FUNDS:choreographer stipends,dancer stipends,producer and director stipends,musician stipends,rehearsal space rental,costumes,flowers,ancillary costs of productions,Thank you for your generosity and support as we take another leap. With the bigger vision of evoking inspiration in our audiences we align with our truest expressions of our dance art. Your support allows our community to realize movement as both visual art and powerful therapy for artists and audience members. Your help ripples out to immeasurable pools of love, inspiration, and artistic prosperity, right here in Nevada County. Thank you for supporting your local movement artists.Blessings and Reverence-Sarah and Hilary and the Nevada County Dance Collective

story:
REFUGEE 

A new play by Milan Dragicevich

Music by Tim Eriksen

The Shea theater, Turners Falls Ma 

October 19th-21st 7:30pm, Sunday 22nd at 2:30pm  

The cast of REFUGEE, which premiered at the UMass Fine Arts Center in December of 2016, directed by Serbian director Nikita Milivojevic and choreographed by his partner Amalia Bennet, has been given the opportunity to remount it at the Shea Theater in Turners Falls, in October 2017. It will be a new iteration, welcoming new cast members and new design team.  The cast includes some returning members and alumni students and faculty from the university and professionals from the local area.  Music is written and orchestrated by Tim Eriksen a local grammy nominated musician.

Milan Dragicevich  (Playwright) is an Associate Professor of Theater at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. His specialty areas are performance, rhetoric, playwriting, harnessing the power of classical techniques in creating contemporary works that resonate with today’s complex world. As an actor, he has performed with numerous nationally acclaimed theaters, including the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Hartford Stage, Pasadena Playhouse, and Northern New England Repertory Theatre. He has become increasingly interested in using his performance background to craft original new works, plays that are physical, actor-driven, combining live music, muscular language, an epic sweep and bold staging. He grew up in Los Angeles, to immigrant parents, both refugees, which fueled his interest in exploring how cultural background, place, ancestral echoes, and capricious destiny merge to shape identity and sense of self—themes explored in his new play REFUGEE.

WE NEED YOUR HELP! 

Contributors to the REFUGEE remount production will help bring an important story to audiences throughout Western Massachusetts, as the play traces the journey of a refugee family, one that is split and scattered across three continents. Across generations and far distances, the family members attempt to piece together fragments of their faded bonds. This story is played out every week on the nightly news, as refugees pour out of conflict zones, staggering across deserts, or floating on rickety boats, in mass exodus, often resulting in families torn asunder, flung on distant shores.

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT?

REFUGEE is loosely based on the historical sojourn of Dragina Kalanj Dragicevich (playwright’s mother), who came to the El Shatt camp on the Sinai as a teenage girl, the beginning of an epic odyssey that thwarted a return to her native land—and family—until 25 years later. The play explores the memory of family, the search for identity and acceptance in a new land, as well as the myriad meanings of refugee and how that experience shapes one’s destiny—and creates generational aftershocks. The play’s events will unfurl ironically against the backdrop of Syrian and Iraqi refugees flowing across today’s Serbia. As such, the play provides much needed perspective and understanding of the “journey” of the refugee.

REFUGEE generated enthusiastic “street buzz” during its premiere at the UMass Fine Arts Center in December 2016. It became a hot ticket after its “premiere” performance and quickly sold out its entire two-week run. Many people were unable to see the production and this has spurred our production company to continue the journey at the larger venue—the Shea Theater Arts Center in Turners Falls, MA. REFUGEE is based on true events. It is a story for our turbulent times, as we seek to understand the plight, displacement, and fate of the “refugee.” We want to share this story with a wider community and help launch community discussions on this important subject, one that touches us all.

THE BREAKDOWN BUDGET

We are an independent theater group, therefore we do not have the funds to make this project possible which is where you all come in. We are asking for your generosity and good will to make this dream possible.  As the saying goes “ It takes a village… to raise a theater.”

We are asking on Indiegogo for $10,200. Here is  how we for see the break down of where your contributions will go: 

  • Rental space of the Shea Theater in Turners Falls, MA

             $2,500

  • Rental space of Bramble Hill Farm, barn studio in Amherst, MA

               $200

  • Music by Tim Eriksen

              $2,500

  • Set and lighting design by Tim Holcomb    

               $5,000                      

This includes: 

  • Lighting Rental 
  • Technical labor 
  • Materials 
  • Sounds 
  • Props 

This amount will get us into The Shea Theater and off our feet.  We are asking you to help us fulfill our goal so that hopefully you can come see us perform!

This budget is a little under half of what we need to be fully funded when all is said and done. This amount is to get us started. We are hoping to get the word out and get people to come and see this production. Anything helps! 

 

WE HAVE PERKS! THEY ARE EXCITING!   

You can listen to the cast sing the songs featured in the production. How about a tee shirt? Or Signed poster? Have you ever thought about becoming an executive producer? Well here is your chance! Maybe you want your name in the playbill… Well nows you can! How about a hot date to the theater? We got you covered with 2 ticket. Perks are located to  right of our page. Check them out! You wont be sorry. 

If we don’t reach our goal, the money we do make will fund the most important part of this production the cost of rental space at the Shea theater Arts Center and hopefully we will have enough to  pay our professional designers and musicians. We hope that the rest of the cost will come from ticket sales!  We are confident (at best) that with YOUR help our goal will be actualized! 

COULD WE POSSIBLY HAVE ANY PROBLEMS?… 

The production of REFUGEE is now an independent production. We are no longer under the auspices and resource-support of the University of Massachusetts, as we strive to take the play to outside venues and locations. This means we are responsible for fully financing and funding our production which includes: 

  • Rental of theater space
  • Set and lighting design costs 
  • Payment of labor/technicians
  • Rehearsal studio rental
  • Live music
  • Marketing and advertising
  • Payment of Actors 
  • Stage management

 

Though it is admittedly a bit daunting to be our own producers, we are up for this challenge. The cast members meet regularly to organize and implement a disciplined plan,dividing specific duties, updating progress, discussing areas that need further work and refinement. The energy and commitment is inspiring!

The company is intrepid, tireless, and creative in their march toward the Shea Theater! We believe in the story, the adventurous theatrical aesthetic that accompanies it, and its poignant relevance to our times. We know the production will generate community conversation. Moreover, while it is more challenging to self-produce, we believe the ultimate reward and satisfaction comes from following and implementing our creative vision, from our initial steps—to the buzz of opening night! Thanks for listening.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP US OUT! 

So now that you have read that book of information, but you can’t break the bank… Don’t worry there are plenty of other options for you to show your support. 

SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN (the most important thing you could do…ever) share it on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Email, Snap chat, snail mail … we don’t care how you do it as long as the word gets out, we are forever grateful!

LIKE our Facebook Page @refugeetheshea

Buy tickets at www.refugeeplay.brownpapertickets.com

Email us refugeeplay@gmail.com if you have questions, concerns or want to get involved. 

SPREAD THE WORD.  Don’t just talk about it! Tell the world about REFUGEE. 

So now we are done with the pitch! We hope that you can donate, share , like, and see. This story is a beautiful one, that must continue.  We are so grateful and appreciative! Thank you. 

- Production Team from REFUGEE

story:
Summary

Mental Health is a topic close to my heart, both for my own struggles and that of the ones of the people around me. I’m worried about health cuts, and the way the number of beds in hospitals keeps diminishing, the way people aren’t able to access information about mental health and how no one is clearly talking about it.

We need to change this.

With In Search of Myself I would like to bust myths and inform people while creating a conversation that will continue in the long-term.

I want to make sure people with mental health problems are represented and can speak up about it.

Every single contribution to this play will help me do that.

Contributions will go towards making a step up in the quality of the play, professional actors will be properly trained and prepared for the roles with continuous contact with mental health professionals and sensitivity readers.

You are the only ones who can make this happen.

Our dates for this run are the 25th to the 29th of August at The London Improv Theatre

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise £1500, this will help us cover the costs of marketing (mainly flyers and posters) and covering the fees for the actual run.

Preparation is key. The amount raised will make sure the team can book out their time during the fringe run and that our actors can dedicate themselves to research and preparation without distraction.

Send us...

…£3 and we’ll thank you on Twitter
…£5 and we’ll thank you on Twitter and follow you. 
…£10 and you’ll receive the above and a thank you on our website and on our Facebook page.
…£25 and we’ll thank you on Twitter, follow you on Twitter, you’ll receive a thank you on our website and on our Facebook page. You’ll also receive 2 tickets to our show at The Camden Fringe.
…£35 and you’ll receive the above and a signed poster & a programme.
…£125 and you’ll receive 2 tickets to our show at The Camden Fringe and you can meet the team.
…£500 and we’ll take you and a friend out for dinner and you’ll receive 2 tickets to our show at The Camden Fringe
…£1500 and you’ll receive 2 tickets for all future productions of Distracting Cats Productions (former Literal Productions)

We will offer more perks when we have reached the milestones of £250, £500 and £1000!

 

The Impact

Your contribution will help us achieve higher standards for the play in terms of development, people involved, and props.

It will make it easier to reach more people and foster an informed conversation with the audience, so to make sure that we represent the many people who get diagnosed every day, and deal with bipolar in their daily lives. 

We need to keep the conversation going about mental health.

We are a dedicated team who all have other jobs on the side that keep us alive.

The run at The Camden Fringe offers us a chance to make a step forward towards creating theatre full time and will open up doors for us to expand onto more and more meaningful projects.

 

We fully appreciate that we may not hit our target for this campaign but any funds we do secure will be put towards making this show happen. We are grateful for any donations received!

Putting up a show about mental health is not easy, especially because of how unique everyone's brain and experience is. A lot of research has gone into it and is still on the horizon, we have had great help from charities and people who have given us testimonials, and we want to make sure that we get their voices heard. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that you might not be able to contribute towards In Search of Myself. But you can help us spreading the word about the show and this campaign on social media platforms (you can use the Indiegogo share features) and follow/like our accounts.

Facebook
https://www.facebook.com/SearchMyselfLDN/

Twitter
https://twitter.com/SearchMyselfLDN

story:
Hi, I'm Jasmine Long owner, and CEO of Jaz'Rii Productions, Writer-Director of the stage play  "When it all goes down". I'm 27 years of age born and raised in Rhode Island where I fell in love with acting at a young age. I've acted through middle school and high school I enjoyed acting out stories that have a meaning. I attended an Art University where I fell in love with writing, producing, directing stories that have a meaning.
  

   " When it all goes down" is the first stage play written when starting Jaz'Rii productions. It means a great deal not just because it's a first, but more so the message they story tells. This Production is important because it helps local artist broadening their horizons of thinking through the expressions of live theater.
  

   Having your support will help Jaz'Rii Productions achieve the first of many more productions. The amazing thing is your support is not only helping put on a full production, but you will be helping with giving a local artist a platform to live out their dream. 

To successfully put on this production it will cost $15,000 
What the funds will be used for:
1. Securing Venue
2. Set Design and Construction
3. Marketing and Advertising 
4. Promo
5. Costumes and Prop
  If we are unable to reach our goal of 15,000 we still plan on using the funds we have raised to put on the best production possible

You get a Perk! You get a Perk! 
Your choice of a signed DVD from the Live show to a signed photo of the cast, signed souvenir book, Merchandise. It gets better Tickets to the Live stage play " When it all goes down"  could be given out!
This production is valuable to the world because it gives people a different insight into a situation they may be going through. "When it all goes down " is a feel-good story it will bring people through many emotions and leave them with a message of love. With support, Jaz'Rii Productions is given a key to open the door to opportunity an opportunity to bring the show to your city.
 

    I can go on and on about how great this production will be, and how the message needs to put out in the world. However; like most amazing productions there are risk & challenges we could come across. Starting with securing the venue Marketing, advertising could be our biggest challenge making sure people from ages 18-65+ know about this great production. Our team here at Jaz'Rii productions are ready to take on all challenges thrown at us. With staff members, cast members aging from 20's to 55+ willing to help in another area of production gives us some advantage in reaching our target audience.  

Other Ways You Can Help

    Now it's understood if you are not able to donate, but still, want to help make this production successful. There are ways you can make a difference you are able to spread the word by sharing it all over. If you need help in different ways to share and get the word out go to Indiegogo share tools

story:
We are...

New Yorkers forming part of Gamelan Dharma Swara, Gotham’s hometown Balinese gamelan ensemble. A collective of friends and Balinese performing arts enthusiasts, we come from all walks of life - we might be architectural designers, artists, civil engineers, opera singers, journalists, wildlife researchers, designers, or software developers - and when we’re not at our day jobs, we make the long schlep to our studio in Long Island City and work hard together for our passion for Balinese dance. 

Since Dharma Swara's inception over 20 years ago, the goal for musicians and dancers alike has been to inspire wonder with exhilarating experiential performances that cultivate a community of learning, creativity, collaboration, and dialogue among artists and audiences.

 

Your contribution will make it possible! 

 

For Dharma Swara Dance to thrive, we seek resources to freely rehearse, hold public workshops, collaborate with other artists, take on ambitious projects, and perform more often. As a non-profit organisation, we survive through the hard work of our members and beyond grants, through the ongoing generosity of friends and donors. We are eternally grateful for this support which allows us to not only exist as a dance troupe, but also to continue our development in skill and artistry.

What we need

The standard stuff

  • Studio rental - Dharma Swara hires a space in Long Island City, but during busy periods the dance squad often needs to seek out additional rehearsal space, because practice, practice, practice.
  • Accounting, insurances, and many similarly fun things
  • Website management
  • Marketing material and printing
  • Truck rental(s) - our full ensemble performances involve transporting around 25 people, cartons of costumes and a boatload of beautiful, handcrafted instruments from Bali. 
  • Performance acoutrements - flowers are expensive!

Going the extra mile

  • Performing at out-of-town events and festivals
  • Engagement of choreographers for collaboration with on new works
  • Professional photography for documentation and marketing
  • Bringing artists to New York for short-term residencies
  • Workshops with Balinese artists and teachers

We are looking to increase our skills and repertoire with some of Bali's preeminent teachers. To do so, we need to travel to these artists who are often based in other parts of the United States ... and hopefully one day, even to Bali. Conversely, we would also bring artists to New York for workshops and short-term residencies. All this to dance even better and bring more works to our audiences!

  • New costumes and accessories 

An important part of our performances are the beautiful costumes. These intricate and ornate pieces are paramount and often unique to the story of each dance piece - they provide much of the awe that is the visual feast of our performances. These costumes can become quite costly and usually, can only be sourced in Bali. Help us look the part and also impossibly gorgeous! 

 

Will you help to keep Dharma Swara dancing by making a contribution today?

We can't do this alone. Support us today and help us to keep calm and dance on!


Support us and feel the warm glow of knowing that Balinese dance can continue to be shared in our part of the world. 

Contributing is as easy as pressing the big, pink BACK IT button at the top of the page and submitting any donation you wish - no amount is too small!

Alternatively, there are great perks on offer should you choose to receive a memento of your participation in this project. Whether it's a recording by Dharma Swara, lessons in gamelan or dance, or you simply want to increase your street cred with a DS tote bag - all perks are prepared with love! 

No matter the level of your contribution - you (and the world) will know about our thankfulness via mentions on our social media accounts and a permanent place on our website Wall of Gratitude. 

Other ways you can help

Support isn’t always monetary. If you know of a fellow NYC arts supporter or gamelan enthusiast, consider sharing our campaign - https://igg.me/at/DS-DANCE-SQUAD - with them and on your social channels.

Help us get the word out and keep bringing Balinese dance to NYC audiences (and beyond)!

Find us on the world wide web:
Instagram  |  Twitter  |  Facebook

Love, Dharma Swara Dance. Om Swastiastu.
John, Miranda, Sonora, Stephanie, Alexandra, Sasi, Jaclyn, Ezra and the entire Gamelan Dharma Swara family!

www.dharmaswara.org

_________________________________________

How the sausage is made

If you are still reading this (Hello! Thanks for staying on the ride), here are further details of our story.

We're on our way!
Our dance squad has come a long way and we are excited about future seasons and projects. While we have secured funding from Dance/NYC's Dance Advancement Fund for the 2018-2019 period, but we are in need of an extra boost in order to achieve all of our goals. 

So far this year we have completed two rewarding intensive workshops with visiting Balinese artists in Massachusetts (I Nyoman Catra) and California (I Made ‘Cat’ Suteja). Our aim is to see out 2018 with at least one additional trip to revisit our friends Gamelan Sekar Jaya in Oakland CA, and further, to work with highly sought-after Balinese dancer (and our former teacher) Shoko Yamamuro on future dance pieces both, traditional and original contemporary. 

Having successfully raised over $8000 two years ago on Indiegogo to reach our goal of owning our very own gamelan instruments from Bali, we are now enthusiastically sharing the growth of our group with you on this campaign. 

More about Gamelan Dharma Swara

Gamelan Dharma Swara (DS) is an ambitious, artist-led 501(c)3 organization based in New York City. Dedicated to performing traditional Balinese gamelan music/dance and new works by leading Balinese and non-Balinese composers, DS has earned critical acclaim from national and international press and has established a reputation as one of the leading gamelan groups in North America.

DS has collaborated with Momenta Quartet, the NOW Ensemble, and with some of Bali’s leading artists, including Dewa Ketut Alit, Gusti Sudarta, Made Sidia, I Gusti Nyoman Darta, and I Made Bandem. The ensemble has performed in top New York venues, including Basilica Hudson, Lincoln Center, The Asia Society, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, MoMA, The New Museum, Symphony Space, LaMama, The Stone, Japan Society, Roulette, Joe’s Pub, and Le Poisson Rouge.  DS has also performed at Princeton, Bucknell, Rider, New York, New Jersey City and Yale Universities, and the University of Richmond.

The ensemble has commissioned works from Balinese and North American composers, including Dewa Ketut Alit, Gusti Sudarta, Vivian Fung, Matthew Welch, Joel Mellin, Richard Marriott, and Andrew McGraw. DS has won grants from the National Endowment for the Arts, the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, the Mid-Atlantic Arts Fund, and the Asian American Arts Alliance, among others.

We are dedicated to sharing the inspiration and beauty of traditional Balinese dance together with the exploration and development of the art from in our New York City. We believe in what we do and invite you to come along on our journey. If you love dance and Balinese culture or have any curiosity, please consider donating and help share it with the world - TERIMA KASIH!

Love, Dharma Swara Dance (...for real this time!)

 

Video by Massimo Biolcati, Miranda Danusugondo, and Stephanie Ho
Many thanks to Desmond White Photography
story_txt:
We are...New Yorkers forming part of Gamelan Dharma Swara, Gotham’s hometown Balinese gamelan ensemble. A collective of friends and Balinese performing arts enthusiasts, we come from all walks of life - we might be architectural designers, artists, civil engineers, opera singers, journalists, wildlife researchers, designers, or software developers - and when we’re not at our day jobs, we make the long schlep to our studio in Long Island City and work hard together for our passion for Balinese dance. Since Dharma Swara's inception over 20 years ago, the goal for musicians and dancers alike has been to inspire wonder with exhilarating experiential performances that cultivate a community of learning, creativity, collaboration, and dialogue among artists and audiences. Your contribution will make it possible!  For Dharma Swara Dance to thrive, we seek resources to freely rehearse, hold public workshops, collaborate with other artists, take on ambitious projects, and perform more often. As a non-profit organisation, we survive through the hard work of our members and beyond grants, through the ongoing generosity of friends and donors. We are eternally grateful for this support which allows us to not only exist as a dance troupe, but also to continue our development in skill and artistry.What we needThe standard stuff
Studio rental - Dharma Swara hires a space in Long Island City, but during busy periods the dance squad often needs to seek out additional rehearsal space, because practice, practice, practice.
Accounting, insurances, and many similarly fun things
Website management
Marketing material and printing
Truck rental(s) - our full ensemble performances involve transporting around 25 people, cartons of costumes and a boatload of beautiful, handcrafted instruments from Bali. 
Performance acoutrements - flowers are expensive!
Going the extra mile
Performing at out-of-town events and festivals
Engagement of choreographers for collaboration with on new works
Professional photography for documentation and marketing
Bringing artists to New York for short-term residencies
Workshops with Balinese artists and teachers
We are looking to increase our skills and repertoire with some of Bali's preeminent teachers. To do so, we need to travel to these artists who are often based in other parts of the United States ... and hopefully one day, even to Bali. Conversely, we would also bring artists to New York for workshops and short-term residencies. All this to dance even better and bring more works to our audiences!New costumes and accessories An important part of our performances are the beautiful costumes. These intricate and ornate pieces are paramount and often unique to the story of each dance piece - they provide much of the awe that is the visual feast of our performances. story:
About Us

Joon Dance is a professional dance company based at the Torch Theatre in Milford Haven. The
company creates touring performances, specialising in performance for young people. High-quality dance in the community is at the heart of our mission: every work by Joon Dance includes an element of involvement with audiences and participants. As well as participatory dance projects for children and young people, we run intensive workshops year-round and provide training and mentoring for young artists developing their careers.


Our goals are to bring dance to everyone - dance as personal expression, dance as activism, dance for health, dance to connect, dance for social change. TONGUES furthers our model of high-quality professional dance work in the community, working with a new age group (young adults aged 14-21) using a model of work devised over a number of previous projects and piloted in a small test last summer.

 

About Tongues

The tongue is where the brain and the body can be most tangibly felt to intersect. It is the
muscle with which we express our thoughts. It is also the place where expression can be blocked, we may be tongue-tied. The word ‘tongue’ conjures up ideas like language, identity, and sense of self. It is central to communication and understanding; without language and self-expression how can we create healthy friendships and keep ourselves emotionally and physically safe in sexual relationships? These issues are vital to supporting young people to have a voice and to use it, and to have a body and use it, and to connect the two.

TONGUES is inherently Welsh and connects young people from rural (Brecon) and urban (Cardiff) environments addressing ideas and identities emerging from these different experiences. With TONGUES, we are targeting an age group (14-21 years) not often catered to with dance and performance, and where the young people's relationship with their physical body and with the idea of ‘self’ is transient, changing and evolving.

Tongues is supported by Arts Council Wales, Dawns Powys Dance, Rubicon Dance, Chapter (Cardiff) and Theatr Brycheiniog (Brecon). We are seeking additional support to complete our project budget.

 

What We Need 

TONGUES is supported by Arts Council Wales, Dawns Powys Dance, Chapter (Cardiff) and Theatr Brycheiniog (Brecon). We are seeking additional support to complete our project budget. Your support will enable us to offer these workshops to young people in both Cardiff and Brecon free of charge, so that the project is accessible to everyone regardless of circumstance. 

We have some great rewards for you including special cast thank-you videos, t-shirts and meet and greets with the team - take a look below! For rewards including t-shirts, please message us with your size and colour choices. 

In addition, the first ten donors at any level will receive a special reward video revealing the research behind TONGUES. Watch our social media to see the project unfold!

 

The Impact

We know from our past work that dance boosts self esteem, improves team work and
communication skills and is good for physical health. Spoken word is a valuable tool for teaching young people to be articulate, creative and to speak out about their beliefs and feelings.


By working with the young people in a series of intensive week-long workshop programmes, we will create a performance with the young people that is unique to them and expresses their thoughts and feelings on topics that are meaningful to them, and perform the piece at a local theatre. Our experience tells us that learning creative skills and working towards a performance shared with others requires teamwork and negotiation skills, and leads to increased confidence and improved self-esteem associated with making something personal and exploring new ways to use the voice and body.

 

Risks & Challenges

TONGUES builds on our previous work and we are working with an excellent team of dance artists and creative practitioners to bring high-quality participation and performance work to the community. We are also supported by our project partners to reach young people in each area and make sure we have a great group to work with in each venue. 

The project will go ahead if we don't reach our total funding goal but in a reduced form, which we would obviously prefer not to have to do. By supporting this project you will be ensuring it is free at the point of access for all who want to take part, making sure TONGUES is open to the widest range of people possible. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please do share this campaign with your friends, and if you're in either Cardiff or Brecon this summer come along to one of our performances!

[images are by Grace Gelder]

story:
“Oh ye Gods…Alas… Why call I on things so weak for help?”
-Hecuba, Trojan Women

In perhaps the first recorded piece of theater in the Western canon that passes the Bechdel test, Euripides’ Trojan Women tells a story of women who are stronger than gods. Trojan Women offers an unapologetic and powerful look at the act of community-building during times of grief, the gendered violence of war, and the messy aftermath of both real and mythic Greek conquests. Written circa 415 BCE and set immediately after the Trojan War, Trojan Women follows in real time the lives of nine remaining Trojan women (and two Greek men) as their city is captured. Project Nongenue digs up, reworks, and breathes life into this historical text through movement, modern and classical language, and intersectional storytelling.

At Project Nongenue, we believe classical stories have, over many centuries, shaped our understandings of identity, justice and morality. By centering marginalized voices and using a contemporary lens to challenge the archetypes, stereotypes and lessons these foundational stories teach, we examine the way these timeless themes continue to exist in ourselves.

We recognize that changing the world through independent classical theater may seem like a wild dream, but with your help, it can be a reality.

We know we cannot do this alone. Participating in a festival is a big step for our company, and with big steps come big price tags: registration fees, advertising, theater rentals, set and costume design. Perhaps most importantly, however, is Project Nongenue's commitment to compensating our actors and creative team for their work. After all production costs are covered, the profit we make goes back to the artists (who, in LA blackbox theater, are often unpaid for their work).  Your contributions will directly support young artists working for excellence and social change. The more we raise here, the more we can give back to our artists. 

Our company is still only just beginning. But in my short time at the artistic helm of this group (and after two unmistakably successful productions), I can assure you of a couple things: I have never been exposed to artists of such talent and courage and heart as I have been at Project Nongenue. When you tilt the focus of narrative onto those people who have been systematically excluded from many of our most foundational stories, the world does change. It could change for an audience member who sees Helen of Troy for the first time as a nuanced, three-dimensional person instead of a villainous seductress or doe-eyed victim. It could change for an actor in the room who is asked to expand her shoulders to play a Hero and realizes she has spent most of her life trying to take up as little physical space as possible. These may be small moments, but string enough small moments together and you have a cultural shift. Women, people of color, queer people, people of different sizes- we all deserve to be Heroes and we all deserve to be Ingenues. 

We want to be a part of this change with you. Your donations will go such an enormously long way, as artists making a living wage for their work is rare thing. If finances are tight right now, however, there are other options. Come to the show, share this campaign with your friends, help us fill up our seats at Fringe. Make some noise for progressive classical theater.

Thank you so much for your support, and please feel free to reach out to learn more by checking out our website (www.projectnongenue.org) or emailing us (projectnongenue@gmail.com).

Let's break open the confines of the ingenue to see what is revealed, and what new we can build.

Love,

Olivia Buntaine

Artistic Director of Project Nongenue
