story:
I'm Lyralen Kaye. I'm a queer inner city multicultural activist, actor, award-winning writer, director, likes-to-cause-trouble person.  After Trump was elected, I convinced my partner to sell our condo and move to Canada.

Oh, if it was only that easy!

The immigration process forced me to confront my deepest personal secret, and the ridiculousness of how I handled that is...well, isn't it the human story?

My team-Marc, Jude, Teddy, Dave and Caitlin--and I are running this campaign to be able to take this story-with its comedy and revelations , with its marriage struggles and amazing discoveries of kindness--on the road. I believe that telling the truth about ourselves, and laughing, are ways to connect in a time of so much fragmentation. I want to be part of creating a new story, one in which we connect to each other, tell our secrets, and think about the walls we really need to take down.  We make art to see and find ourselves. And we contribute to the world, because, "it just takes a small group of concerned citizens to change it ."

With your donation, we will perform the show in Boston, Brighton UK, and Hollywood (we've also entered to perform in Vancouver, Providence and Melbourne). All our donors matter to us...and since we are so focused on community-building, we just keep adding connection to our perks. ..more community, more involvement. We're all about fun, but also about really knowing each other and each other's stories.

Each production costs somewhere between $4-7K, so our goal is to raise at least $16K in the next 6 weeks. That money goes to marketing, venues, to purchase music and gobo lighting effects, to the artists and crew, and to the festivals that make performance possible. (*And for those of you who are more visual in nature, pie charts of the budgets are at the end.)

This project means a great deal to me because I'm outing myself-not as gay, everyone knows I'm gay-but as a person with hidden struggles and secrets. The whole process of immigration made  me determined to be much more transparent about who I am, because the saying, "You're only as sick as your secrets," seemed relevant, but less so than, "No one can own you if you own who you are."

This transparency takes the show into the personal and then far beyond...because if I connect with you, with my community, I open the door for you to connect with me, too. And I live for that. I live for the moments we come together...and boy do we ever need to come together right now .

We know that raising money and inspiring people to invest both financially and emotionally in a project is a challenge. But since many of us have worked together before at Another Country-Jude since its inception, Marc since 2010 as a producer and production manager, and Caitlin as a director-we understand the nature of grassroots work. We have a history of teaching tolerance and bringing large numbers of people to reach a common goal. We think we can do it again!

We’re asking everyone to give what they can—and we have perks to express our gratitude. We really thank you, whether you can give $250 or $10. We’re reaching out to everyone we know, because if 1600 people give $10, then our village has supported us. Of course, if 4 people do $4000, that is equally true.

We do need A LOT of people to give $10 (think grassroots, of the people), so please use the IndieGogo share tools (the icons next to the back it button), and let people know what we're doing. We would so appreciate it! And of course, if you’re one of the people who can do more, we appreciate that, too! 

Thank you so much for coming to our page and being interested in our story. Resist! And tell people who you are. We have to keep being human to each other.

Be well,

Lyralen, Jude, Teddy, Marc, Caitlin & Dave

PS-Check out our extras page. It’s really fun! That's where we post extra vlogs and videos.

 

www.anothercountryproductions.com

www.lyralenkaye.com

_______________________________________________________________

___________________________________________________________________

____________________________________________________________________

__________________________________________________________________

With your donation, we will perform the show in Boston, Brighton UK, and Hollywood (we've also entered to perform in Vancouver, Providence and Melbourne). All our donors matter to us...and since we are so focused on community-building, we just keep adding connection to our perks. ..more community, more involvement. We're all about fun, but also about really knowing each other and each other's stories.
Each production costs somewhere between $4-7K, so our goal is to raise at least $16K in the next 6 weeks. That money goes to marketing, venues, to purchase music and gobo lighting effects, to the artists and crew, and to the festivals that make performance possible. (*And for those of you who are more visual in nature, pie charts of the budgets are at the end.)
This project means a great deal to me because I'm outing myself-not as gay, everyone knows I'm gay-but as a person with hidden struggles and secrets. The whole process of immigration made  me determined to be much more transparent about who I am, because the saying, "You're only as sick as your secrets," seemed relevant, but less so than, "No one can own you if you own who you are."
This transparency takes the show into the personal and then far beyond...because if I connect with you, with my community, I open the door for you to connect with me, too. And I live for that. I live for the moments we come together...and boy do we ever need to come together right now .
We know that raising money and inspiring people to invest both financially and emotionally in a project is a challenge. But since many of us have worked together before at Another Country-Jude since its inception, Marc since 2010 as a producer and production manager, and Caitlin as a director-we understand the nature of grassroots work. We have a history of teaching tolerance and bringing large numbers of people to reach a common goal. We think we can do it again!
We’re asking everyone to give what they can—and we have perks to express our gratitude. We really thank you, whether you can give $250 or $10. We’re reaching out to everyone we know, because if 1600 people give $10, then our village has supported us. Of course, if 4 people do $4000, that is equally true.
We do need A LOT of people to give $10 (think grassroots, of the people), so please use the IndieGogo share tools (the icons next to the back it button), and let people know what we're doing. We would so appreciate it! And of course, if you’re one of the people who can do more, we appreciate that, too! 
Thank you so much for coming to our page and being interested in our story. Resist! And tell people who you are. We have to keep being human to each other.
Be well,
Lyralen, Jude, Teddy, Marc, Caitlin & Dave
PS-Check out our extras page. It’s really fun! That's where we post extra vlogs and videos.
 
www.anothercountryproductions.com
www.lyralenkaye.com

story:
Who we are

Guessworks started life back in 2015 with a five star reviewed production of The Star Rover, made in collaboration with our friends Shedload Theatre (‘The sort of show that leaves you gasping for words that never fully materialise’ ★★★★★ edfringereview). We then performed a small scale production of Pirandello’s ‘The Man With the Flower in His Mouth’ at the Maddermarket Emerson Studio in Norwich. After a brief hiatus for life, love and drama school we are now back with new ideas and a mission statement to make theatre that is full of heart.

The show we’ve made

Our new show is called Son of Jim and it’s the real story of the discovery of a piece of buried family treasure. It goes a little something like this:

’One day, Dave was rooting through a desk drawer in his parents’ house when he came across an brown A4 paper envelope...he opened it to find a story, written three decades ago, by his dad...’ Thus began the strange journey into the mind of a parent, and a mission to fulfil the dreams of an unpublished primary school teacher.

It’s weird, it’s wonderful, it’s full of imagination, and it’s an affirmation of the bonds that tie fathers and sons together.

Here’s why we need you

We have our Edinburgh venue in place. We now need to raise the money to get the show there. Guessworks, like 99.9% of theatre companies, is a financially impoverished theatre company. Would we have it any other way? Yes, yes we would. But until the National Theatre comes knocking we rely on the support of friends to keep us alive!

We have a £3000 crowdfunding target.

This just covers our venue hire for the month (£2970), and the rest of our expenditure (Fringe registration, marketing materials, production costs) is self funded.

Every pound and penny that we receive goes towards the cost of our venue hire. And it makes a massive difference.

PERKS!

Here’s how we express our love to our backers:

We have badges!

We have prints of original artwork made for the show!

We have unique poems written especially for you!

We have free tickets available!

These things and stuff will be yours as a token of our massive appreciation.

Look out for us

If you can’t sponsor us you can help us in other ways. Follow us on Twitter @guessworksthtr and tweet us because that’s an exciting thing to do.

story:
Let’s be Skewered without shame but with humour by sexuality, desire, rejection of self, assault, the body, relationships, fame, the artistic world and death. 

 

 

Break barriers, be Skewered.

To start, be immerse in the universe of Low Level Panic by Clare McIntyre. Skewered the intimicy of 3 flatmate, in their bathroom the central point of their confession, the place of their deep intimicy. Follow the build of their perfect life fantasy, and sexual desire, and secrets.   

In the second part, we tried to imaginated what will be a perfect life for Low Level Panic’s characters, a life that they would dream of, but this life doesn’t seems to be so perfect finally. In Cold Loneliness, by Candice Morel, be Skewered by the intimity of one ex cabaret star in the 30’s, in her backstage, hear her stange confession, hear her fear but don’t get scared by her story. In Cold loneliness watch the sexy burlesque dance of this strange women and hear the truth.

Let’s be Skewered without shame but with humour by sexuality, desire, rejection of self, rape, the body, relationships, fame, the artistic world and death. Don’t be ashamed to hear about women's sexualities, to see women's bodies and don’t be afraid to hear them.

 

Why break barriers and support us ?

We won't bore you with the fact that you will support an engaging show about women’s sexuality, desires, relationship, assault but also fame and death.

To be honest we tried to do everything with just two of us, but after few trials we figured out that doing a burlesque performance in the park was a very bad idea, so we need a venue. We also think that we could play four characters - but it would probably be quite awful for the audience, so we need actors. We really wanted to create our own songs, but someone told us that we weren't talented enough... I'm afraid they’re right. We wanted to draw all our flyers by hand but making 500 flyers would probably take until next year…. After a few experiments we figured out that we probably couldn't do everything... So we really need lots of help to realise our project!

 

Our baby Skewered

 

Because one play wasn't enough for us, we decided to do two plays! And because it’s our first production we decided to start with a bang, with a 2.5 hour show! “You’re crazy”, you exclaim! Yes we like challenges and Skewered is our challenge, we’re putting all our love and energy to make it gorgeous, to make the audience cry, laugh, wonder, and to be shocked a little bit! Skewered is exactly the word: we are Skewered by our passion for this project and our ambitious is to skewered our audience without barriers, and we would be pleased to be skewered by your support, however it comes.

 

What do we need ?

Costumes, actors, theatre hire, performance rights, 

We couldn't do the list of the multitude things we need so we'll just say we need you!

Why The Paper Theater ?

Paper is the origin of every text so even the origin of a piece of theatre. It's also often bearer of our ideas, we write on it our thoughts, we draw on it our sets, our costumes. It's also easy to make it disappear as an idea or a feeling. We can crumple it, fold it, cut it, like we can handle our body. But a piece of paper as volatile as a feeling, as fine as human relations, we can pierce it as fast as we are pierced by an emotion. Paper is the metaphor of our vision of the theatre: authentic, shapeable, and carrier of our messages.

 

But girls, I'm broke !

 

Don't worry you can support us in so many ways! You can share this fundraiser page, go to our social media and share it , speak about it, scream about it! And of course come to the show!

story:
Short Summary

Heidi Duckler Dance (HDD) creates innovative performances in non-traditional spaces that invite audiences to think differently about the space, and each other. We deliver arts education and site-specific performances to communities up and down the West Coast. Now, we have an opportunity to present our work and community development methodology to international audiences...but we need your help to get there!

HDD has been invited to present at the 2018 Tanzmesse Dance Festival in Düsseldorf, Germany. The company will perform "A Bela e a Fera (Beauty and the Beast)", inspired by the story of the same name written by acclaimed Jewish Brazilian author Clarice Lispector. However, this isn't your grandmother's fairy tale--"A Bela a Fera" explores intimacy, female identity, and income inequality. Experimenting with the idea of "self as site," HDD's soloist will embody the interior lives of the characters in the story.

Though class divide breeds confusion and mistrust between Lispector’s characters, they also find brief moments of connection. Duckler’s piece examines the construction and erosion of these characters’ worldviews through movement, as well as eliciting a collaboration between audience and performer, music and text, English and Portuguese.

Bringing this piece to Tanzmesse 2018 will allow Heidi Duckler Dance to scale its innovative site-specific and multi-disciplinary approach to dance internationally, providing the greater dance community with greater tools to engage both within and across métiers. 

Our projects would not be possible without the guidance of our Board and Advisory Board members.

Heidi Duckler Dance Board

Jamarah Hayner, JKH Consulting

Michael Anderson, BASE Architecture

John Friedman, JFAK Architects

Mary Ann Braubach, Huxley on Huxley

Connie Ramirez, Union Bank

Danielle Valentino, METRO

Lisa Quateman, Polsinelli

Adam Englander, Englander Knabes & Allen

Lisa Gilmour, Pancreatic Cancer Action Network

Terez Kreisz, Philanthropist

Tom Majich, Arroyo Hill Development

Deena Selenow, Occidental College

Mark Walsh, Artshare L.A.

Heidi Duckler Dance Advisory Board

Liliane Corzo, Capital Group

Olga Garay-English, Ford Theatre

Lorcan O'Herlihy, LOHA

Jan Perry, Los Angeles Economic and Workforce Development

Sarah Pillsbury, Liberty Hill Foundation

Craig Watson, California Arts Council

 

 

The Impact

Participating in Tanzmesse will be a valuable cultural exchange experience in which we will share with and learn from a range of international artists. Our works are tailor fit to every environment we enter, making for a unique experience shaped both by and for our audiences. From our inter-generational arts education programs to our collaborations with institutions such as the UCLA Labor Center, Heidi Duckler Dance is pushing the envelope of what is possible in the world of dance. Art is a key tool to addressing social distance in our communities, fostering communication, thought, and expression that lead to action. We plan to present these myriad potentials of dance to our international collaborators.

Since founding the company in 1985, HDD's Artistic/Executive Director, Heidi Duckler, has choreographed more than 300 original dance works at unique sites across East LA, Southern California and around the world. Dubbed "the reigning queen of site-specific performance," by the LA Times, Duckler has received major commissions from Grand Performances, REDCAT, the Autry Museum of the American West, Brookfield Properties, and Occidental and Pomona Colleges, among others. Through its education programs, HDD has served over 8,000 students in Los Angeles. Sharing our work with the world can catalyze new avenues for community-building across the globe.

What We Need and What You Get

The cost of international travel is hard on our little company! To get to Düsseldorf, we need:

Artist Ensemble Fee (5 people): $5,000

International Travel: $7,500

Per Diem: $1,800

Lodging: $3,750

Visa Processing Fee: $400

Materials/Supplies: $1000

TOTAL: $19,450

Check out the perks on the right side of this page!

How You Can Help

  • Support in any amount is greatly appreciated
  • Shout our name from the rooftops! Share our campaign with friends and family through social media

  • Stay connected – follow us on Facebook, Twitter, & Instagram to hear about upcoming performances and events

We truly thank you for your support. Advocates like you make it possible for Heidi Duckler Dance to connect communities across the West Coast, and now, the world!

story:
WELCOME!!!

 I'm just a kid who grew up on the lower east side of NYC, raised by my Dominican immigrant mother who taught us the importance of family, spirituality and community. While I never had formal training in theatre, music or the arts in general, I’ve always had a desire to do good, to tell the stories that are familiar to so many of us. I often think about the past men and women who have sacrificed and did so many amazing things for future generations and I aspire to be great like them.

As an artist, I personally feel it is my responsibility to present experiences that can teach, that can introduce audiences to something normally wouldn’t be exposed to. I am proud to have created a show that I hope will open hearts and minds of the audience, stir emotions, think differently, challenge, inspire and motivate. 

 

What We Need

I have already provided a great deal of funding that has already gone into executing this project but, we could reallyuse your help. Here's what $10,000 will pay for: 

  • I firmly believe that artists (creatives) deserve to get paid for the work they do.  No one is asked to work for free on this project.
  • Hiring a lighting designer and sound tech to help increase the quality of the show.
  • Hiring a stage manager
  • In our last run, each night was more filled than the night before. That momentum build up was proof of the shows ability to live in an off Broadway theatre. We would love to use part of the funds to help with sustaining the run beyond October.
  • Another percentage of the funding will go into costumes and props which will also elevate the quality of the show. 
  • One of the key investments we plan to make is to invest in marketing. Up until this point, all of the major success achieved has been through word of mouth from audiences who have seen the show. With the right advertising, the show has a greater chance of being seen by a major investor, production company and a larger audience. 
  • While the team is putting all of our blood sweat and tears into this project, like the creatives, it it is very challengine to find an administrative team that will work for free. 
  • We would love to have a Videographer come in and record a high quality copy of the show. The show in the past has been used as a diversity training tool. Having a HQ copy affords the show more opportunity to be used in educational and non educational institutions

Your perks:

Depending on how much you contribute, there will be some cool perks ranging from T shirts, and posters to an exclusive show soundtrack and personal cartoon image of you!!

The Impact

One of the most common comments after our show has been "This show has to live on Broadway. It's not just a show, but a call to action." One of the reasons the show has been so successful is because it is very accessible. It is very relevant regardless of race. I have seen the impact, the validation audience members have felt and expressed. With a talkback after the show being one of the key components, it creates a platform for the sometimes difficult conversations on race to happen. Given the current climate, this show get people from all different walks of life together to have a conversation about what they have just experienced, and how it is relevant to them. 

Another important factor about the show is that it is family friendly. The show is the type of show that the whole family can go see, and have discussions at home about the topic. While the topic of racism can be difficult, the humor and music in the show very accessible.

Of course as with everything there are always risks. Risks of failure, risks of mismanagement of the budget, and so on. But what gives me the most confidence with this show has been it's track record. Having first premiered in 2011, it was relevant then and continues to be relevant today. It has been developed for years, shaped into the great masterpiece it is today. 

A huge advantage with this show is that it target audience is literally everyone. It is for kids, it is for adults, it is for White people, it is for people of color, it is for the adopted population, and on and on. Contributing and being a part of this movement can give you the satisfaction that you have a hand in fighting against racial inequalities, educating and entertaining people, and putting out theatre that is truly a vessel for change.

Other Ways You Can Help

While I know that we all have our lives, our bills, and may not be in a position to financially sustain this movement, you can still help by sharing and trying to get people to donate or come to the show.

story:
Our Company & Our Project

We are the after-image, a passionately postmodern theater company embarking on our first fully-produced work, RE: SHE a litany of adventures, premiering at the Philadelphia Fringe Festival. 

Show dates : September 13 - 15 + 20 - 22

Location : PlayArts, a flexible children's play space hosting us for their first theatrical event

 

 

Credited as one of the original “lost world” stories, H. Rider Haggard’s She: A History of Adventure has been adapted ad nauseum in a variety of forms from the late 1800s through today. Though each maker of She tailored the narrative for his target audience, each iteration’s archetypes and messages perpetuate racist and misogynistic ideology. She is all the more damaging for inspiring myriad lost world stories rooted in colonialism that we continue to encounter in contemporary media. 

Quite the opposite of telling the story again, RE: SHE a litany of adventures examines how these stories were told, why these stories were told, and why they were popular. We are looking at the context of each adaptation to subvert them and reclaim the power they stole.

 

 

 

And while She and her thematic descendants show up everywhere we look, with this project we are drawing on alternative lost world stories that have gotten far less air time. These alternative narratives - envisioned by women and people of color - are guiding the modern day explorers of RE: SHE on their path towards individual and historic reckoning.

Your generosity is a critical part of telling this story with and for our community, and we are so grateful for your support.

For more information on our company history and past work, visit our website here. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

While our total costs for this production will exceed $13k, for this campaign, as our first priority, we are focused on raising the funds to compensate our dedicated and talented artistic team. 

Our $6200 artist budget line covers a group of ten devisors, designers, and stage managers. It also includes two ASL interpreters, a day-hire technician, videographer, and photographer. Producing Artistic Directors, Kate St. John & Amy Shoshana Blumberg are not receiving compensation for their work unless the entire project exceeds its break-even point.

As it is, we are unable to pay our collaborators even a fraction of what they are worth. This project would not exist without their generous allocation of time, talent, and intellect.

In the spirit of generosity, we are excited to thank you for your support by offering perks that reflect our team’s unique process & production.

 

 

For an account of our entire projected budget and anticipated revenue, take a look at our website here.

 

The Impact

Since RE: SHE primarily addresses race and gender, it is critically important to include as many perspectives as possible in this creative process. In a series of generative workshops, we are devising RE: SHE a litany of adventures with and through the unique viewpoints and experiences of our collaborators. 

With this project, we don’t want to erase the past; we want to hold it and make space for it so that we can take away its power. Through the work of our collaborators, RE: SHE will uncover a story that needs to be told now more than ever. We need your support to compensate these brilliant artists as well as we can.

 

Risks & Challenges

While Producing Artistic Directors Kate St. John and Amy Shoshana Blumberg have been a part of the theater community in Philadelphia for 4 years and anticipate an eager response from their Temple University community, the after-image is a new company presenting in a competitive festival. As recent MFA grads, Kate and Amy are eager to share this work with the community they know while reaching a much larger Philadelphia audience. 

In addition to our cultivated network of friends, followers, and previous collaborators, we expect that the extended reach of RE: SHE’s devising artists will yield high ticket sales for the duration of the run. And since we are hosting one performance with ASL interpretation, our show will be listed twice in the Fringe festival guide, thereby drawing an even wider audience. 

Even with nearly-sold-out houses, though, ticket sales will cover just over a third of our total production needs. We are seeking additional sponsorship from local businesses, but we cannot cover our projected costs without your support.

For more information about RE: SHE’s budget and funding breakdown, check out our website here.

 

Spread the Word!

We are immensely grateful for contributions of any amount.

Whether you can donate or not, you can support the after-image and our production of RE: SHE by sharing this campaign. 

For more information on how best to share this campaign, please see below for a few suggested sharing platforms :

  • social media
  • email
  • carrier pigeon
  • word of mouth
  • any other brilliant way that you invent

 

Thank you for your support! We can’t wait to share this work with you in September.

story:
About Ramona, A New Musical

California Territory, 1850; a young Ramona does not know who she is or where she came from - she only knows that the Señora Moreno raises her, grudgingly, as the only daughter of a wealthy family determined to live by rules and customs. Ramona's story of loss, love, and destruction explodes under the sharp heel of war, and carries us through her desperate journey in search of family, legacy, and home. 

Kayla Friend here - creator of Ramona, A New Musical, set to premiere in New York City next month as part of the first ever Furnace Festival.  An artist of Mexican, German, Irish, and Native American descent, I am originally from Hemet, California - the very region where Ramona’s life story took place.

Together with Jaime Lozano, James Rushin, Andres Maldonado, Jessy Tomsko, and Brian Cedric Jones, I am thrilled to be bringing the first ever stage-musical adaptation of Ramona to New York City!

So...about this campaign you’re reading right now. There is no way around stating that producing theatre in the biggest market in the world is HARD. From space fees, to unexpected costs, to paying all participating artists fairly, to marketing, promotion, and media - it adds up quickly, before a single audience member even walks in the door.

 

With this letter, Ramona’s fundraising campaign is officially live, and we are here to ask for your help. 

 

For two staged presentations, the full tech week in the performance space, approximately 40 hours of rehearsal, a 15+ person cast comprised of diverse, gifted artists, we need to raise the entirety of $8900.

Your Money at Work - What It Looks Like:

Staged workshops are a critical step towards the expansion of a new show; from performers bringing characters to life, to musicians and writers working together to point out flaws, experiment, and make changes for the better, a show can live or die by the workshop. Our goal is to mold the current version of Ramona into a full-scale commercial production, and your donation will immediately inch us closer to that goal.


Latinx and Native American voices are not often given platforms in the arts - with Ramona, we are working hard to bring to life this true story heard by only a few and a legacy that speaks to our melting pot of a nation then and now, through the eyes of a young woman searching for identity and home.

The Perks!

You think we’d just take your money and run? No way! Your donation makes you a part of the Ramona family. From custom lapel pins of Ramona’s signature yellow rose, to hand-written calligraphy of the show’s poetry, to exclusive invitations to a private cocktail party, and of course tickets to the performance - we want to show our gratitude for helping this story come to life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to donate? Here are some ways that you can help us to spread the word about our campaign and the production: 

  • Share your own Ramona story on IG, Facebook, Twitter, etc. and use our hashtag #RamonaMusical
  • Share our campaign with your friends! Blast it out to everyone! Even a $5 donation makes a huge difference when we've got enough folx!
  • In New York City? Tickets can be purchased here: https://www.centeratwestpark.org/furnace-festival  We will have performances on August 24 and 25. See you there!

Thank you for your support. We can’t wait to share this story with you.

See you at the theatre!

~ Kayla

story:
The Story 

A warrior goddess created by the Black Mother Goddesses and adorned in glorious robes of divinity, the celestial Ishtar fiercely guards her temple until the moment a stranger appears and disrupts her sanctuary and her sense of self. Under the counsel of The Black Mother Goddesses, Ishtar flees from the stranger abandoning her home and her beloved companion, The Bull of Heaven. Overcome with loneliness and grief, Ishtar makes a damning choice that forces her to choose between her divinity and her desire. 

Why We Need Your Help 

devour., has been selected as part of LadyFest 2019 at The Tank NYC! Your support means bringing this story to life with an amazing team of collaborators mostly from my home community in Austin, Texas. Reaching our goals helps offset the cost of their travel and minimal sound design, lighting design, scenic and costuming. 

The Impact

According to the Centers for Disease Control black women have the highest rate of dying by homicide than any other ethnicity and according to the U.S. Department of Education, 42 percent of girls receiving corporal punishment in schools are black despite only making up 16 percent of the U.S. school population.  devour.,is an investigation of the ways in which black girls and women are broadly excluded from our collective definitions of beauty and desirability and by extension are excluded from protection, safety and justice. 

devour., in many ways is my story and the story of black girls and women who have found themselves trapped in the tension between who they know themselves to be and who the world around them says they are. It is my belief that having the opportunity to explore that tension and see it reflected back to them helps move us all closer to a deeper understanding of our individual and collective humanity. Thank you.

The Team

Written and Performed by Taji Senior 

Directed by Matrex Kilgore

Dramaturgy by Marina DeYoe-Pedraza and Leah Braitwaithe  

Costuming by E.L. Hohn 

Lighting Design by Sierra Boudoin 

Sound Design by Devon Boyd 

Movement by Sade Jones 

Graphic Design by DJ Mahaelani/ Lesli Sparkman-Williams 

Photography by Hakeem Adewumi

story:
Our Story

Aura CuriAtlas is known for its exciting and inventive blend of acrobatic dance theatre.  The company embodies the qualities of our name – lightness, curiosity, and strength – to create characters and stories that audiences can relate to and embrace.

Since 2014 we have shared DREAM LOGIC and A Life With No Limits in communities large and small in the East Coast, Midwest and Southern United States. 

We are right in the midst of creating our newest work, The Fool and The World.

The Fool and The World is inspired by Tarot Card images. We will perform 22 stories inspired by the  major cards, accompanied by Sophia Serghi's piano solos, drawn from the same inspiration. 

The Tarot deck dates back to the 15th century and is used for both games and divination.  People interact with Tarot and other contemporary oracle cards in many different ways – spiritual guidance, psychological insights, and entertainment. We offers this Tarot-inspired performance as a way for each audience member to have a conversation with their imagination.  Audiences are invited to talk with the company after the show and offer their own interpretations.

 

We Need Your Support

We need your help to launch this world premiere! Our campaign goal is to raise $5,000 by the time our show opens at 7pm (Eastern) on March 9. Can you help us get there?

We’re self-producing which means amidst the creative development of the work, we also have to make sure we can afford all of the elements of the production – the venue rental, technicians, costumes, marketing, performer fees, and transportation.

 

Every Dollar Counts

In addition to grants and box office income, Aura CuriAtlas relies on the generosity of friends, patrons, and business partners to help create original works and bring them to the stage.  Every dollar goes DIRECTLY to producing shows. Your gift helps pay for:

  • Travel to rehearsals and performances around the country
  • Rehearsal and performance venues in different cities
  • Technicians, designers, and performers
  • Props and costumes
  • Publicity

Plus these funds allow us to connect with our community by

  • Providing access to the performing arts at affordable ticket prices
  • Offering no-cost tickets for community partners
  • Teaching educational workshops that explore collaboration and discovery

We know our performances have inspired so many people, and we want to reach even more.  Our partner organizations have included Big Brothers Big Sisters, Literacy for Life, and Here for the Girls.  Through these groups we share free tickets to audiences who might not otherwise have had the chance to come to a performance. Your contribution will support meaningful art that gives back to communities all around the country.

In a digital world, real interactions matter. Live performances, meet-the-artist experiences, and educational workshops that draw out creative thought and spark human connections all matter. Your support helps bring these experiences to life.

 

Ways You Can Help

Your financial support is huge. THANK YOU for your generosity.

And if you like what we do, you can also help by talking about us!  Tell your friends in person and by using the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word on Facebook, Instagram, email, and other social media.  Friends of friends are some of the most important contributors any company can have!

 

Aura CuriAtlas Physical Theatre is a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. All contributions are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information contact: Aura CuriAtlas, 2825 Hidden Lake Drive, Williamsburg, VA 23185. auracuriatlas@gmail.com

story:
About Us

Eternal Theatre Collective is a youth not-for-profit organization dedicated to providing opportunities to young performing artists between the ages of 13 and 25. We believe that young people are just as capable of creating amazing and beautiful theatre - especially when they collaborate with each other and learn from the process. Emerging artists need experience and real theatre work to get their careers started, and we are dedicated to helping them get that experience.

Everyone we work with, from the actors to the designers, the creative team to the managerial team and even the board of directors is under 25 years old. We offer fantastic opportunities for youth to experiment and grow in their craft in a professional and collaborative environment.

 

 "Working with Eternal Theatre Collective has been important to me, and important to many other of these other emerging artists because it allows us to gain confidence and enter the world of professional theatre."

          - Jessica Wong, Sister Chantelle in "bare"

Because we are a small, young company, we always count on generous people like YOU to help us continue to create opportunities and make dreams a reality for young people in our community.

This summer, we're doing a musical with a rock score, so we need microphones to be able to amplify the voices of our actors to be heard over the band. Renting microphones and sound boards is an expensive task which is why we're asking YOU to help us reach our goal. With your help, we can ensure that all the talented young actors in our production will have their voices heard loud and clear to tell this important story.

"I think it showcases the social pressures that teenagers have to go through when they're trying to grow up and figure themselves out. Whether is be with their sexuality, their self-esteem, and I think it shows that you don't need to have all the answers. You just need to seek out someone you love and trust for support."

          - Shelby Armstrong, Kyra in "bare"

 

What We Need & What You Get

Sound equipment, microphones, sets, costumes, and venue costs bring  - but any funding we can get to help offset the costs makes a HUGE difference! Bare takes place in a Catholic boarding school, and much of it takes place inside the chapel itself. Our production is happening in the beautiful Unitarian Church of Vancouver, which will add to the feeling of the show. However, putting on a show in a non-traditional theatre space adds to the cost. We need extra sound equipment, versatile set and costume pieces, and other site-specific accommodations.

 

"I think bare is so important because it really delves into the need for acceptance, but most importantly, self-acceptance. I really think that's an important thing for any audience member to want to see."

          -Hannah Myers, Tanya in "bare"

 

In exchange for your generosity - we have some really exciting and fun rewards available:

For a donation of $5 - Our eternal love and thanks, as well as a social media shout-out!

For a donation of $15 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, and a complimentary concession item when you come see bare!

For a donation of $25 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, a complimentary concession item, and a personalized thank you video from the team behind bare!

For a donation of $30 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, and a copy of Shakespeare's Romeo & Juliet signed by the cast of bare! Only 5 available.

For a donation of $50 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, a complimentary concession item, a personalized thank you video, and two (2) discounted tickets to the performance of bare that works best for you!

For a donation of $100 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, a complimentary concession item, a personalized thank you video, and two (2) complimentary tickets to the performance of bare that works best for you!

 

Your Impact

 

"Growing up with dreams of working in "big-city" theatre, I am incredibly grateful to have the chance to work with ETC to turn my own ideas and designs into the sets for bare. I came to ETC with very little training and experience in set design and construction, but a strong interest in learning more and being able to put on an incredible show. bare has given me and the other youths of ETC the chance to participate in a professional and constructive environment, where we can learn and showcase our skills for the thriving theatre community in Vancouver."

           - Bailey Madison Kaye, Set Designer for "bare"

 

ETC is a fairly young company, but we've already been lucky enough to have many successful projects in the past, including 8 cabaret concerts, 4 short plays, 1 full length play (Seven Minutes in Heaven), and 1 musical (13). None of our success would be possible however without the generous support of our community.

 

"I think bare is an important show because it offers a really real and raw look into experiences that LGBTQ teens have all the time."

          - Robbie Hébert, Jason in "bare"

 

In donating to our campaign you are not only helping a production reach its full potential, but you are also feeding the passion, learning and love of the craft of the next generation of theatre makers, ensuring that Vancouver will have a thriving theatre community long into the future.

 

 

"We have luckily been able to assemble an amazing cast of diverse and emerging artists who will all become forces in the upcoming years. It is such a pleasure to work with such energetic and new talent because they are unafraid to pour their heart and soul into each note of the score.  This immersive and uniquely stage production will invite the audience to surrender to the lyricism of the piece and discover the inner thoughts and desires of each character."

          - Seamus Fera, Director of "bare"

 

Other Ways to Help

If you can't donate to our campaign this time around, but still want to help - don't fear! There are tons of things you can do to help support out show:

Share the campaign on social media, and talk about "bare" with your friends and family!

Check out our website at www.eternaltheatre.com and subscribe to our newsletter!

Most importantly, buy tickets to come see our show in May! It's going to be a fantastic show, thanks to you!

With your help we can get the word out about the work we're doing; we'll be able to achieve all our goals together and bring fantastic opportunities to young artists in Greater Vancouver.

 

bare runs May 29 - June 8, 2019, Wed-Sat at the Unitarian Church of Vancouver, at 7:30 pm.

Tickets available at: www.eternaltheatre.com

Eternal Theatre Collective is a youth not-for-profit organization dedicated to providing opportunities to young performing artists between the ages of 13 and 25. We believe that young people are just as capable of creating amazing and beautiful theatre - especially when they collaborate with each other and learn from the process. Emerging artists need experience and real theatre work to get their careers started, and we are dedicated to helping them get that experience.
Everyone we work with, from the actors to the designers, the creative team to the managerial team and even the board of directors is under 25 years old. We offer fantastic opportunities for youth to experiment and grow in their craft in a professional and collaborative environment.

 
 "Working with Eternal Theatre Collective has been important to me, and important to many other of these other emerging artists because it allows us to gain confidence and enter the world of professional theatre."
          - Jessica Wong, Sister Chantelle in "bare"
Because we are a small, young company, we always count on generous people like YOU to help us continue to create opportunities and make dreams a reality for young people in our community.
This summer, we're doing a musical with a rock score, so we need microphones to be able to amplify the voices of our actors to be heard over the band. Renting microphones and sound boards is an expensive task which is why we're asking YOU to help us reach our goal. With your help, we can ensure that all the talented young actors in our production will have their voices heard loud and clear to tell this important story.
"I think it showcases the social pressures that teenagers have to go through when they're trying to grow up and figure themselves out. Whether is be with their sexuality, their self-esteem, and I think it shows that you don't need to have all the answers. You just need to seek out someone you love and trust for support."
          - Shelby Armstrong, Kyra in "bare"

 
What We Need & What You Get
Sound equipment, microphones, sets, costumes, and venue costs bring  - but any funding we can get to help offset the costs makes a HUGE difference! Bare takes place in a Catholic boarding school, and much of it takes place inside the chapel itself. Our production is happening in the beautiful Unitarian Church of Vancouver, which will add to the feeling of the show. However, putting on a show in a non-traditional theatre space adds to the cost. We need extra sound equipment, versatile set and costume pieces, and other site-specific accommodations.
 
"I think bare is so important because it really delves into the need for acceptance, but most importantly, self-acceptance. I really think that's an important thing for any audience member to want to see."
          -Hannah Myers, Tanya in "bare"
 
In exchange for your generosity - we have some really exciting and fun rewards available:
For a donation of $5 - Our eternal love and thanks, as well as a social media shout-out!
For a donation of $15 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, and a complimentary concession item when you come see bare!
For a donation of $25 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, a complimentary concession item, and a personalized thank you video from the team behind bare!
For a donation of $30 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, and a copy of Shakespeare's Romeo & Juliet signed by the cast of bare! Only 5 available.
For a donation of $50 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, a complimentary concession item, a personalized thank you video, and two (2) discounted tickets to the performance of bare that works best for you!
For a donation of $100 - Our eternal love and thanks, a social media shout-out, a complimentary concession item, a personalized thank you video, and two (2) complimentary tickets to the performance of bare that works best for you!

 
Your Impact
 
"Growing up with dreams of working in "big-city" theatre, I am incredibly grateful to have the chance to work with ETC to turn my own ideas and designs into the sets for bare. I came to ETC with very little training and experience in set design and construction, but a strong interest in learning more and being able to put on an incredible show. bare has given me and the other youths of ETC the chance to participate in a professional and constructive environment, where we can learn and showcase our skills for the thriving theatre community in Vancouver."
           - Bailey Madison Kaye, Set Designer for "bare"
 
ETC is a fairly young company, but we've already been lucky enough to have many successful projects in the past, including 8 cabaret concerts, 4 short plays, 1 full length play (Seven Minutes in Heaven), and 1 musical (13). None of our success would be possible however without the generous support of our community.
 
"I think bare is an important show because it offers a really real and raw look into experiences that LGBTQ teens have all the time."
          - Robbie Hébert, Jason in "bare"
 
In donating to our campaign you are not only helping a production reach its full potential, but you are also feeding the passion, learning and love of the craft of the next generation of theatre makers, ensuring that Vancouver will have a thriving theatre community long into the future.
 

 
"We have luckily been able to assemble an amazing cast of diverse and emerging artists who will all become forces in the upcoming years. It is such a pleasure to work with such energetic and new talent because they are unafraid to pour their heart and soul into each note of the score.  This immersive and uniquely stage production will invite the audience to surrender to the lyricism of the piece and discover the inner thoughts and desires of each character."
          - Seamus Fera, Director of "bare"
 
Other Ways to Help
If you can't donate to our campaign this time around, but still want to help - don't fear! There are tons of things you can do to help support out show:
Share the campaign on social media, and talk about "bare" with your friends and family!
Check out our website at www.eternaltheatre.com and subscribe to our newsletter!
Most importantly, buy tickets to come see our show in May! It's going to be a fantastic show, thanks to you!
With your help we can get the word out about the work we're doing; we'll be able to achieve all our goals together and bring fantastic opportunities to young artists in Greater Vancouver.
 
bare runs May 29 - June 8, 2019, Wed-Sat at the Unitarian Church of Vancouver, at 7:30 pm.
Tickets available at: www.eternaltheatre.com

story:
CVRDIVC PRODUCTIONS

Moments to make your heart stop.

We are a collective of individuals who come together to create immersive experiences that confront your worst fears.

 

OUR BEGINNINGS

We first started after our founder, Forrest Orta, scared his way around Orange County and had a thirst to try something new: creating experiences that cause fear while telling a compelling story. Based in the Orange County area, create stories that take concepts and tell them in a new way and place them in physical locations to truly strike terror in our audience.

 

VALUES

Although we seek to endure fear in our audience, there are key things we value:

INCLUSION: CVRDIVC Productions aims to be the space for anyone and everyone. We will never exclude any gender, race, class, sexuality, or ability from experiencing our pieces. The same goes for the staff and cast. Everyone has a thirst for horror and no one should be told that can’t do what they have a passion for based on something they can’t change.

ACCESS: Art can be very pricey, a factor that shouldn’t exist. We will price our experiences to make our needs but will do everything we can to ensure that everyone has an opportunity to enjoy our creations.

OVERALL SATISFACTION: At the end of the day, we seek to not only scare you, but we also seek to ensure your enjoyment has been made. This also translates to our staff, cast, and crew. If our people are enjoying what they love to do, the audience will do the same.

YOUTH EMPOWERMENT: There is a surprising amount of youth that shares the thirst for their wanting of horror. We seek to be the people behind them cheering them on, as well as be there when they struggle with their creative process.

 

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

As with most experiences, it takes not only hard work, dedication, and people to bring it to life, but it also takes money to make it happen. We are only asking for $7500.

With this goal, it will allow us to:

  • Work with locations that best fit our stories
  • Cast great talent, regardless of gender, race, class, or ability
  • Produce quality work with long production runs
  • Purchase props and design costumes

Up till now, we have been funding through our day jobs. While it has been very helpful, it's not enough anymore.

You may be asking, “What do I get out of supporting you?” I’m glad you asked. Because we are asking for a significant amount, we have come up with some amazing perks if you decide to support!

 

PERKS

$10 - Thank You On Social Media

We thank you for your donation! For that thank you, we will create a personalized media that will be shared across all of our social media

 

$25 - Letters of Gratitude

If you donate with $25 or more, you will receive a personalized letter of gratitude mailed to you. 

 

$50 - Experience a CVRDIVC Production Creation

If you choose to support with $50 or more, you will get all previous perks, PLUS two tickets to the next experience we produce.

 

$100 - CVRDIVC Productions Swag!

If you choose to support with $100 or more, you will get all previous perks, PLUS a swag bag filled with CVRDIVC Production-branded items.

 

$500 - Become an Easter Egg in a Future Production

If you choose to support with $500 or more and you pick this option, you will get all of the previous perks, PLUS be placed within a prop (book or photo frame) for a future production that will be seen by all who attend the experience.

 

$500 - Pick The Title of a Future Production

If you choose to support with $500 or more and you pick this option, you will get all of the previous perks*, PLUS you will be allowed to choose the title of a future production created and will be listed on the show page of our website.

 

$1000 - Friend in the Shadows

Wow! First of all, that is insane! THANK YOU SO MUCH! If you choose to support with $1000 or more, you will get ALL perks, PLUS being placed within in our special thanks page entitled FRIENDS IN THE SHADOWS! You will get to pick the photo displayed, along with the label GENEROUS DONOR, and a brief description next to the photo.

 

 

WHAT IT MEANS TO US

The impact of everyone making the decision to support will open doors for us to do greater things.

What other plans do we have in store?

  • A Horror-centric dance troupe
  • Workshops created to allow talent to hone their skills in scaring
  • A facility that will include rehearsal space, conference rooms, and rooms for creating their experiences.

We also seek to empower kids to create THEIR brand of horror and have a place where no judgment is cast upon, as well as people behind them to assist if they reach a mental block.

 

WHAT HAVE WE DONE SO FAR

Since launching in December of 2019, we mounted our first immersive entitled MIDNIGHT. The experience places our audience into the home of The Steinen Family, a family just new to the neighborhood, and play a game that awakens a demon. The show, being our first, was met to modest praise

"With a high level of suspense maintained throughout, MIDNIGHT delivers on creating an exciting and thrilling immersive experience."

-Shannon McGrew, Nightmarish Conjurings

"It was a fun, and terror, filled hour"

-Jeff Heimbuch, Horrorbuzz

 

Now we completely understand if you can not support in a monetary manner. If you could support us in a more "digital" manner, it would be greatly appreciated!

Some other ways to show support!

  • Visit our LinkTree link to follow our social media.
  • Share this campaign with your friends!

 

Thank you again for taking some time to hear what we have to offer.

 

SEE YOU IN THE SHADOWS!

-Shannon McGrew, Nightmarish Conjurings

-Jeff Heimbuch, Horrorbuzz

story:
Summary

Catherine Higgins-Moore is a BBC trained journalist, and the mother of two daughters. She holds an M.A. from Trinity College Dublin in English Literature and Drama and in Creative Writing from  the University of Oxford. Your contribution will help to make the world premiere of The Maternity Monologues stand out in the crowded world of New York theatre.

Catherine is concerned with women's health. Her poetry collection, Strange Roof, was published in 2017 by Finishing Line Press as part of their New Women's Voices Series.The work garnered praise from writer Danielle McLaughlin, author of Dinosaurs on Other Planets, who said:

'‘Strange Roof’ is a collection that delivers exquisite explorations of distance, loneliness, and the constant tug of home. It also delineates with grace and ferocity the price that life exacts from women, the scars it inflicts; physical scars, and psychological ones.'

And from Lisa O’Donnell, author of The Death of Bees and Winner of the 2013 Commonwealth Book Prize who said:

 ‘Catherine Higgins-Moore’s use of language to embolden and communicate experience inspires and excites. She is not afraid of anything. Her confident gritty flair inks life into a world both known and unknown. A joy resides in these pages. A bold and fearless joy.’

According to the World Health Organization, 803 women die from complications related to pregnancy and childbirth every day. 4% of births lead to PTSD. And that's from those who report it. According to the World Health Organization, 803 women die from complications related to pregnancy and childbirth every day.

A study from 2003 found that a third of mothers who experience a “traumatic delivery”, defined as involving complications, the use of instruments to assist delivery or near death, go on to develop PTSD. With 130 million babies born around the world every year, this means an incredible number of women may be trying to cope with the disorder with little or no help.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your contribution to help secure rehearsal space, market the show to a large audience, and to compensate all the talented creatives involved.

You get amazing perks like free tickets, signed scripts, editorial feedback on YOUR play and even a Champagne reception with the cast in New York City.

We are mothers. We are New Yorkers. We will make sure this show goes up in style!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help financially, please spread the word. Recommend the show. Talk about it. Share on social media.

story:
Our Story

"The Smell of the Kill" director, Adam Schulmerich, envisioned this production for some of Lights Out Theatre Company's actors several years ago, but it seemed like we might never have the resources to produce this show we had fantasized so much about. But then a disregarded cash box from our previous shows was unearthed & crow-barred open, and lo! there was money to be spent! 

Lights Out's meager $3,000 budget represents the highs and lows of almost a decade of artistic collaboration, late nights, hard-learned lessons, & friendship. We're joyfully spending every last cent on a show that embodies the spirit of our company, in the unique space that has allowed us to thrive. "The Smell of the Kill" is a high-energy comedy rooted in dark truths; a perfect way to say farewell to our beloved Lights Out.

Through your contributions, we'll be able to give this show its due production value & pay the playwright, Michele Lowe, for the use of her art. You'll improve the experience for the entire audience & help Lights Out Theater Company go out on a high note.

The Lights Out Theatre Company family is grateful for all of the support we've received since we were hopeful, enthusiastic, post-college dummies. Your continued assistance through this final show means the world to us. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

What We Need & What You Get

We have $3,000 and we're trying to raise an additional $1,600. 

We understand budgets are tight for many of our supporters, so we appreciate every level of giving. If you're in Chicago & will be enjoying the show, consider that most storefront shows set you back about $30, and we arent charging admission. Whether you make minumum wage or use $100 bills as napkins, we want you to see the show & ask that you donate whatever amount that is meaningful to you. 

The largest portion of our budget has gone towards the set & more is needed to complete the look of an upscale kitchen in the suburbs of Chicago. Though we've been very frugal & have found/borrowed excellent pieces, but lumber & truck rentals come at a fixed cost.

We also need to pay for the rights to the script, costume pieces, a license to Qlab to run our fantastic sound design, some props & set dressing, and a bit of stage magic. We strongly believe in paying our designers and actors for their training, time, and talent, so any donations above our goals will go directly to the artists who have worked so hard to bring you this show. 

We have some fun perks for the night of the show, like our VIP Treatment. We also have great options for groups who might want to take advantage of some time at The Lincoln Loft. You can even rent the space to use the projector and giant screen or host a roast like a pro! We invite donors at every level to feel proud of supporting the live arts. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have money to spare, we'd be grateful for your help in other ways:

  • Come to the show! We're doing all of this because we want to entertain you!
  • If you have an employer or contact who would like to have a group outing, we can try to accomodate a private event. Email annalu88@gmail.com
  • Help us spread the word & fill the house every night.
  • Follow The Lincoln Loft on Facebook and check out their other shows

Thank you!

story:
BUY TICKETS OR DONATE HERE:
https://www.accelevents.com/e/MSM2019

Who we are:

ASAP Drama: For more than 1,100 youth in 40 clubs, ASAP Drama nurtures young people’s powers of expression, teamwork skills & cultural knowledge through participating in group performances and attending professional productions. ASAP Drama is an after school initiative of Philadelphia nonprofit, ASAP/After School Activities Partnerships, whose mission is to keep youth safe & engaged after school. 

ASPIRA, Inc. of PA: ASPIRA is a network of 6 public schools dedicated to serving Latino and other vulnerable North Philadelphia youth. It is a community based organization serving underprivileged youth through high-quality, need based education, public advocacy, and
other programs dedicated to empowering communities from within.

Our Story:

This multi-school musical production was borne out of ASAP Drama & ASPIRA’s shared goal to find new, compelling ways to use the dramatic arts to empower the city’s emerging bilingual student population and build a sense of community among participating schools. ASAP and ASPIRA first partnered and piloted the multi-school musical in 2016 with a dual-language production of “Aladdin, Jr.,” followed by “Barrio Grrrl,” in 2017 and “Little Mermaid, Jr.” in 2018.

While English is spoken in ASPIRA's network schools, the surrounding communities and families of the students primarily speak Spanish. In addition, according to statistics from the Philadelphia School District, 15,200 students are first time English learners. This year, ASAP & ASPIRA present a full bilingual production of Fame Jr. in Spanish to create an inclusive and welcoming theatre experience for all, as Philadelphia is a Sanctuary City.

Your support:

  • Theatre Professionals: Set design, choreographer, and music director to guide youth-let production
  • Costumes: provided for all cast to wear for 4 performances 
  • Technology: Includes two wireless microphones
  • Transportation: Buses to ensure all students from all five campuses can make it to and from rehearsal, safely
  • Snacks: aid long tech rehearsals near showtime

Other Ways You Can Help: 

  • Follow @phillyASAP on FB, Twitter, Instagram and Youtube
  • SPREAD THE WORD AND BUY A TICKET!
  • Tickets: www.multischoolmusical.com

Thank you so much for your time and we can’t wait to bring Fame Jr. to our eager estudiantes de drama (drama students).

Follow @phillyASAP on FB, Twitter, Instagram and Youtube
SPREAD THE WORD AND BUY A TICKET!
Tickets: www.multischoolmusical.com


Thank you so much for your time and we can’t wait to bring Fame Jr. to our eager estudiantes de drama (drama students).

story:
What is Ginger & Rosemary Theatre?

Ginger & Rosemary Theatre is an Edmonton and Strathcona County theatre collective, spearheaded by local theatre producers, Bill Roberts and Giorgia Severini. Bill and Giorgia started Ginger & Rosemary Theatre with the mission to bring you shows that have never or rarely been seen on Edmonton stages before. 

Before we were Ginger & Rosemary Theatre, members of the company have worked together on productions with consistently increasing levels of success, including The License by Luigi Pirandello (Edmonton International Fringe Festival 2012), the first Canadian Production of Ages of the Moon by Sam Shepard (Edmonton International Fringe Festival 2014), and Apocalypse, Saskatchewan by Dion Huel (various productions 2012 - 2015, culminating in a standing ovation at the 2015 Regina Fringe Festival and sold-out houses at the 2015 Edmonton Fringe).

What is Three on a Seesaw?

Our first production is Three on a Seesaw, a dramatic comedy by Milan playwright Luigi Lunari and translated by Giorgia Severini and Barrett Hileman. Three on a Seesaw has enjoyed success all around the world for over 25 years. This unique North American English translation was first produced by Calgary’s Fire Exit Theatre in 2015, and now Ginger & Rosemary Theatre are producing it in Edmonton for the first time.

The Three on a Seesaw  team includes:

Cast: Bradley Bishop, Bill Roberts, Trevor Talbott, Maura Penn
Director: Giorgia Severini                                                                                                 Designers: Pierre Valois (set), Yvonne Trethart (costumes), Roy Jackson (lighting/sound)

In Three on a Seesaw, three very different men arrive in the same room, all for very different reasons. The three men--a businessman, a professor, and an army captain--find themselves trapped together for the night with bizarre, irrational, almost miraculous incidents happening all around them. As the night wears on, they find themselves confronted with questions about mortality, God, and the meaning of life.

How will my sponsorship monies be used?

Three on a Seesaw will be running April 13 - 17, 2016 at Edmonton's Holy Trinity Anglican Church. Your sponsorship monies will be applied directly to costs of this production, including set, costumes, props, venue insurance, and artist honourariums.

While we are but a little upstart theatre company putting on our first show, we are committed first and foremost to pay our actors and production members for the time and effort they are putting in to make this show possible.

What else can I do to help?

If you are unable to give funds but still want to help, please spread the word about Ginger & Rosemary Theatre and Three on a Seesaw!

Share:

The link to this fundraising page: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/three-on-a-seesaw/x/13416124#/

And the link to our website: gingerandrosemary.com

Like us on Facebook.

And most importantly: come see the show yourself!

story:
Hi, I’m Ed Ballou, and I wrote ‘The Glimmer’. I want to produce this play in Oakland this fall - but first, I want to stage a reading of the play, and I need your help - I have to rent the theater, pay the actors and director, buy insurance, etc. - please donate whatever you can - contributions are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law - I’m shooting for a free staged reading of ‘The Glimmer’ on Saturday, August 13 from 1-4 pm, currently available, at The Fight Deck theater at 1540 Broadway at Telegraph in Oakland, with beer, wine, and bottled water available, along with free pizza - if that date is unavailable by the end of the  fund-raising, I’ll try for another Saturday in August at the same venue - date and time of the reading to be announced on my website at 2020glimmer.com - a Question and Answer session will follow the reading - I want your feedback as an audience as to how the play works - you’ll be helping in the development of this play..

  I have written a dozen plays, seven which have been produced - ‘The Glimmer’ has been produced twice as a one-act - once in San Francisco and once in New York City, which is where the video clip was filmed - I have since expanded it, adding two more characters: Maritza, a young Millennial woman and Fred, a fellow worker at the Accelerator - the reading is all about seeing how it will play out as a full-length drama. ‘The Glimmer’ is based on a couple who lived next door to us in a little duplex on the freeway  - but instead of a freeway, I have them living in a duplex under a large urban bridge..

 - the husband claimed to have been an ex-boxer who later worked at the Stanford Linear Accelerator, until his vision was diminished by radiation exposure - they were alcoholic, had fights we would hear through the thin walls, and I would go over and intervene - after a while, it seemed they would fight just to get me to come over - the husband wanted to teach me about electronics, and had a strange old electronic machine on the floor - I seemed to have become the son they never had - two of the characters, Mike and Lil, are based on that couple and another character, George, is based on myself - after 6 months the couple moved away - I never saw them, again...

   

LIL

You think I’m having an affair?

MIKE

(Pauses, squints in her direction)

I don’t know what to think! 

(Pauses, squints at her)

Sex?

LIL

(Pauses)

Well, we - Fred and I - we talked about..

MIKE

(Interrupting her, turning away from her)

I don’t want to know!

(She stares at his back - Mike raises the bid papers up to his eyes, squints at them)

I want to you to read his bid to me, I want to know all about it..

(Shoves the papers in her direction)

Read it...

LIL

(Backing away)

I can’t..

MIKE

(Shouting at her)

Read his bid! 

LIL

I’ve already read it! - I’m the one who pushed him to write it! - at least he’s willing to do something, Mike! - willing to try something! - besides complain all day!

MIKE

(Pauses, throws the bid to the floor - the papers scatter)

Get your stuff.. you’re not staying here, anymore...

LIL

(Pauses)

Where can I stay, Mike? - where can I go?

MIKE

To a cheap motel.. or maybe to Fred’s!  

(He squints over at her - Lil hesitates)

Get out!

(Mike turns and squints up at the bridge - she talks to his back)

LIL

Mike.. can we talk about this?

MIKE

Talk, talk? - sure, sure we can talk, Lil..

(Turns and faces her)

Get your stuff packed! - there, we just talked!

(LIL pauses, looking at him - turns and  EXITS into the bedroom - Mike pauses, then gets down on his knees, crawls around on the floor, 

squinting, collecting the bid papers - A KNOCK on the door)

MIKE

(Pauses, calls out)

What? - who is it? 

FRED (OFFSTAGE)

It’s me, Fred...

(Mike pauses, gets up, squinting at the door -  slowly walks over to the door, slowly opens it - ENTER FRED)

Copyright Ed Ballou, 2016

PERKS:

$5 - a free beverage of your choice at the reading

$10 - recognition in the program as an Associate Producer, and a free beverage of your choice at the reading

$20 - 1 ticket to the fall production, recognition in the program as an Associate Producer, and a free beverage of your choice at the reading

$50 -  3 tickets to the fall production, recognition in the program as an Associate Producer, and a free beverage of your choice to each ticket holder at the reading

$100 -  7 tickets to the fall production, recognition in the program as an Associate Producer, and a free beverage of your choice to each ticket holder at the reading 

I hope to raise $3,500 for the reading, with the costs as follows:

The Venues (Rehearsal space rental, performance space rental, insurance, required staff) - $1,350

The Show (actor compensations, set, props, costumes) - $1,400

The Other Costs (Pizza, beer/ wine license, advertising, fund-raising processing costs, brochure printing costs) - $750

Thank you for your support, and I hope to see you at the reading! - Ed

story:
Help Take Jo-Mé Dance To Montreal

Founded in 2011, Jo-Mé Dance is a multicultural modern-contemporary dance organization from Boston, MA whose goal is to enrich the lives of people of all ages, races, and backgrounds through the art of dance. We are a three-tiered organization consisting of the Jo-Mé Youth Company (ages 5-13), Jo-Mé Dance Company (pre-professional), and Jo-Mé Dance Theatre (professional company).

Though a young organization, we have toured to Philadelphia PA, North Carolina, and Michigan. To celebrate our fifth season, Jo-Mé Dance Theatre premiered our 5th anniversary show,  EVOLUTION, to a sold-out audience in Boston on April 30th. NOW we are thrilled to take EVOLUTION abroad and make our international debut at the Festival St-Ambroise FRINGE de Montréal where we will perform 6 shows in 12 days -- but we need your help to get us there!


Your Support Will Help Us Go Far

The generous donations we receive through this campaign will help us pay for:

  • round-trip transportation from Boston to Montreal for 10 company members
  • 12 days of room and board for the full company
  • metro cards for the company to travel to and from our performance venue
  • printing for flyers & postcards, which we'll hand out on the streets of Montreal (we're in charge of our own marketing for each show!)
  • costumes
  • administrative support
  • lighting designer

Our $4,000 goal will cover the bare minimum of these expenses and YOUR HELP can make it all possible. Any additional funds we raise will help us to pay for rehearsal space and dancers' stipends leading up to the tour. Help us make this the best season for Jo-Mé Dance as we look forward to the next 5 years and beyond!


The Impact

Jo-Mé Dance aims to set new levels of excellence in Boston dance through impeccable skill and artistry, and we strive to put Boston on the map in the dance world, both in the US and abroad. We also proudly exemplify cooperative diversity and promote cultural awareness within our companies and community, which we intend to bring around the world as we expand our tours in the future.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Donations of any amount will help get us to Montreal, but you can also help us by spreading the word about this campaign and about Jo-Mé Dance. Please share this campaign and visit www.jo-medance.com to keep up to date with our organization!

story:
About Lippy

Edinburgh University’s Theatre Paradok present the first amateur revival of the award-winning play, Lippy by Bush Moukarzel with cameo playwright Mark O'Halloran.

Lippy is a story about how we try to understand the unthinkable. Telling the true story of four women who starved themselves to death in Ireland at the turn of the millennium, Lippy simultaneously attempts to uncover the motives that drove them to ending their lives. The first amateur production of the award-winning Dead Centre production, Lippy is haunting, powerful, unforgettable and at points darkly comic. The show effortlessly plays with the narrative of conventional theatre while exploring the characters of the four women at the show’s heart. 
Bringing a new voice to this contemporary classic, Theatre Paradok present a stripped-back version of Dead Centre’s original production, focusing on powerful performances and brutal realism. 

About Theatre Paradok

Theatre Paradok are Edinburgh University's experimental and alternative theatre company who have been producing multiple productions both in term time and at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for many years. Our latest production is one of our most ambitious yet, tackling the challenging and powerful modern drama Lippy, originally produced by Dead Centre at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2014.

But it is not possible for us to put this show on without your help. We need public funding to help us put this show together and it won't be possible unless you help us out! It's a big task putting a show like this together and unfortunately it doesn't come cheap. Lippy is a brutal and powerful drama about fiction, starvation and how we become the tellers of our own stories and we would love the opportunity to bring our take on this story to you this August.

We Need You!

We need £550 to afford to put on the production we want. From technical elements like props and lighting to publicity costs such as flyers and posters, this money will help us out dramatically. We want to create a show that is worthy of the script we are working with and for that we need costumes, lights, rehearsal space and lots more. But we don't expect you to give us money for nothing and we are offering lots of rewards as thanks for your support.

Theatre Paradok have been producing alternative, experimental and unusual theatre in Scotland's capital for a long time and we have received plenty of praise for our work. From previous Fringe productions like last year's Mrs Dalloway to productions in the last year such as original physical theatre piece 'To Breathe' and a production of Harold Pinter's 'The Hothouse'. Lippy presents fresh challenges for us as a company, putting on a show so heavy in technical elements and difficult performances in such a short space of time. However the experienced cast and crew on board this project have dedicated lots of time to making sure this production is a success and honours the original work.

If you would like to follow the production...

We are on Twitter at @LippyFRINGE2016

And also available to follow on Facebook as 'Theatre Paradok'.

story:
Summary:

WC cultivates the artistic, civic and academic minds of underserved youth by providing access to in-depth art, theater and new media programming that promotes diverse voices in the arts, nurtures intellectual curiosity, and demands a more equitable society. For the past 28 years we have provided middle and high school students with the opportunity to learn from guest artists from around the globe, to develop professionally and academically, to prepare for college, and to participate in paid internships. 

Why address educational equity? 

New Mexico ranks 50th in the nation for educational outcomes and 49th for child welfare. In a district with a graduation rate of a mere 62.5%, an average household income significantly lower than the national average, and where the largest public schools’ grade ranking continues to plummet, the time to tell to this story is now.

Your sponsorship will fund the tour of Solving for X, and will bring the experiences of our most vulnerable and valuable population to the national stage. What realities must we face in order to understand the opportunity gap? What can we do to make the education system more equitable? How can this production influence future education policy? These questions are at the core of our investigation in our latest theater project.

We ask you to support our young artists and professional actors as they tell this story. This new work aspires to reach a diverse audience through free performances, a regional tour, and workshops with our audiences.

What we need & What you get:

Working Classroom wants to share Solving for X: The Education Project with schools state-wide throughout 2017/2018. If we reach the full amount we will be able to tour the work to Tucson and Phoenix, Arizona. The more we raise, the more we can do.  Our tour package will include:

  • Free performance of Solving for X
  • Free workshop with the cast
  • Free copies of the play
